They defer final judgment to the reader after providing their evaluation, which is characteristic of evaluativist reasoning.

text:
Yes. lol. To all of it.

Warmth is absolutely something that many people are born with or at least learn as pat in their formative years. And like any other inherent trait or natural talent, it can absolutely be intentionally learned as a developed skill as well. And you may very well in fact at least sometimes during the period of working on adopting that characteristic come off as a lizard alien trying to blend in as a human until you find your sweet spot.

If its important to you, then its still worth it. If its not worth that risk and awkwardness and discomfort of trial and error to you, that's totally fine to; plenty of super cool people who happen to be fairly stoic.

Entirely your call.

Oo I think I actually have the opposite problem! Sometimes I do worry though that since I give them out so liberally that it seems disingenuous, but if I say it, I really do mean it. 

If I see something I like or someone does something nice, I just say so. I find that when someone gives me a compliment it often makes my day, so if I have an appropriate opportunity to do this for someone else it makes me really happy. 

Things that work: 
- short and sweet, perhaps going into too much detail with someone you don‚Äôt know well can sometimes be a little too intimate but again really up to you and how you interact
- start off with cool, nice, or any descriptive term and then what you‚Äôre complimenting ‚Äúcool shoes!‚Äù 

It can be hard to make the first few compliments but just be true to yourself, say what you mean, and it‚Äôll be so rewarding. Feel like it has improved my confidence a lot too and I‚Äôm no longer afraid to say ‚Äúgirlll cool outfit!!‚Äù at another girl I see on the street even üòåüòå

stance_markers: ["Here's something to keep in mind", "probably just good at hiding it", "personally when I have to", "This is physiology, nothing more", "I've been married for 7 years now, but I still think back", "If you're in high school or something... but out in the real world"]
text:
Here's something to keep in mind: the difference between nerves/anxiety and excitement is a very fine line. Excitement is just anxiety but with proper breathing. 

I'll get back to that, but first here is something really important to consider:

You are completley normal. What would be abnormal is if you remained completely calm and unaffected by members of the opposite sex you're attracted to. 

Human are so hardwired for sex that we LITERALLY start to have chemical reactions when we're around someone we find attractive. Our hormone levels shoot up, dopamine and norepinephrine course through us and make us feel loopy, give us jitters, make our stomach do flips, and give us insomnia and loss of appetite. 

That is real. The only people who don't are probably just good at hiding it, or actually have something wrong with them.

So knowing that it's normal, just breathe through it. Whatever works for you, but personally when I have to maintain calm when I'm worked up I use a simple 4 count in / 4 count out breath (quiet, continuous, not "deep breaths" just normal breaths basically) and I can actually feel it working: the feeling of terror turns into the feeling of being a kid on Christmas morning in fewer than 10 breaths. 

This is physiology, nothing more. You're still going to feel all those butterflies and flushes and racing heart beat, but the fear will dissipate. And it can start to feel fun!

I've been married for 7 years now, but I still think back to how much I used to LOVE that feeling on a first date. You can actually learn to love and look forward to the exact feelings you're describing as being so uncomfortable now. It's a GOOD discomfort!

It even serves an important function of conveying attraction: people can pick up on this energy, this altered hormonal state, and it can actually be a positive signal. When I went on dates and I saw completely calm unaffected girls, I was like "nah this isnt happening". If their eyes were a little wider, they were laughing a little too much, if they were peeling the label of their beer bottle, if their skin was flushed and they seemed edgy... I considered that a sign they were into me, which can be a really great feeling!

If you're in high school or something and people are going to make fun of you or whatever  you might need to play it cool, but out in the real world, there is absolutely nothing wrong with letting someone you like see they're working their magic on you.

Rejection will happen but that's a different story and a different advice thread.

TLDR: Mastering social skills is about breathing through the awkwardness and jitters NOT preventing them from happening in the first place. 

(That would only be possible through drugs and alcohol -- which I have definitely used to calm my nerves around the opposite sex but it is not what I'm recommending here.)

They acknowledge complexity and trade-offs rather than presenting simple solutions.

text:
You're definitely the weird one, but that doesn't have to be a bad thing.
I think that in a sense, since you don't interact or provide a means of interacting with you it makes them feel less secure because that's how normal people go about trusting people, feeling uncomfortable is a more general feeling than trust but trust is a part of it.

It's up to you to change that, and it's probably going to be hard right now since the first judgements have already cemented the image of you in their memory. Not impossible though.

Save things to do would include asking them for specific help with something that they are able to help you with, asking for an opinion that you know they are opinionated about and being interested in them or helping them with something when they need help, however for the last one only do it if they really struggle or it seems sollicited because you don't want them to wonder why you're helping them.
Humor is also a way to improve your situation but then you can fall in the trap of not being taken seriously ever again.

text:
> ‚Äúmaybe this can change at some point,‚Äù 

Whenever someone says something like this they are always (in a misguided way) trying to soften the blow. 

You don't take it personal by recognizing and believing that it isn't personal, because it's not. Not everybody is going to click or vibe with you, the vast majority of people that anyone meets will not be people who they click or vibe with. If you can genuinely say that you click or vibe with everyone you meet then you don't meet very many people. You may also have the issue that some people here seem to have where they think it is desirable and possible to be liked by everyone, it's not possible and it's not desirable. It's not possible because everyone is different and has different tastes in people and to make yourself palatable to everyone you are making yourself the blandest, most boring person in existence in order not to offend anyones tastes and no one truly likes someone who is bland because there's nothing to actually create interest in you hence why it is not desirable.

text:
I‚Äôve been in a similar situation now for months, and I‚Äôm just starting to break out of it. For me, I realized that fear was holding me back from engaging in new hobbies/activities, and the same thing for talking with new people. Eventually I had to resolve that I wasn‚Äôt going to let fear run my life, and I adopted a mindset to start trying things I‚Äôm afraid of. Run towards the fear. Be the master of your own destiny. Maybe this approach would help you. 

You mentioned that you don‚Äôt have hobbies. I think this is the first place to start- find something you enjoy doing! Start trying things, you never know what might pique your interest. I would suggest dancing classes. They‚Äôre usually free or very cheap (~$10) and tons of people go there just to meet others. And even if people come as a group, dancing is a very social activity so they would welcome you in! Pick a dance of your choice and just go for it!

stance_markers: ["A lot of it depends on", "I think the best advice is to attempt", "can be difficult", "that one is tough", "this should be used with caution", "generally humans find", "taking this too far often results in", "there is no substitute for"]
text:
A lot of it depends on who you are talking to. Each person will bring up new ideas and questions. I think the best advice is to attempt to cultivate a genuine curiosity about other people.

With a teacher asking them about how they got into a subject or if they are a college proffessor reading a bit about their research can open a lot of avenues of conversation.

Classmates can be difficult because you may not always want to be friends with that person, assuming you do try to pay attention to them (in a not obsessive or creepy way), maybe they are doodling something, maybe they are reading a book, or more generally, what are their goals and plans for the future?

People like talking about themselves the more you can become genuinely curious and interested about their life the more you will have to talk about. 

Once you start a nice dialogue you can start trying to relate to people with stories of your own that you think are similar about yourself (this should be used with caution, conversations shouldn‚Äôt feel like they‚Äôre being initiated simply for you to tell a story about yourself, they‚Äôre more to highlight an aspect of the other‚Äôs story that you found interesting).

As for being funny, that one is tough, but generally humans find unexpected things funny. Most comedians talk about common and well known topics, but the punch line is something unexpected, we‚Äôve all thought about that topic 100 times, but they thought of it in that one way that was different and unexpected. This is one reason why Dad Jokes remain a popular form of entertainment, puns are an example of this idea (even though they get overused and can become expected). Cynicism is another often used comedic tool, taking such a caricatured dark perspective on a topic as to shock others, taking this too far often results in a feeling of, ‚Äútoo far,‚Äù or ‚Äútoo soon,‚Äù too cynical can definitely make you appear too callous.

There are many more tools than this, which you can study more formally, but there is no substitute for just talking to people. There are books like ‚ÄúHow to Win Friends and Influence People.‚Äù I‚Äôm sure you can also find books about small talk and incorporating comedy. Some times copying a dialogue or joke is good practice, you might memorize a few jokes you like and try to incorporate them into your conversations that week.

stance_markers: ["It depends", "I've noticed that", "However, I've also", "It's a matter of either", "upon actually getting to know"]
text: It depends. Someone can be friendless due to external/out-of-their-control factors (I.E. bullying, anxiety disorders, personal preference) or due to internal factors. I've noticed that the latter tends to be toxic people - upon actually getting to know my abusive ex, I realized their manipulative ways and selfishness were what drove people away. However, I've also befriended plenty of previously friendless people who simply couldn't approach people first, or weren't given a chance because of reputation or appearance. It's a matter of either getting to know someone, or - in the case of questioning why you, yourself are friendless - getting to know yourself.

text:
Hey man, I just want to say its great that you're making this positive change in your life. I'm sure you made your choice after thinking about it for a long time, and props to you for taking the steps needed to take back control of your life again.

I think a big hurdle in meeting new people is not being ok with yourself. From your post, it seems like you still have troubles confronting your past behaviors. Although joining hobby groups is a great way to meet new people, If you aren't able to open up, nothing's going to come out of it anyway. 

I would strongly encourage you to first become comfortable with yourself, especially in regards to your past. No matter how many people you meet if you aren't able to open up, you won't find the fulfillment you're looking for. There's no shame in having fallen and standing back up. You might think its none of their business, but its part of your identity. Embrace it, learn from it, don't repeat it.

If you're having trouble finding people in your life to talk to about these issues, maybe consider a therapist or a counselor. My inbox is also open if you ever want to talk about anything specific. 

If you have some time I'd encourage you to watch this [Ted Talk] (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iCvmsMzlF7o&t=155s) by Brene Brow. It might be relevant to your situation.

text:
The hotline workers won't be terribly invested in you, but the majority of them try not to let that show. That doesn't mean what they say won't be valuable. I really appreciate having that as an option when I need to talk through something, not because theyre going to solve all my problems but because they know how to deescalate the situation and allow you to talk about yourself and think more objectively. 

I'm not gonna say that people don't think something is wrong with you or that youre totally fine. Im sure you do come off as different than most. However, you aren't a broken or useless person for that. You clearly have issues with mental illness and btw, most peope including myself do. I am 100% confident that your social skills will improve once you can get treatment. Just try to keep in mind that you are more than just your relationships with other people. You're just in a bad situation at the moment, that's not your fault. You arent being allowed the independance you should have. I wish you the best and hope youll be able to get out that situation soon.

text:
Stop overthinking it. Just introduce yourself to anyone you would like to speak to. If someone came up to you and said ‚ÄúHey how are you? My name is ________ what‚Äôs yours?‚Äù Would you see that person as awkward or feel awkward yourself? Probably not. 

I find it‚Äôs easier to just say what‚Äôs on your mind when conversing, you only really need to think about you‚Äôre saying when speaking about a sensitive topic. Causal conversation flows naturally, trust me. And if it doesn‚Äôt that‚Äôs okay too. We are not machines that need to speak 24/7, especially when on a hike where most are too busy taking in gorgeous views.

DIDN't expect for the post to be this long, however i tried to give you the most help i could. if anything else PM me and i'll help you as much as i can, although i am not a pro at social skills i hold my own some what :D

i can relate, with the "how are people talking hours on end while i can't even hold a two minute convo!"

however i feel like i've solved that, well sort of....

what i did was Lower my expectations as to what i was *supposed* to be talking about compared to what actually we talk about. really there is never a standard as to what you should be talking about, you just talk, don't even question as to "is this good enough convo?" or "i don't know what i am going to say/talk about when i am with XXX person!" just don't even preplan scripts or nothing. i'll give you what worked for me!!!!


a while ago i was reading hella books on dating and shit,i still am a virgin but at least better social skills LOL, there was good shit.. mostly some weird mind positive bullcrap. but i can remember two effective concepts i learned from there. 

one- in a conversation there is something called rapport, which is basically the friendlyness of a person to another, basically little raport yields less talk, while more rapport yields more conversation. basically Rapport is how will the person be willing to open up to you, therefore predicting how the conversation will unfold and lenth of convo.

anyway there was a concept in which it talked about conversations. 

the concept of deep rapport vs. wide rapport--
think of it like this... deep rapport is very subject based. while wide rappor is basically really diverse. let me give you an analogy, deep rapport is like a sniping rifle, you are sniping a specific target or object, in the case of conversation is a specific subject, wether you be talking about clothes, finances, school, childhood memories,dogs, movies, etc is very specific. wide rapport is like a shotgun, you are firing multiple shots not just one, this could be like your daily youtube surfing experience where you start by watching a video about dogs, and next thing you are watching a video of a car exploding on a lake. however wide rapport in conversation is a variety of topics to talk about rather than one specific topic on deepRapor, think of the "related videos" on the analogy as how the conversation drifts, you started watching dog videos, but ended in exploding cars, but all due to related videos/convos that were "related" or somehow connected and therefore bled in together to link subject to subject in a conversation.

 So what does this help with fucking conversation and friends and shit you may think. well i'll give you an example.

deep raport. 

*you see a person walking with a dog* 

you say "i like your dog, it looks so diciplined and friendly"

owner: "oh yeah i got it last june... bla bla bla bla bla"

you: "oh cool, i really like dogs, i remember when i was a kid i used to be so jelouse of people who had dogs....bla bla bla "

owner: "yeah you should adopt a dog at xxx shelter buy xxx food, buy xxx bla bla bla bla. 

notice how its always on topic of DOGS, a meaningless conversation but an engaging intresting conversation nontheless.

now wide raport

*you see a person walking with a dog* 

you: "oh cool dog you have i like how its really friendly" or some bullshit equivalent

owner: thanks, i really take care of my dog. 

You: how you got it?

them: oh i got it bla bla bla at the time i was in school. 

you: you reminded me of the time when i was in school, i used to do this shit with my notebook to piss of my classmates" 

them; bla bla bla blal

notice how in wide raport you are drifting away from dogs and start to talk about school, and you can do this jumping from subject to subject back and forth referencing jokes, and building inside jokes, etc. this is valuable skill.

two- the thinking out loud
this is your conversation starter, usually you want to start convos with watever you are thinking on the spot, wether is a though of the person, their first impression, what they remind you of, stories you remember as you are talking. really it doesn't have to be "THAT important" or a subject to talk about it, you could even talk about cartoons, or watever the fuck, when you evesdrop on people's convo they seem kinda trivial cuz you are like "why the fuck are they taking about this random ass shit" but that is how convos work, there is really no criteria to what you should talk about or how long you should talk about anythying. you just have to go with the flow on this one. you just kinda have to share your memories and shit open up, and share your life/thoughts/experiences so that as in return people share theirs with you.


you seem like a kid still, probably highschool or college age kid. i know i was a social inept when i was that age and fucking around like a moron. 

One thing i do warn you about is as you learn social skills you start to uncover other shit. 

not only on the sidebar from learning about

body language, vocal tonality, how convos work. 

you'll start to uncover a bunch of shit like

fucking self esteem, trust me confidence might play such a big part on fucking convos in unbeliable, basically it test you, what you do when you run out of convo? and trust me is a lot, how do you manage other people when you are fucking up or being awkward? how will you manage yourself? how will people respond? do you even care what people think of you? are people ignoring you or am i being boring? ALL these questions i asked myself all the time when i would talk to people but don't sweat it, just keep at it.dam so many questions so many godam topics . using questions over statements, statements vs questions. cold reads, predictions, manipulation, influence/persuasion, compliance,lying, so much fucking shit, which is why there isn't a precise guide to learning socialskills, its mostly based on context, on people's personality, their boldness and self esteem and a bunch of other shit you don't even have control on that will unfold a convo one way or the other.


My recommendation is to build your self esteem, while at the same time learning social skills by talking to people more often. 

My recomendation is that, i get the impression that you don't even bother talking to people. is hard. 

but one of the main concepts you should learn one of the basic ones are even on the side bar BOOKS. Danel Wendler the author of Improve social Skills in a ted talk "think of a conversation as if you were making a sandwich, where you put contribute and ingridient and the other person contributes an ingridient back and forth until you got a sandwhich" basically you talk, they talk, you pay attention, ask questions,etc its all a engagement.

I would say that the coat and the shoes are the things that I look at the most. it's not that I'm sitting there with a checklist trying to determine if this guy is worth dating based on his coat, I'm just talkin about the biological reaction turned on or off. I had to stop dating somebody who had the habit of wearing a peacoat, peacoats and scarves always end up looking feminine. Solid color, non fringed scarf is fine. He also wore pointed-toe shiny dress shoes which looked very... Gay! I'm sorry! It's not about the shoes or the coat or the muscles it's about biological impulses I think. I'm just giving you advice on how to widen your dating pool. Alternatively, don't change a thing, and look for women with short hair and colored hair. Literally 100% of my friends whose type is skinny effeminate guys have short and or colored hair. Or overweight women . I see a lot of overweight women coupled up with short or thin or feminine looking men. Alternatively you could just hold out for that perfect person but that's your choice.

stance_justification: The writer presents their advice as definitive solutions using directive language ('Let that go and say anything random', 'Ask them where they get it from', 'tell them your experience') without acknowledging that conversation strategies might vary by person or context. They frame their approach as the correct method rather than one possible strategy among others.
stance_markers: ["I am assuming you struggle", "Let that go and say anything", "don't just compliment it", "Ask them where they get it from", "tell them your experience", "tell them your genuine opinion", "it's best to practice this"]
text:
I am assuming you struggle to strike up a conversation because you try too hard to think of the most specific and "best" way to find a topic. Let that go and say anything random, whether it's someone's outfit, a random object that reminded you of something, or anything else. Say it, any words that are being said can have a follow up. 

If you see someone wearing shoes you find nice, don't just compliment it and call it over. Although it is a step to make friends since people will feel more comfortable are happier with you that you complimented them, it still will not guarantee a conversation. Ask them where they get it from, tell them your experience with those shoes, tell them your genuine opinion of those shoes from any aspect. 

And if you do that and people still don't say anything, then it's okay. It's not you, sometimes people don't know what else to say for whatever reason. Everyone is different and that's why it's best to practice this with multiple people.

text:
I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre going through this. I know you desire to patch things up and have things return to normal, but this situation screams toxicity. It‚Äôs one-sided. You‚Äôre putting in extraordinary effort, she got used to not having to put in the work in return, took you for granted, and then once you reached your limit with giving her unlimited attention, kindness, and thoughtfulness, she plays the victim card which is meant to make you feel badly for stopping the attention. 

I‚Äôve gone through this with romantic partners and friendships. 

You said yourself she puts in effort with others and gives a blanket statement (I‚Äôm struggling) to diffuse blame. Guess what: We‚Äôre ALL struggling. What about your struggles? There‚Äôs no reciprocation. This is horribly anxiety inducing and hurtful. 

This also isn‚Äôt your fault. OP, it‚Äôs not up to you to put in the effort to rebuild a relationship that she let rot and decay. You tried to breathe life into it for ages, and it didn‚Äôt seem to work. You are much better off putting that effort into making new friends, finding a new hobby, binging a new TV show, or catching up on sleep than to continue putting effort into a relationship with her. This cycle will continue if you let it. She‚Äôll string you along with just enough attention until she‚Äôs sure you‚Äôre in her orbit again. 

I don‚Äôt mean to be pessimistic; I just want you to be protected from something that a lot of us have experienced before. Feel free to DM me if you‚Äôre still having anxiety about this. Best of luck.

They provide structured reasoning with specific examples and invite further dialogue with 'if you have more questions, please feel free to ask,' showing openness to revision.
stance_markers: ["I suggest you to replace", "Maybe you question your action because", "I hope I made my self clearer now", "if you have more questions, please feel free to ask", "I'm kind of repeating my self, because I'm not sure how to correctly express my self", "fyi: I suffer the same problem as you"]
text:
What you described as a moral code of you, is the usual stuff. Its not really your moral code, but this is a moral code designed by a civilized society to keep people from being hurt and respecting their privacy and their life.

What I was talking about is your own moral code. Maybe the word "moral code" are not really a good words for this.

If you watched "How I met your mother", there was a "Bro code" made by Barney Stinson, to sum up how friends should behave when a woman is involved in their relationship (for example: "you dont hit on your friends girlfriend", "friends are always more important than a random girl" and etc). Of course this was made as joke (however some "moral codes" there are good to follow), but this is an example of the stuff I mean.

You need to have your own beliefs on things that matters to you. See, for example: when you don't hurt a person, do you have this feeling of "whether I acted ok now or not"? I guess no, because this is one of your beliefs: that you should not hurt people.

I'm kind of repeating my self, because I'm not sure how to correctly express my self (fyi: I suffer the same problem as you, sometimes I look for confirmation from other people, and keep apologizing about stuff that I think I made wrong).

What I'm trying to say is that you can't just read a book or a how to about moral codes and say "oh ok, so this is how I should behave". You need to decide on stuff that is important to you on a less global level than "dont hurt people". "Dont hurt people" is a very good moral code, and I wish more people would have adopted it, but this is a moral code of a civilized society. Ideally, its applies to the whole society, while what I'm talking about is moral codes for **you** as an individual. If you dont have such, you are just copying other peoples behavior and loose yourself as an individual.

I suggest you to replace the though of "was it ok that I did X?" with the though "Why do I question the act of doing X?" It will help you to understand yourself better. Try to find the answer to this question. 

* Whether is lack of confidence that makes you question your actions? - Then work on your confidence.
* Maybe you question your action because this action really does not express who you are as an individual? - Then you should probably stop acting like this. Or if you really believe that this is the way you should behave then you need to give this action a time to "grow" into your belief. Lets say you decided that you need to be more dominant by speaking louder. It will feel awkward at the beginning, because you just planted a seed in your head "I want to speak louder". But this seed still needs to grow and become your belief. While it was not grown yet, you will continue to question your loud talking action: "am I talking too loud?" "what if the other person thinks I was shouting at him?" and etc. The more confidence you build, the less time it will take this seed to grow and become your adopted belief.

I hope I made my self clearer now, if you have an more questions, please feel free to ask and Ill try to answer!

stance_justification: The writer provides reasoned guidance while consistently acknowledging that different people have valid but different perspectives and boundaries. They engage substantively with the complexity of interpersonal relationships, offering specific strategies ('establish rapport,' 'have open conversations') while recognizing that outcomes are uncertain and context-dependent.
stance_markers: ["It's reasonable and doesn't disqualify as many people as you might think", "Know that your own boundaries will be different than others' and that's okay, it doesn't necessarily invalidate either party", "you may not be able to generalize why others feel that, but they do and that's valid because it's their personal experience", "If you think you are making an assumption about someone, it would likely be better for both of you if you just asked", "without invalidating others or comparing your perspectives"]
text:
It's great that you have a sense of what you're looking for. And it's okay if that idea changes/stays the same over time. It's reasonable and doesn't disqualify as many people as you might think.

So how do you find what you're looking for? It's unlikely that you'll know right away. Establish rapport with girls or friends that seem interested in you and then have an open conversation. Let them know where you're at/what you're comfortable with. These are valid and they matter. 

Know that your own boundaries will be different than others' and that's okay, it doesn't necessarily invalidate either party. You might not have that sense of urgency in common with some people, and you may not be able to generalize why others feel that, but they do and that's valid because it's their personal experience. Keep that in mind if you meet someone you end up not meshing with. Don't shame them and don't accept invalidation.

Give yourself time with people and give yourself the opportunity to find what you're looking for through open communication. If you think you are making an assumption about someone, it would likely be better for both of you if you just asked. If you want to develop experience with someone who is at your own level, that makes sense, don't beat yourself up for it. If you don't want to drink, that's valid. You can have a valid position free of comparison to what others seem to like.

Advocate for yourself compassionately, without invalidating others or comparing your perspectives, try not to take others' preferences personally, and conversations should go smoothly.

text:
Honestly? I‚Äôm neuroatypical with a lot of friends on the spectrum as well and some of your ‚Äòreal you flaws‚Äô aren‚Äôt flaws to me. Like, it‚Äôs okay to be cringey and obsessive‚Äîand also controlling, up to a certain point (ie when I go to my friends‚Äô for a few days I end up cleaning their space to feel ‚Äòin control‚Äô of this new environment). Anger and dominance are problems though.

What I suggest is, instead of having this ‚Äòfake you‚Äô that will, in the end, get you nowhere in terms of long-standing friendships/relationships, you should work on the anger and dominance issues. (Idk you so the best I can advise is a therapist, but it depends on your situation of course.) And once these issues are settled, find someone that will like that cringe, obsessive self of yours!! Might be a little long but it absolutely will be more rewarding in the end.

PS: you said you thought you were on the spectrum at one point, but faking to be liked is one of the symptoms too. did you get a counter-diagnosis to give the idea up like that?

And either way, that's life'). The advice centers on personal choice without criteria for making better decisions.

And either way, that's life", "It will happen in its own course", "that's okay"]
text: Cheers. And I'm not saying don't have a casual fling if the opportunity presents itself and that's what you want, but also don't feel pressure to settle if you'd rather hold out for something better. There's no formula that says you must hook up by X age or sleep with Y number of partners. These things vary a LOT (and don't assume that other people talking about their "numbers" are being honest either), so do what feels right for you. I'll tell you my first time was lame as shit. I thought it was just something I needed to get over with because of my age, and it sucked. Loads of people end up feeling that way. I don't beat myself up about it, but I'm not proud of it either. Know what I mean? There's no right or wrong way for all of this to go down. Your first relationship might be phenomenal, and it might be a total dud. And either way, that's life. You'll be just fine. It's hard at your age, but try not to build it up in your head. There will be a first time, and there will be times after that. It will happen in its own course. It (probably) won't be the earth-shattering event you thought it would be, and that's okay. That's why I say keep working on yourself. Take care of yourself, and maintain other interests. Ten years from now you will look back and laugh at your younger self, I promise. For now, just enjoy the ride.

They demonstrate evaluative thinking by examining how different communication modes serve different people's needs ('helps people who are socially awkward') and different contexts ('more involved or complex conversations'). Rather than declaring one method superior, they analyze situational factors and recognize the complexity of communication preferences.
stance_markers: ["But everyone is different", "I find it helps to understand preferences", "It helps people who are socially awkward or have social anxiety in some instances and this is good", "I still find that conversation allows you to cut through to the point faster", "Other people though sometimes", "This indicates to me"]
text:
Phone calls are more interactive and more information can be processed faster because of that. If someone answers a text and it wasn‚Äôt what you were looking for then you may start to realize how hard it is to get an answer this way. I find typing tedious after spending my work day on the computer. But everyone is different and I find it helps to understand preferences. When email first became generally available I found that I could finally communicate with people who didn‚Äôt do as well in conversation. But email was still mail so you had to wait for delivery and response. Texting is closer to conversation. It  helps people who are socially awkward or have social anxiety in some instances and this is good. I still find that conversation allows you to cut through to the point faster in more involved or complex conversations. 

It is interesting to me how I feel like a benefit of texting is that the person can respond when it is convenient- the one downside of phone calls because they demand that you engage immediately. You can think before responding to a text without the sense of an awkward silence. Other people though sometimes apologize because it has taken them 3 or 4 hours to respond. This indicates to me that they expect me to treat it as a phone call - so many new rules for engagement!

text:
You are being too needy and she can probably detect that. Chill out, take a step back and let her come to you as she originally did. Also there‚Äôs never a reason to talk to someone for 3 hours unless you‚Äôre getting paid or they are for listening to you.

People are scared of needy stalker type people. Don‚Äôt be like that. It‚Äôs possible she was bored and playing with you, don‚Äôt take talk so serious, it‚Äôs cheap. Action speaks louder than words. If she approaches you again it means she‚Äôs attracted to you (doesnt have to be sexual) know that,use it to your advantage so you don‚Äôt feel so desperate to talk to her and lose your mind. 

You need to find who you are and what you‚Äôre worth before worrying about having friend‚Äôs girlfriend etc. if I were you career/education, physical fitness, and hobbies would be my priority. Everything else will come in time...

Love yourself, learn how to. When you love yourself people will feel that and be drawn to you without trying. 

Im sorry to be hard but when I was 17 I was like you. You can change for the worse or better, it‚Äôs up to you.

text:
Ha didnt mean to upset you to that extent, i feel like perhaps i didnt clarify enough.

>How the fuck is that not rude? I wouldn't even say this person is much of a "friend" at this point either. Friendships aren't one way streets.

I absolutely agree, the person is being rude and i'm not trying to advocate that OP just sits back and takes it.  Certainly not, that won't help anything.

>No, fuck that, if OP wants change, he/she has to address it. Thinking that it's only OP that is due to his friends not listening and even cutting him/her off is naive.

Again, i apologize that you've inferred that the blame is on OP entirely,  i believe that the other party is the guilty one.  However we also don't know if OP is bringing this on themselves a bit (with their reactions/body language) or if OP just has some pretty bad taste in friends.  We really can't say anything definitively, but his "friends" do sound like asses. 

>Maybe two wrongs don't make a right, but OP isn't going to get any improvement if he stays in fear of upsetting his "friends".

Here's where I both agree and disagree.  I really believe that OPs "friend" is being totally rude (and selfish).  However I dont think he/she should fight rude with rude.  When you call people out on their personality flaws (valid, though they may be), the majority of people will take offense and rather than apologize, become defensive.  Especially in a situation where you are coming off as rude.  Does the other party deserve OP calling them out? Yeah likely...  However I believe its in OPs best interest to tread carefully.  If she/he confronts someone on being rude and they respond apologetically and sincerely sorry, I have to imagine OP will feel kind of bad for being so confrontational.  My suggestion would be for OP to be careful as he tells people he feels like he's not being listened to.  I think he should bring it up, but test the waters light-heartedly before going full "fight fire with fire", that's all.

They present their advice as considered judgments rather than absolute truths or mere personal opinions.
stance_markers: ["I think that if you have negative feelings after opening up to someone, it is due the other person", "Everyone is different, so I don't expect", "I think you have to learn to accept", "it definitely takes time and practice", "I definitely obsess over things, and I have to tell myself"]
text:
This used to be a huge problem for me. I always think about what other people say. Opening up to people has been an ongoing work in progress over the past few years. I've definitely felt like I'm blabbing when I talk about myself, but putting myself out there has really helped me make more friends and become better friends with my current ones.

I think that if you have negative feelings after opening up to someone, it is due the other person not being empathetic or just not responding in a caring manner. I am a very private person, and I will only open up to certain people- people who I know will be empathetic or offer me advice. Everyone is different, so I don't expect all of my friends to give me the advice I need for all my problems. I will sometimes go to certain friends for certain situations, because I know that person has the experience or time to advise or comfort me. 

I think you have to learn to accept your actions and problems, whatever they may be. We're all weird, do weird things sometimes, and have problems. I definitely obsess over things, and I have to tell myself to stop, it'll be ok, no one will remember in a few days because they're probably thinking about their own problems. But it definitely takes time and practice to become accustomed to opening up.

They demonstrate awareness of complexity ('Aspergers is more complicated than some...seem to realize') and calibrate their confidence appropriately, offering multiple qualified suggestions rather than definitive answers.
stance_markers: ["I would take a lot of the advice in this thread with a grain of salt including mine", "Aspergers is more complicated than some of the people this thread seem to realize", "I think we maybe looking into something with a behavioral psychology approach", "might also be a good accompaniment", "probably a good idea", "may be more that people just need time", "They probably mean well but don't really understand", "You can consider adding", "This may be overwhelming but", "Whatever works for you", "I'd look into some behavior modification therapy and maybe run my ideas past your therapist"]
text:
I would take a lot of the advice in this thread with a grain of salt including mine. Aspergers is more complicated than some of the people this thread seem to realize. I guess the reason people don't realize what it means to have Asperger's is from your post because you seem to be relatively high functioning compared to some people with Asperger's I've read about or interacted with, and you're aware of the effects of your actions. You analyzing your own mannerisms might not be possible and just being confident and not giving a fuck is just bad advice from someone that doesn't understand Asperger's.


So I definitely think you should discuss these matters with your therapist or consider seeking a new one altogether. Heck, just print out the post you just wrote and show it to them and say "I don't feel like I'm getting help with this here can we focus on this or can you recommend someone who can?"


I think we maybe looking into something with a behavioral psychology approach.


Wikipedia says on the Asperger page that there is therapy called social communication intervention which is a special type of speech therapy that focuses on I think what you're talking about.

Joining a Toastmasters speech giving group might also be a good accompaniment to this.  You'll never run out of material of what it's like living with Asperger's and you'll have an audience of people to give you feedback.


As far as your ability to make friends, it may be more that people just need time to hang out with you to see past your social awkwardness at first. So clubs and groups organizations that you have an interest in are probably a good idea for you. Sports or activities based organizations are probably a good idea, the social aspect is definitely still there, but if you can throw a frisbee a mile or you are a great rockclimber your social awkwardness is going to be less important.


As far as your fraternity friends. They probably mean well but don't really understand what it means to have Asperger's. Confidence/being relaxed will help but doesn't really get to the source of your issues. 


As far as being teased, that's just what having a a large group of male friends is like. People tease each other as a way of showing that they are part of the group that while you may have faults you're still one of us. Somewhat related to self-deprecating humor. I'd ask a close friend in the fraternity if this is what is going on when people are making fun of you. 

Everyone has boundaries for what they're comfortable joking about. Examples include, it's fine for you to make self-deprecating jokes about your Asperger's, and even for your friends to do it every once in a while, but a whole circle of friends making the same joke at once is crossing the line. It's totally acceptable to let people know that. "Guys make fun of me for my giant nose all you want but take it easy on the asperger's."


Asperger's is just an aspect of who you are it's not the only one. That doesn't mean that you should deny it completely either. Better to be honest, "yeah guys I have Asperger's it can fucking suck sometimes and I can be awkward, doesn't mean I can't kick your ass at beerpong."


Which leads me to the idea of whether or not you have weekly chapter meetings in your fraternity. Write up the speech and ask the president if you can present it at the chapter meeting. You should probably have friends look it over first. Of course you can say what you want, but I think the idea of it would be to let your fraternity know how you feel about having Asperger's, what's cool to make fun of what isn't, let them know that yeah you're to be awkward sometimes, but maybe they can help you be less awkward by letting you know occasionally when you're missing some social signals or what it is that you're doing specifically that is awkward.


You can consider adding a signal you can pick up on with your friends for when you're doing something awkward, such as them scratching their shoulder. This may be overwhelming but you can probably have them try to pick out one thing to work on for a while, maybe you're voice pitch is all over the place or you  maintain eye contact too long. Whatever works for you. If you're in a group of people and they signal you, you can talk about it later with them. Or maybe they can give you the signal that you're doing something awkward and then give you a nonverbal cue of what it is you need to fix.


Honestly not everyone in your fraternity is going be stoked about helping the new awkward guy be less awkward. But most will understand and some will be take an active interest in helping you hopefully.


Find out from the helpful ones what your social strengths are, whether you're funny, or you have interesting things to say about music, or some aspect of your Asperger's syndrome is particularly funny that you can play on and let strangers know you're aware of some of your awkward habits (sort of). Then play on these strengths.

As far as sorority girls... I mean I was in a Fraternity and hung out with sorority girls. But honestly a lot of them suck, some are really cool, but many will be too shallow to give you the time you deserve to get to know you especially when drunk at a party. But I virtually guarantee none of the girls think of themselves this way. 

Larry king says in awkward situations when you don't feel like talking to anyone but you know you should, it's best to just acknowledge that the situation is awkward. It breaks the ice and helps everyone relax. When you're introducing yourself to someone at a party "hey I know I can be awkward and I sound retarded sometimes but I assure you I'm not... Well I am awkward". sorry to put it that way I don't mean to be offensive but the idea is to disarm the person and hopefully get a laugh. Of course you can word it however you want though. 


FYI parties clearly aren't the most effective time for this but it's what you have to work with. Just try to do this before the party gets going, before there are other party distractions, and the girls have had a chance to analyze you from a distance and realize that you're awkward and decide they don't want you approaching them in the first place. (three second rule) So just figure out a way to come clean. And let them know why you're acting awkward is that you have Aspergers.  If you're awkward as you say people are going to figure out something is kind of weird anyways,  might as well let them know what it is. People generally are scared of what they don't understand , you're just helping them understand you. If this backfires does it make much of a difference if you go from that weird awkward guy to that weird awkward guy with Asperger's?


So find a nice friendly one not just someone you're attracted to, because attention whores and hot bitchy girls this probably won't work with and your goal isn't to get laid right away (not to say it won't), you want her to get to know you so they can vouch to other girls for you and maybe set you up.  Act as though you're looking for a sympathetic female ear, honestly that's all you really are doing. Let her know that you have Asperger's found that you know that you  can act awkward sometimes and miss social queues. That you're not some fucking weirdo, you know you're doing it but there's not much you can do about. But maybe she can. Let her know the last time you had a mixer with another sorority you  felt like the girls never really gave you a chance to get to know you. They were bunch of bitches and you were excited because you heard the sorority was really nice. Ask her if maybe she could help you out a little bit, have her let you know what you're doing that's awkward, and or be her little pet project for the night to help you make some lady friends. Play some drinking games together, have her introduce you to her other lady friends. I don't mean play the pity card, just try to get her to empathize with you, that you thought that she looked friendly and would see past your Asperger's (it's a social strategy of giving someone a reputation to live up to). Hopefully she will see past it. Ask her she's done anything as awkward as you have lately. Girls tend to have a sense of humor about their own awkwardness  as long as you're empathizing with them.


Beyond that just trying to be interesting, relaxed, friendly and  make sure you're well-dressed and groomed (more things to ask a girls opinion on by the way).


Just talking to people at parties is hard enough even when you don't have Asperger's is hard enough. So activities are your best ally, drinking games, dancing etc.


I wouldn't worry too much about sorority girls tho. I love some of them but, as a group they suck. Like really suck. House parties are where it is at anyways, people tend to not be such social animals and kind of resent that part of the Greek system. I had friends in an outside of the Greek system and I'm well aware of the pros and cons. The Greek system is a great way to meet people but there's also a lot of social drama and hierarchy that goes  along with it.

Also you kind of reminded me of this, 
http://charismaarts.com/

Wayne Elise "juggler" puts on conversation boot camps directed towards interacting with and attracting women specifically body language type stuff. I'd email him and explain your situation, if that is  something you might actually be interested in. He would know more if they could actually benefit.  I haven't taken it, but Wayne has a reputation as an honest no trickery approach to interacting with women within the "seduction community." if you don't know what the seduction community is look up the game by Neil Strauss.  The Seduction community Does help with the specifics if interactions and probably something worth looking into and could help you, but it is a pretty easy to get carried away with it. You might especially become too focused on all the little rules and guidelines and it could make things worse.  Just check it out.I don't follow that stuff anymore, I learned what I needed to and I got out before I got sucked in. 


Hope some of that helped if you have another questions just ask. I'd look into some behavior modification therapy and maybe run my ideas past your therapist. Best of luck.

text:
My bro and me were over 5 years apart and I too was a little worried like you. He maybe the way he is because in part he doesn‚Äôt have the money to really do things. As long as he appears to act normally around you and your brothers he should be fine. Take a closer look at his behavior and make comments if they wouldn‚Äôt be acceptable in a social setting. 

Like my bro he maybe just a late bloomer. Everyone is different. And maybe in some ways this maybe a blessing when he goes to college where he doesn‚Äôt just hang out with his own high school cliche. 

More importantly is his grades and how he deals with frustration/anger. That where you and your bro can really guide him by explaining the next time things flare up on how you guys deal with it. Talking about how things suck sometimes and how things don‚Äôt always go your way would help. Life‚Äôs up and down. Most importantly just let your bro know that you will always be there when ever he wants to talk.

stance_justification: The writer presents their advice as reasoned judgment ('IMO') rather than absolute truth, provides a logical sequence of steps with explanations for why each matters, and shows metacognitive awareness of contradictions in their own approach ('The trick here is...'). They acknowledge the complexity and challenge of their advice ('Which is hard because...') and demonstrate self-reflection about their own tendencies toward condescension.
stance_markers: ["IMO", "You have to decide", "The trick here is", "Which is hard because", "Which is a challenge I face", "because I'm an ok guy"]
text:
> How do I relate with others? Through reading, exercise, hobbies? How should I be interesting and easily hold chemistry with people?

IMO, do you first.  You have to decide what you want to do with yourself, who do you want to be, what you enjoy doing.

Do those things, be comfortable and happy with an identity of yourself exposed through your actions, interests, and choices.

Then you are interesting to people because you are doing things that they aren't, you can talk about those things, you can talk about the things others do that you don't, and why.

The trick here is to actual give a shit about people.  Which is hard because to start with you have to not give a shit.  You become who you want to be on your terms by not caring about what others think.

But when you want to then relate to people, you need to actually care again.

Also, you need to not be condescending.  Which is a challenge I face, ~~because I am literally the best person in the world~~ because I'm an ok guy

stance_justification: The writer demonstrates evaluativist thinking by weighing competing values (honesty vs. empathy), providing nuanced reasoning for different scenarios, and acknowledging complexity rather than presenting absolute rules. They show metacognitive awareness with phrases like 'I'd say my belief is a little more complicated' and provide conditional reasoning throughout.
stance_markers: ["I'd say my belief is a little more complicated", "largely because I don't see honesty and empathy as diametrically opposed", "For me they are two fairly separate values", "with the caveat that", "except for when I believe it would achieve nothing positive", "it's far more likely to have a chance of being hear enough", "depending on my relationship with them, I may or may not admit that", "USUALLY the best policy to me, except for when"]
text:
Lmao! You‚Äôve got me on that first one. They‚Äôre dying, it‚Äôs too late to work out yall‚Äôs issues, honesty in this instance has no value. Tell em you love me n let em die in peace.

Literal life and death stakes aside however...

They‚Äôre not dying? Again, even hard truths can be delivered empathetically. You can characterize your struggle to love them as exactly that... a struggle. Something you would want to be able to feel. You can acknowledge their own struggles in addressing the issues with their behavior, etc. If for no one other reason than that it‚Äôs far more likely to have a chance of being hear enough for them to make an effort when it‚Äôs said that way rather than an accusatory diatribe. If they didn‚Äôt ask, you only have to do that second part and only if it‚Äôs a relationship you still consider worth trying to salvage. Being honest does not, after all, mean always sharing everything you think and feel solicited or not.

Coming out of the closet is a very personal choice. If you‚Äôre not ready, you‚Äôre not ready. But if your parents are homophobic not telling them is realistically the kinder/more empathetic act anyway so again... the truth vs empathy choice isn‚Äôt actually present. If they didn‚Äôt ask but you DO want to come out... again, that news can in fact be delivered with empathy. When I came out as bi to my father for who IK that would be a challenging thing to accept and understand I acknowledged that. I told him that this was who I was, that I would always be available to answer any questions he had even if they were uncomfortable for me, that if it wasn‚Äôt something he was ready to talk about I would respect that too. I told him that this was who I was and a part of my life and that I still wanted HIM to also be a part of my life and that, however he needed to show up, there would always be a place in my life for him.

I tend to focus my appreciation for gifts on the thought/consideration put into it. It may or may not be something I‚Äôll actually end up using and, depending on my relationship with them, I may or may not admit that... but that doesn‚Äôt mean I‚Äôm not touched by it either way.

I‚Äôm actually pretty honest about this tho I do try to do so kindly. ‚ÄúYeah... but it‚Äôs cute AF! I can let it out here n here probs n maybe do a cinch here if you want it to be more slimming... but that‚Äôs you‚Äôre call, mine would be to rock your bodacious ass!‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre gorgeous n awesome home girl n yeah, your ass got some extra cushion for the pushin, don‚Äôt play like you don‚Äôt know that! Ain‚Äôt an issue for me n IK it damn sure ain‚Äôt for plenty of fools you might wanna holla at but if it is for you... happy to be a workout/diet buddy if that‚Äôs important to you!‚Äù Etc.

I‚Äôd say my belief is a little more complicated largely because I don‚Äôt see honesty and empathy as diametrically opposed or even necessarily directly related. For me they are two fairly separate values. 

I believe it‚Äôs always best to practice empathy in everything as best Im able... with the caveat that empathy does NOT mean never telling anyone anything they might not want to hear; it means being consistently cognizant of other‚Äôs feelings and taking them into consideration. 

And honesty is USUALLY the best policy to me, except for when I believe it would achieve nothing positive and would in fact have purely negative impact... and again with the caveat that honesty does not mean always saying every damn thing on your mind lol; it just means speaking and acting sincerely and authentically w/out deception.

stance_justification: The writer consistently frames all approaches to friendship as equally valid without evaluating their relative merits. They use pure relativistic language like 'There isn't a right "meter"' and 'There isn't a "right" way to be friends' and defer all judgment to personal fit ('find someone that fits with you'). Rather than weighing different friendship approaches, they present contradictory advice (being available vs. not being too available) without acknowledging the tension.
stance_markers: ["There isn't a right \"meter\"", "There isn't a \"right\" way to be friends", "find someone that fits with you", "only he doesn't fit with you", "Look for someone that fits with you", "It's normal", "it's okay"]
text:
In my experience, if you make friends... you will realize that they have their lives too, and their lives and facts are often more important than being available or worried for you. It's normal to be a friend, and having a life; it's okay if you want to pass some time alone, if you wish time to care for yourself. There isn't a right "meter", to establish how much time you need. There isn't a "right" way to be friends, if you are loyal; do not feel guilt, you have just to find someone that fits with you and have similar needs.

It happens also that if you are too much focused on being "available" for your friends, therefore you become angry when they aren't available for you, so you become "selfish" in another way.

Do not worry, and please understand that it's not entirely up to you. You are only half responsible for the success of your friendship. Even if someone dislikes your "friendship style", only he doesn't fit with you. Look for someone that fits with you... At least to begin.

They offer qualified suggestions ('it might be better to just watch people dancing') and show awareness of complexity ('The leap to the dance floor with people is still hard'). stance_markers: ["A bit odd maybe", "it really depends on the person if that works", "it might be better to", "should get you started", "The leap to the dance floor with people is still hard", "source: started dancing in front of my mirror"]
text:
A bit odd maybe and it really depends on the person if that works but: You say you listen to music all the time. Do you have a full body mirror? If yes, stand in front of that, turn the music on and start to move. Try to have fun with looking silly (you will definitely look the part in the beginning).

Don't try anything fancy, rather find some simple moves that you can repeat to almost any rythm. It's alright to be repetitive, you most likely don't plan to dance for hours straight during your first try. Rather a couple minutes and then some time back at the bar to relax.

You could look up some simple steps online, but instead of learning full-on choreographies, it might be better to just watch people dancing at the club and pick some very easy moves that look solid and won't make you stand out.

If you're dancing in front of a mirror for a couple songs each day and actually manage to find the fun in moving to music, you will eventually get better. The leap to the dance floor with people is still hard, but with some alcohol and long breaks in between, you confidence should rise. Especially later in the evening, when everyone's really drunk and almost no one can dance anymore anyways.

Or maybe even better, at a concert, where everyone is looking to the front.

Actually dancing *with* someone instead of next to someone is a different beast, but that should get you started.

(source: started dancing in front of my mirror as a young teen, mainly because I was bored and too young to really go out. I'm nothing compared to professionals, but I get complemented for it. It's just practice after all, not unlike what people do in a dance studio all the time.)

stance_justification: The writer presents their advice as definitive steps that will work, using directive language like 'Basically buy yourself some time' and prescriptive instructions without acknowledging uncertainty or alternative approaches. stance_markers: ["Basically buy yourself some time", "say something like", "go back with a short, crisp reason", "Showing that your choice was", "resist the urge to", "For extra mileage"]
text:
2 things:

1. Stall (in a mature way). Basically buy yourself some time to think more rationally. Rather than say yes in the moment, say something like ‚Äúlet me get back to you on that‚Äù and then take time to assess whether it‚Äôs something you want to and should do.

2. Say a positive no. If after your assessment, you‚Äôd rather not do said thing, go back with a short, crisp reason starting with a polite ‚ÄúI would have loved to do xyz but there is abc other thing I have to do instead.‚Äù Showing that your choice was for something else shows that you didn‚Äôt turn them down thoughtlessly. Pause for a response and resist the urge to over-explain. For extra mileage with the relationship, offer some hope for possibly doing said thing in the future, but give no promises or hard deadlines. 

Good luck!

stance_justification: The writer presents their claims as experience-based judgments rather than absolute truths, using qualifying language like 'from my experience' and 'depends on.' They engage with the complexity of friendship dynamics by acknowledging multiple factors and trade-offs, while providing reasoned analysis of why certain approaches work or don't work.
stance_markers: ["Few things here I can talk from my experience", "Depends what city/environment you're from", "From my experience", "I can get that basically", "Generally people are not often initiative", "More often than not you're just not surrounded by the right people"]
text:
Few things here I can talk from my experience  
1. Depends what city/environment you're from. Some countries and cities are much simpler with that and people are friendly and want to hang out all the time. In others meeting once a few months is considered "friendly", so it depends on your needs and frequency of interactions  
2. From my experience, the more I push on the friendly angle and really try to explain it's important to me - the more it pushes people away. It's still frustrating to me, but I can get that basically people just want to hang out and have fun. If I want to hang out once every week and you keep initiating stuff all the time and asking me to hang out - it will push me away, so you need to feel that out
3. Generally people are not often initiative, even if they are really good friends, because only a handful of people in general take initiatives, so you shouldn't expect that either, that's just sadly how it is
4. Feel free to reach out if you wanna try to be friends, I relate a lot to what you've talked about and we can try to get to know each other  

Either way, best of luck with your searches, don't give up. More often than not you're just not surrounded by the right people for you that makes it frustrating for both you and them, and there might be a place where you feel welcomed and valued instead, and people share your values with deep talks, hanging out a lot, and initiating more hanging out - it's up to you to sit down, write down what's important for you in a friendship, what expectations you have from others, what is not being fulfilled and why, and then doing something with that information, and seeing how those needs are met in other places

stance_markers: ["Ask yourself if", "you have to decide between one or the other", "In my experience", "if the decision is between", "I've mostly regretted", "Is she worth the risk?", "If the answer is yes", "you will learn"]
text:
Tldr: ask yourself if she's worth it ?

Ask yourself if your are satisfied with friendship or you're looking for a relationship. The answer should be obvious. Remember, you have to decide between one or the other. If it's friendship you value then don't ask her out and if it's romantic relationship with her that you want, you have to risk loosing friendship. 

In either case a decision will be made. However, If you want control, you need to make the decision and stick with it. What you decide is correct.

Once you've decided if it's romantic relationship you're looking for.

Ask her out. If you don't take the risk, you'll simply be wasting time with someone who's isn't going to reciprocate. That feeling you have while chatting with her till 2am or when you think about her, that's your gut feeling. You have a doubt because you don't know if it's right.

Sadly, the only way you can only know and gain advantage is by testing it. In my experience, if the decision is between doing and not doing something, I've mostly regretted choosing the latter. 

If she accepts you.. well, you have a girl you like :D. That's the reward.

If she rejects you, it will hurt you like hell, and make you sad. that's the risk. Is she worth the risk ? If the answer is yes, you know what to do, if she isn't, well time  
to move along.

Failing will suck, but you will learn. Lot of fish in the sea mate.

Good luck

text:
Part of being professional is establishing personal boundaries and respecting others'. If someone wants to name his/her kid Ainsleigh, you respect that and don't get upset over someone else's personal choice that doesn't affect your daily activities. On the flip side, if people want to constantly engage you in conversation, try to show some body language that implies that you'd rather not hold a conversation too long: shoulders away from them, or just a smile instead of a verbal response to indicate that you'd like the talk to end.

What is your ideal situation of you socializing with your coworkers or your coworkers approaching you?

text:
You are still very young at 16. I have seen a lot of socially awkward penguins transform into socially charismatic gods in their twenties. 

I am not going to lie though, your lack of social situation does seem dire. The solution is simple yet extremely difficult. Go out and socialize. It's an extremely difficult task which is why you are going to have to approach this with baby steps. Different methods work for different people hence, I can't tell you what you have to do, you will have to figure out this yourself. Remember, go slow. You will fall and fail umpteen times but that's how we grow as a person. Embrace failure and enjoy success.

Seriously, I think you are worrying too much. There is still a lot of time for you to grow as a person. One more thing, I am not a psychiatrist, but it is always better to make sure you don't have any mental illness contributing to your problem, such as depression or social anxiety disorder .etc

It was never your fault", "You're worth your autonomy", "the people who make an effort to be in your life...they love you"]
text:
Hey, listen! I'm you! I'm you and I'm gonna say a thing: your post sounds like the after effect of childhood trauma. You know how there's Flight or Flight? It's actually Fight, Flight, Freeze, Fawn. You're fawning, but something is making you direct failed attempts (or even any attempts, as you're frustrated with the sense of even needing to do this) inwardly, as negative thought and self-hatred. *I know how you feel.* ***I know, exactly, how you feel.*** 

>I still want to be nice but I want to be able to say ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

Baby these things are not mutually exclusive. *You can be nice and still consider your needs before others.* Love, you're important. Try a thing: you know your best friend? Someone you could never hurt, like they accept you for everything you are? Ask them to ask you things. *Tell them no*. Telling people no *takes practice*. Establishing boundaries is not a thing you just "do" overnight. It takes *work*, it takes *practice* to identify when you *WANT* to say no, but say yes anyway, and practice *not doing it*. This is a skill I'm working on *right beside you*. I've *always* done it. Accepting invites to do things when I had other things planned, or when I don't have the "spoons"/energy/time. Apologizing for *everything* in an attempt to lessen my perceived *punishment* for not doing so in the form of social rejection. My dude, my dog. *You can't please everyone.* Love, don't even try. Friends are going to understand. Just be real with them "hey I don't have the spoons today to hang". "Aight np". You're not going to nuke, in a 300,000 degree apocalypse, your friendships over the word "No."

>but I fucking hate myself I‚Äôll always fucking hate myself.

I want to hug the shit out of you. I know this feeling all too well, and I know the *crushing* weight of what it feels like to live every day under it. To feel like a *snake*, hated and feared, misunderstood. I'm not going to tell you to just magically like, or love yourself (r/thanksimcured). I'm *going* to say that there's a *reason* you feel like this, and I'm gonna venture a wild guess that something, some emotional experience *forged* your thoughts into.. this. *Listen to me and listen good*: ***It's not your fault. It was never your fault.*** 

You're worth your autonomy and boundaries. You can't please everyone, but the people who make an effort to be in your life, and the ones you make an effort toward, they *love you.* I love you. Because I know where you're at. DM me if you don't want to go buck-ass with comments in this thread.

text:
I've actually encountered some demons. Here's what you do:

1. Show up before everybody else every day.
2. Master every task.
3. Be annoyingly upbeat and nice (think Kenneth the Page on 30 Rock)
4. Whenever you screw up (cos you will) laugh at yourself. Then they'll think, "Oh. Recaculating..."
5. Stop seeking their approval.

You can't get fired for doing a good job. Don't you dare leave that job! You're entitled to that money just as much as they are. You know what I do? I come up with my own nicknames for a-holes. So everytime Mr. Thunderbreath comes up to you with a joke, you're laughing at him already and he can't figure out why.

It's a job. It's money. It's Biblical punishment. Contrary to what our lazy hippie parents told us, we're not supposed to enjoy it. They aren't your friends either so don't expect any kind of human decency.

text:
I think it's important to keep in mind that you are going to need to do the legwork to hook up with new friends. To meet people with similar interests go to social events that center on or are tangential to those things you are interested in. Search out groups in your area. They don't come to you. They may not be big on broadcasting themselves either. If you like manga, then go to the local shop and talk to the shopkeeper. Let him know you're new and see who (s)he knows. If you seem like a decent guy then (s)he may just invite you to their social circle. 

Everyone is entitled to their own interests and your's are perfectly valid, but as somebody else said, it may be good to get into some activities that lend themselves to creating social connections and avoid ones that seclude or isolate participants.

text:
Bruh, this isn't a math problem. You're trying to figure out a single algorithm for approaching girls, but there's so many things wrong with that way of thinking:

1. You can't generalize behavior to a rote series of steps and "execute" a routine every time for success. You've been told this time and again.
2. You're asking how you can know whether someone will be receptive in advance. Partly, I hope, out of consideration for the other person, but given the other things you've written, I get the sense that you're also doing it to shield your own ego and avoid the possibility of being seen as a creep. You can't account for the gamut of potential reactions you could get from approaching someone, because most of the factors are out of your control. Sure, there are things you can to improve your chances, but beyond common courtesy, how you're received isn't really up to you. You have to decide, situation by situation, whether approaching someone is worth the risk. And once you've done that, you need to pay constant attention to how you're being received.

&#x200B;

>You infer that I am angry; I did not say I was.

I wouldn't describe you as angry, but your original tone sure was petulant, self-pitying, and demanding. Like, do you not see the problem with repeating this so many times in your original post? Do you not see how that comes across?

>What, exactly, are the rules?

She's not obligated to tell you them, but moreover, she probably don't know herself, because she can't speak so generally to something she does without thinking.

But that's on top of responding to a very real concern (being forced into a situation by someone with unknown intentions and not having an easy out) with this shit:

>Noted. I will ensure there is a clearly marked exit somewhere.

&#x200B;

Then there's all the other areas where you're responding as literally as possible to things (like the dog/cat comparison). I genuinely can't tell whether you're ridiculously dense, are trying to crack wise but don't know how to do it, or are being passive-aggressive in an attempt to save face. I get the frustration you're clearly facing, but you're going about things the wrong way by using uniquely male hardships to dismiss uniquely female ones. The risks that women face in random interactions are much higher. Like, I'm assuming you did read the other thread. Do you realistically think that men are ever going to face things like being pulled by the hair into another room? Those are the kinds of things women have to worry about. While you'd kill for a way to know whether your approach will be well-received, most women would settle for knowing whether the perfect stranger before them is socially and mentally well-adjusted.

text:
Sometimes people don't respond promptly because they genuinely care about giving thorough responses and that means they want to take their time with answering, either because the topic is something important or if saying the wrong thing could have severe consequences.

Your issue sounds like you are having problems with scheduling and people failing to commit to plans you're trying to make with them, I think you probably are making plans that are too immediate, plan things a week in advance rather than 1 day. People have busy and chaotic lives and when you make plans with them they might genuinely want to do something with you but they realize that they have an appointment that day.

Lastly, the problem of being ghosted and having people drift from you is probably influenced by the way you've chosen to react to and perceive their actions. You need to be able to empathize with the fact that there is probably a reason they weren't able to hang out and you've probably encountered the same situation they were in during your life. So try to be compassionate and understanding that they were unable to hang out, by doing so you will make them want to make it up to you rather than feeling like you're criticizing them for having their own lives.

I hope this helps
