text:
Fucking hell. I am not a lawyer I am not a therapist I am just a dude on the internet so proceed with that in mind.

In many states in the US, a 19 year old having sex with a 16 year old is illegal and he could do serious time and face serious legal consequences for the rest of his life. If the photos are of you when you were under 18, he is in possession of child pornography.

It was NOT your fault for sleeping with him, however many times you did it or in whatever context. It is considered rape that he and his friends had sex with you while you were black out drunk EVEN if you consented beforehand as you were not in a state to be able to revoke consent during the act. If I was sleeping with a girl and she wanted me to stop and I continued, that is rape.

But legal steps are difficult to take for many reasons. So I will from here on offer personal advice rather than legal.

This man took advantage of you. He called you names and manipulated you. In a healthy relationship, these things do NOT happen. You are RIGHT to consider him a rapist, waste of space, asshole, arrogant, etc. He is NOT "always nice" to you. He is manipulating you with PHOTOS and with FAKE KINDNESS to try to keep you hooked in. He is doing this because so far he has been successful. 

What you need to first do is forgive yourself. Forgive yourself for ever meeting him, for partying with him, for having sex with him that one time, and for having sex with him all the times after. Your past actions do not reflect the person that you are and do not control your present nor your future.

With regards to the photos, like I said, they can be considered child pornography if you were not of legal age. Beyond that, he is just using them as a scare tactic. Something to keep you roped in. You need to think about this logically. If he realized you were no longer in fear of the photos getting out, would he still feel so powerful and in control? No.

Think to yourself. EVEN IF the photos were to get out, does that control your life? Would your parents, friends, and family abandon you over these photos? And if they were to, would the lack of support they ever had for you even make it worth caring over? If they are the kind of people that would turn on you over these photos, they do not deserve to be in your life. And that's IF he ever had the balls to do anything with the photos.

If you have a good relationship with your parents, talk to them. Tell them you made a mistake when you were younger and that he has photos of you. Your parents should be understanding. It might be hard for them but if they love you they will be a source of support not criticism. Even if NONE of your family/friends turn out to be the caring people you needed, you still have yourself. Realize that NO MATTER what ANYONE on this green Earth thinks of you, photos or not, that you still will go on living.

Next time he threatens you, tell him to fuck off and tell him you don't give a fuck WHO sees the photos. Say it and mean it. Realize that the photos, if they ever get out, can change your life in ways you may not want, but if you let this man keep doing this, he will FOREVER control your life. Free yourself. Shed yourself of your past and move on to a better future.

When you confront him, he WILL try every tactic in the book to rope you back in. He will try to remind you all the things he did for you, everything he has against you, he will call you names and all sorts of things, he will remind you of all the things YOU did and what a shitty person YOU are. When he does these things, realize that is is just a desperate cry for help from a pitiful man losing power over another human. Even if he brings up things YOU may have done, so that it's not "all his fault", REALIZE and ACCEPT that EVEN IF you did things too, it DOES NOT mean they make you who you are. You are going to move on from this situation even if it means moving on from mistakes you made. Even if it was you who kept coming back to him or WHATEVER the fuck, it DOES NOT MATTER. You are DONE with him and NOTHING, not PHOTOS, not THREATS, not BLAME will bring you back. Block his number, every number he tries to use to contact you, all his emails and fake emails, EVERYTHING. Begin your life anew.

I don't care what happened in your past, what mistakes you made, who you made them with, or if you kept making the mistakes. I don't even care if it is partially or even fully your fault that all this happened or is happening, as I'm sure he will try to convince you. And he will. You deserve a life full of kindness, happiness, and love. You deserve a life that is fully yours and in your own hands and control. Another human being, especially one so despicable, does NOT get to control you and manipulate you, no matter how much you are to share the blame for the situation. Yes, you and him had sex while you were drunk. Yes, you chose to continue hooking up with him. None of that matters and none of that can be used to hold you back from escaping from this hell. Because it is also your choice to continue living a fulfilling life despite of it. Is is your CHOICE to cut him off and never go back. It is your CHOICE to be happy.

You have been through hell and I can't imagine all the ways this has taken a toll on your daily life. Please, for your own sake, regain control of your life. Choose to be happy, choose to be in control, and choose to move on completely and fully.

1-800-273-8255 is the Suicide Prevention Hotline if you ever feel like you need to talk to somebody

I understand you want answers, but you are not entitled to having her answer your questions about her decisions. Her refusing to answer further is a clear signal that her decision is not up for debate. 

In fact she has answered pretty clearly that she does not see you as relationship material for her. It does not matter why not. You should not change yourself to be with her anyway. She does not have to justify her relationship preferences and decisions to you or anyone either. 

Imagine the tables were turned. Think about how comfortable you would feel going into the reasons why you don't want to be in a relationship with a girl you like but don't click with. It is just not cool and definitely not going to change your mind if she were to keep pushing for clearer explanations why you don't want to be in a relationship with her. You might be more mature in how you handle things than you believe your ex has been, but you still would not appreciate her refusing to accept your decision and trying to get more justifications. 

Usually girls that can't take respect boundaries after a short relationship followed by a break-up get labeled "psychos", and guys like that usually get labeled "creeps" or worse. That is not a road you should let yourself go down.

If they do contact you again after you cut them off, look deeper. Is there anything they want from you? Favors? Prestige? Attention? If they were bad enough to warrant cutting off, then you need to be sure about responding. Personally, I believe in second chances. stance_justification: The writer acknowledges multiple valid approaches to leadership ('both sprezzatura AND anti-sprezzatura are valid paths') but provides reasoned evaluation of when each might be appropriate based on context ('depends on the make up of his subordinates'). They engage substantively with different leadership styles while maintaining that effectiveness depends on situational factors rather than treating all approaches as equally valid in all contexts.
stance_markers: ["both sprezzatura AND anti-sprezzatura are valid paths", "depends on the make up of his subordinates", "Whether he takes a taskmaster or paternal approach depends on", "I'd say that there's no optimal build", "How flexible are you willing to be"]
text:
Ah, but sprezzatura was instrumental to a courtier's professional career in support of his liege, and the same applies to business environments!

Sprezzatura also means hiding the ugly work. It doesn't mean being lazy or careless, but the illusion of doing so. Those 15 hours you spent perfecting that agreement? You say that it took 2 nights and a bottle of Captain Morgan. That money you spent to make a wise home improvement? "Ehhh, it's only a couple hundred Chipotle burritos." Both statements are true when you do the math, but the presentation makes them look like not big deal. That's part of the magic.

Rest assured, both sprezzatura AND anti-sprezzatura are valid paths to being a good leader. In fact, I'd say that there's no optimal build for a good leader. A good leader inspires his followers to excellence, or else he's just a super-employee. Whether he takes a taskmaster or paternal approach depends on the make up of his subordinates. A good leader is only one man; it is his people that give him that title. 

Do you think you could inspire your peers with your ways? How flexible are you willing to be in pursuit of that title?

stance_justification: The writer provides reasoned analysis of why large group conversations feel unsatisfying ('you can't talk about things most people haven't heard about'), offers specific strategies based on their reasoning, and explicitly weighs different approaches without claiming there's one right answer. They acknowledge uncertainty ('I don't know what you should do') while still providing substantive guidance.
stance_markers: ["I think part of the reason", "I don't know what you should do", "I guess you either need to", "That said, I don't think you should necessarily", "there's no real reason you should force yourself"]
text:
I think part of the reason you feel this way is that when people are in a larger group and they want to have a conversation in which everyone is included, that means you can't talk about things most people haven't heard about or are interested in. So you get casual conversations about what have you.

I don't know what you should do about this. I have sort of the same problem, and as a result I far prefer talking to people one-on-one or at least in smaller groups, because then you can actually have interesting conversations and, say, learn something new from them rather than just listen to general information which is semi-known and semi-interesting to everyone. 

If you really want to join in larger conversations, then I guess you either need to get with the program and add literally whatever pops into your mind. Is the weather being discussed? Someone thinks it's really cold outside today? Agree and point out that the forecast calls for equally cold weather all weekend. Is a TV show being discussed? If you've heard of it, oh wow I really like that, my favorite episode is so and so/that last episode was really great/when does it start again? If not, I've never heard of that, is it any good? Just ask a question or say whatever you think about the topic at hand.

That said, I don't think you should necessarily feel like not joining these conversations is a problem of yours. Being quiet in larger groups is completely ok, people are all different, and there's no real reason you should force yourself to discuss something you don't care about.

So then it just comes down to how much you care about the opinions of others. Are you thinking about disagreeing out loud because *you* want to, or because you're too worried about how you seem to others? 

If you do care a lot about others opinions it's up to you to put in the effort to vocalise your thoughts and views - it's not really a waste if you're getting what you want out of it right (making sure people understand your viewpoint). And at that point it's not about you changing minds. Or have a conversation/debate around this topic another time just specifically with the people you care about. 

If you don't care what these people think, and believe that they might agree with the person ranting... Why do you care about making a certain impression? Just move on with your life.

I think there are personality traits which are viewed as positive, negative or neutral by the society. Popular people have more of the positive ones and unpopular more of the negative ones (of course money, good looks and some other things play a big role in popularity as well).

 You can't be rude, loud, mean, "weird" and expect people to like you...but lets take the trait "rude" you might be seen as  rude by some people but not so much by other people.
 Or the trait "mean". Some people might think you are mean and others could think that you are not, you just don't take shit from anyone. 
Most of the time it's subjective,  but there are cases when a lot people will agree about the negative traits you have and you if you realize,  that everyone tells you that you are very rude then that might be true and you should work on that, but a lot times you just don't klick with the people around you. 
Just be Yourself is said to prevent you from acting like someone you are not. Instead of changing yourself first, try to find people who klick with you, because pretending to be someone you are clearly not, will not make you happy in the long term. A lot people tried to that and most of time it did not end good for them. 

Some people naturally have personality traits that makes them more popular with others and thus gives them easier time to find friends. However, that does not mean anything, more does not necessary mean better. You have to go out more(after corona...or when the corona cases are much lower)or try to find internet friends. Just don't expect people to knock on your door and start liking you.

stance_markers: ["Sounds like a little narcissism", "that's probably my narcissism speaking!", "Your self perception might be more of the issue", "you may have to take responsibility", "Neither of you are wrong, but you use different definitions", "It's up to you!"]
text:
Sounds like a little narcissism.  That's not exactly a high enough IQ to warrant any, but then again, that's probably my narcissism speaking!  Believe it or not, people with narcissistic tendencies often have a pretty rocky self-concept and have to construct ways to inflate it.  Your self perception might be more of the issue than intelligence itself.  Social problems are stressful and sometimes painful.  Blaming yourself is even more painful, so a difference in intelligence is a great way to put the blame on other people.  Still, you may have to take responsibility for your contribution to the problem.  I take this post as a sign that you are ready to do that.

Many "intelligent people" (people with a high IQ, as defined by you) do not have interpersonal problems because there's more to it than that.  Watch a season of Survivor and you will see that many people with high IQ's will struggle to get ahead because they overlooked the value of emotional intelligence, which is the key to success in Survivor.  Life isn't much different.  We're stuck on earth with other people, and understanding ourselves and others is how we survive.  Remember, your definition of intelligence is related to the way you think, and the positive attributes you have.  A bubbly senser-feeler-type may find you to be unintelligent if you are stuck in your head all the time and don't have people skills.  Neither of you are wrong, but you use different definitions. 

On a side note, being in therapy is a great place to unpack all these problems.  Therapists know that narcissistic people can be very sensitive to criticism, and a good one will not put the blame on you, as it could cause you to drop them entirely.  However, if you decide for yourself that there's some room for improvement, they will support you and help you move forward.  It's up to you!

Everyone is different bruh. Maybe she didn't like the question. Maybe she didn't like the question coming from the new person. Maybe she was busy. Maybe she had other things on her mind and didn't want to make small talk about her dog at that time. 

What if you thought the question was nice but for whatever reason she thought it wasn't nice? I mean who knows, that could be the case. And if it were the case you ought to respect that, and if you don't respect it then you aren't being nice anyway. Asking what you consider to be a nice question and then expecting a nice reply could definitely be considered a rude and entitled attitude. And I mean it sounds like you're now doubling down on that by ignoring her now. 

So yeah my advice would be to be nice. But by nice I mean be open minded and flexible. Try not to get twisted up over small slights. How you feel is largely on you, and how you react is absolutely 100% on you. People aren't like vending machines where you put in a nice question and get out a nice response or something. Sometimes they have bad days or whatever

But maybe that won't be fulfilling to you, and there's nothing wrong with that", "Only you can find solutions", "Write it out if that helps you process things. It helps me"]
text:
You used the word "better" several times. For the most part, when applying this term to humans, it becomes subjective, especially when dealing with creative tasks. Comparing yourself to others obsessively often leads to depression and low self-esteem. You're comparing the best qualities of a GROUP of people to your own, which is simply setting an unrealistic and unreasonable standard for yourself, and when you don't meet those impossible standards, of course you're going to repeatedly feel like a failure. 

Sure, I wish I could throw a football like Peyton Manning, play the piano like Beethoven, deliver a speech like president Obama, be able to fix things like my brother-in-law, be as handsome as my cousin, have great business knowledge like my dad. They're all better than me at those things. But, you know what? They can't do what I can. They don't posses the collection of skills and personality traits that led to my personal success, however I might define that. 

You feel shallow? Find a way to deepen yourself. Be introspective. Be brutally honest with yourself, especially when it hurts. Most of us lie to ourselves every day so our ego isn't bruised. Only you know your deepest thoughts and desires. Feelings of emptiness? Look inside yourself to find what fulfills you. Again, use brutal honesty. You might think it's noble to help out the needy and lie to yourself saying, "this is what will fulfill me". You might do this because society puts that type of person on a pedestal, and you want to be viewed by others as a good person. But maybe that won't be fulfilling to you, and there's nothing wrong with that. 

Only you can find solutions to fix these feelings. Sure, therapy might help, but it boils down to you. Write it out if that helps you process things. It helps me. The key is realistic, brutal honesty.

text:
Finding the right people, but that takes practice. Over time you'll learn to know who is willing to invest their time into knowing you and vice versa. It's difficult to find a friend that genuinely cares about you and is willing to prioritize you as well. 

But it all starts off from being yourself, not trying overly hard to fit in and eventually you will find people gravitating towards you - and you towards them. I think it also goes down by finding similar interests although I have a few friends that are polar opposites to me, but knowing who wants to make an effort to be your friend is a start. Because you don't want to invest a lot of time in a lot of people - you want to narrow that down.

Don't feel obligated to keep people who are negative, toxic or want to bring you down. Ain't nobody got time for that. But make sure you know your self worth, and that you treat others well and hope that they do too. Friendships will never be equal, but you want it to be as closely balanced as possible.  


I'm rambling, but I hope that makes sense haha.

text:
General points already made that are good: speak more plainly because your words sound like a scalpel next to everyone else's butterknife, accept compliments and move on, don't feel ashamed of your gift, don't lie, and probably stop self-depreciating so much.

A couple points are worth noting. People, myself included, unintentionally take things they see and hear and alter it based on their own personalities. Sometimes self-depreciating humor gets a chuckle, sometimes it leaves a person feeling insulted. This isn't news to you, but you should try to get a feel for how people's perspectives can be categorized by the way they react to different things you say and do. No one can tell you how to mesh with others because no one else is you. 

When it comes to conversation in general, it sounds like everything in a 'get to know you' type conversation comes back to intelligence. My guess? Your intellect is like a giant statue standing behind you. You used to boast to everyone about the giant statue, forcing them to compare themselves to you. Now, you've thrown a giant white sheet over the statue that towers over you. Naturally, conversation drifts back towards the giant covered statue. You try to cover it up and insist that you don't talk about it or insist to others that it isn't so large, but, no matter what, it feels like conversation will always be drawn to the giant statue that is your academic success. Practice leading conversation in a walk away from the statue. 

When you focus on keeping the conversation away from it, it's like checking to make sure the sheet is fully covering it. That won't keep conversation off of what's underneath for long. 

Your personality is a garden, walk away from the statue. If a younger schoolmate starts talking about their intelligence, listen, ask questions, etc., don't try to avoid theirs or you'll end up at yours. If a direct question is asked about yours, just say you've talked about school enough lately and you don't want to think about it. Maybe ask them to help keep your mind off of it for a while, people like to feel helpful. 

To do this effectively, you'll have to develop a genuine interest in talking about other stuff, instead of thinking about other stuff as a way to avoid your intelligence. 

Positive (towards) focus AND negative (away) focus, will always lead back towards where the focus lies, whether you want it to or not. The best way out is to shift the center of focus elsewhere. The easiest place to start is the other person. With practice, you'll be able to talk to others about yourself while keeping the giant statue out of sight until you're ready to talk about it. Sorry for novel, I really help something in here is at least the slightest bit useful.

stance_markers: ["90% of the time", "from experience, I've learnt", "from my similar experiences", "I just think", "It was still rude from my perspective, yes", "Most people just don't give a shit like we do", "I'm not just being positive for the sake of it"]
text:
Well, most people don't initiate conversations because they either find text conversations tedious or they don't have the energy for socialising after a long day etc. You are the centre of your universe, he is the centre of his universe. He doesn't think about you much, or about anyone else for that matter. But that doesn't mean he *dislikes* you, see? It's not personal. 

I'm also very emotionally sensitive and used to worry about these things too, but from experience, I've learnt that 90% of the time (when looking back in hindsight) that I had read between the lines too much and saw things that weren't there. Honest to god, it isn't personal. For instance, my best friend ignored me for 2 months - but it just turned out he was busy. It was still rude from my perspective, yes, but most people just aren't a [highly sensitive person](http://hsperson.com/) - they just let things slide without thinking about it. But he got back in touch and our bond is still as great as it ever was. Most people just don't give a shit like we do - which is why ***it's up to you*** to take the initiative. But stay true to yourself, and be your amazing self that genuinely cares about others :) It's much more rewarding in the long term :)

The only way you can *really* know is if you ask him out in person and 1) see how he responds 2) and if he says yes, then see how he acts with you in real life. I'm not just being positive for the sake of it, I just think (from my similar experiences) that you're too quick to jump to negative conclusions.

Please. Realise this. It will change your life. Promise :)

My husband is exactly like this and has told me his mind is usually blank. He only speaks when he has something to say and he doesn't enjoy small talk because of this. I think that it's okay to be like this and to accept that you aren't as social as the next person. Everyone is different. 
People constantly ask me if he ever talks, or if he hates them. Sometimes they make fun. But little do they know how intelligent and funny he is and how well he tells stories when it's just us or a few select people in our lives. And those of us he can hold a conversation with feel pretty special. 
You don't have to try to be someone you're not. There are people out there that will still be friends with you or want to hang out with you even if you're a quiet person. When I first met him, I was so intrigued because most people never stop talking. He was mysterious and it was fun getting to know him. I'm still getting to know him. I absolutely adore him. 
But that‚Äôs just us. If it makes you unhappy or affects your day-to-day life, there are many resources out there to work on social skills. Such as a life coach/confidence coach. 

Best of luck to you.

text:
I can certainly relate to being socially awkward around past supervisors at work (and most other people as well actually). That worked in my favor for one aspect of the job. I didn‚Äôt waste much time talking to people, I just worked instead. 

I went to a psychiatrist when I was younger to get help with my anxiety. He basically gave me two suggestions (after about 10 sessions and $3,000 later haha). 

1. Desensitize yourself to what you‚Äôre afraid of by little by little doing more of it. So go talk to people more, in different social settings or whatever you think will help. My brother was similar to me in this regard and went to Toastmasters, an organization that forced him to talk, mingle with professional people and even give toasts/speeches. It seemed to help him.

2. The psychiatrist thought my overall diet/health was not great for my overall emotional state. He encouraged me to eat a more balanced diet, including fresh fruits and vegetables. I didn‚Äôt think much of this for a while honestly. But once I actually tried to eat better I felt better (and wasn‚Äôt so nervous/ anxious when talking to people).

So just believe in yourself. I know, it is easy to say and think but harder to do. Bosses (of which I am now one to about 8 or so) want people who are working for them to get stuff done. Because it makes our jobs so much easier. 

I hope this helps. 

You can do this! Good luck!

I think this urge may have something to do with the ‚Äúvulnerability hangover‚Äù people experience when they open up to others. 

Many people don‚Äôt know how to react or to be validating of anther person‚Äôs struggles. I want to ask you if you have noticed the way you react when someone opens up to you in such a way? Are there any similarities?

We are all empaths, and for some of us it‚Äôs really hard to allow ourselves to feel with another person if ‚Äúnegative‚Äù emotions are involved. Some people are really invalidating by trying to get you to see the bright side or whatever. Others are so numb to their own pain, they may have no idea how to open up to the pain of others (hence the awkward silence that often follows an admission). 

And yes, I think it‚Äôs common for many of us to want to cut ties with people we‚Äôve shared personal stories and struggles with. I also think these people deserve another chance, and maybe some honesty, such as asking them how they felt or what they thought about what you told them, and letting them know how you felt in response to their reaction or lack thereof.

text:
Hello. 

As a side note it's fun being the first commenter on posts like this because I feel the first few posts are usually probably the most impactful.

I have somewhat of the same problem where it feels awkward to sit down with a group of people I may not know well. Double awkward because I only speak English and living in Germany right now :D

For me 1 on 1 conversations are much easier because I don't feel rude for expecting them to speak English to me. But in a group Germans fall back into speaking Deutsch and so I can lose the thread of the conversation and feel excluded.

I also do the same thing you do. Casing the joint. Walking in seeing who's talking to who, who's sitting where and If I feel comfortable entering into any of those conversations / situations.

From what I can tell you're looking for a way to extend your conversations and probably onto more meaningful topics. For me the best way I've found to keep conversations alive is through asking questions. The only thing you need to keep in mind is to adjust your questions to the current topic and make them specific. 

I don't know you well, Really I know nothing about you more than this post. But even from this an entire conversation can be spawned if I pick out details about what you have said and ask you to elaborate or explain what you mean. It increases my understanding of what you were trying to explain and it extends the conversation longer so that new questions can be formed.

I find as you ask more questions and find out about the person they will start to share information you don't ask for. Sometimes the new information is interesting but a complete tangent to the conversation your having and it is your choice to comment on what they said or let it go by.

It is important to remember a few things about the question mode. try to avoid simple questions that only require yes / no answers. Try to gauge how interested the person is in the subjects you are talking about. I.e they are very animated and lively explaining something to you compared with distracted and quiet. People enjoy talking about themselves, they enjoy it even more when someone is interested in who they are but quite rightly people aren't willing to share everything about themselves so learning to read when someone is uncomfortable talking about something will steer the conversations away from an untimely demise.

About awkward silences. This is a belief. It is an idea that not talking is awkward. Silence is a natural occurrence in a conversation and should be thought of as a good thing. It happens when one party is listening the other is talking and the talker finishes and the listener doesn't respond. Why they don't respond could be any number of reasons. From them still considering what you said, to them not listening and being unable to enter back into the conversation. If they're your friend it's probably not the latter so just take the moment of silence to look around, consider what you said or they said and then when you feel the natural occurrence of wanting to speak then carry on. Feeling awkward about silences means you try to remove them which means you will never learn to be comfortable with silences.

Take home points. Ask questions. Get specific. Be interested. Listen. Learn to think of silences as positive not negative. Put yourself out there, You can't meet people with meeting new people. When in a conversation remember family, friends, occupation, goals / dreams all easy topics to start to learn about them and get a fuller picture of the person who you're talking to.

Hope this helps.

text:
You fucked up sleeping with you ex. Telling person B wasn't the fuck up, but really you should have expected her response. I mean think about it: if she came up to you and told you she's been shagging her ex while you are trying to be with her, you would not be happy about it. 

I think you are gonna just have to grow up and realise your actions have consequences. You might well have lost your chance with person B now, and there's very little you can do to change that; it's all dependent on how she feels. 

Also, you have to be honest with yourself first and foremost: why did you sleep with your ex if you are looking to be with person B? Once you know the answer to that, you should probably talk it through with person B, be as honest as you can, and just hope that she will still want to have anything to do with you. 

Good luck trying to resolve this; lying is never the best way to go.

text:
While much easier said than done, it is important to not compare yourself to others and ask questions when you need to. Instead of receding back into your head and jumping into flight mode, think of those social situations as a challenge, and a growing experience. Asking questions is the an excellent way to build a relationship with someone, and when approached with a smile, people can be very receptive. As someone who myself struggled in these situations, never being able to find solutions to my problems because I was too intimidated to ask, pushing yourself to reach out can be one of the best decision you ever make. Just ask me (ha ha)

In a friendship respect, you do not need to trust anyone right off the bat. Just because you don't trust someone, does not mean you can't have a relationship with them though. Trust needs to begin somewhere.

Everything begins with you, once you start to put in the effort to open up, the world may open up to you.

Same boat, except it is the people I work with, not friends. I have heard for the last week about me walking around with my hands in my pockets. They don't understand there is a reason I do that. Because I know what they don't know, I just chuckle or make a joke about it and move on. They see it as me laughing with them when I am laughing at what they don't know. This approach may help you deal with your situation. Accept that they are not you and may not understand why you do what you do. You can laugh at this or you can take the time to explain it to them, which may backfire and result in more of the same. 

Ultimately, all you can do is be the best you. If they think that is a joke, you have to decide if you want to stay in that type of toxic setting or move on to something better?

text:
Just because all she wants is your help with math problems and nothing more doesn't mean that she is using you. It means that's all she wants from you right now. It is your choice if you want to keep helping her or stop. If you feel used, maybe let her know. Just because you expect more from someone and they aren't fulfilling your expectations then that doesn't mean they are a bad person.

But if you feel strongly that she is just using you and you don't want to help her out then just confront and say it to her that you don't feel comfortable talking to her or helping her. Since you are expected to respect her boundaries then she should respect yours as well. Hope that helps. 

Also, don't stress about what other people in the classroom thinks about it. It's not important now nor in the long run.

text:
Use the 3-second rule. 

This is mainly helpful for when you just want to be able to approach when you don't want your thoughts overiding your decision to go and stop yourself. 

This technique allows you to not think about about what you are doing, and by the time you get to back out, you have already approached them. 

This is a really easy technique here's how to do it. 

1. Find your target of who you want to talk to. 
2. Within 3 seconds of seeing them, start walking to them. 
3. Use all your will power to not stop walking and walk away. Just do it. 
4. Realize that its not as bad as you think after you do it. 
5. Practice the 3-second rule as often as you can. 

Best of luck

text:
Dude you‚Äôre doing it right. I was nothing, nobody, most boring person in the world at your age. I worked my ass off and instead of partying it up and having adventures of idiocy in my 20s I get to do it in style middle aged. Who really has a better time? The idiot at 22 years old who gets black out drunk in the Netherlands, loses his passport, and has to call his mom cause he‚Äôs broke, or the guy who‚Äôs older, more responsible, doesn‚Äôt black out and do stupid shit, and has a lavish time with his wife cause he‚Äôs got money in the bank from making sound decisions his whole life? You‚Äôre not missing anything dude.

And as far as girls go, two things:

First, you‚Äôre gonna have to keep meeting and talking to people. This will happen on its own through school and work. You have no choice but to be who you are. Be anyone else, and people will see right through that shit, so just be who you are. Most people won‚Äôt like you, but that‚Äôs fine. It may not seem like it, but I swear to god nobody really likes anybody. However, some people WILL like you as long as they have the chance to see you and meet you. It‚Äôs probability man. Sooner or later you MUST meet someone who will dig you. It‚Äôs just math man. Tons of people hate me. Tons of people can‚Äôt stand me. Didn‚Äôt stop me from eventually marrying someone. If I can do it anyone can.

Second, you WILL be rejected. Everyone is. Again it‚Äôs just math. Even if people say crappy things to you, the worst thing you can do is take rejection personally. There is no such thing as ‚Äúunlovable‚Äù or people being put together ‚Äúright‚Äù or ‚Äúwrong‚Äù. That‚Äôs all aesthetic bullshit invented in people‚Äôs minds. Turns out the world keeps turning whether you‚Äôre cool, or lame, or a supermodel, or a loser, or a serial killer, or a prom king, or whatever else. There‚Äôs gonna be lots of people who don‚Äôt like you. It‚Äôs normal. For everyone. Trust me on this. People don‚Äôt make meaningful real connections very easily at all. A lot of conditions have to be right for that, and that‚Äôs tough because everyone is different. Some people seem on the outside like everyone loves them and their life is perfect. It‚Äôs bullshit. Going on a spring break in Cancun and getting impregnated by some dude you don‚Äôt even know cause ‚Äúomg he was so haaawwwwttt‚Äù is not a meaningful connection. It‚Äôs just retarded. The only thing that you‚Äôre different about is a lack of meaningless false connections. Most people don‚Äôt have real friends. I have 1, and honestly even he‚Äôs questionable.

When you finish school in a lot of ways the real world will probably be kinder to you. People‚Äôs priorities really change once they have to survive everyday and the world is kicking the shit out of them on a daily basis. You will find someone and your studies will allow you to have a much better shot at a good life than most people. If you‚Äôre really that serious about suicide, at least do this first: wait until you‚Äôve been out in the real world away from school for 5-6 years. You haven‚Äôt experienced the real world yet. You have no way to imagine what life is really about yet. Ending it before it starts means that statistically you will probably be throwing away your best years, even if you had experienced all these overrated experiences you want.

stance_justification: The writer presents their experience as one perspective among many ('I'm sure everyone is different'), acknowledges the limitations of generalizing from personal experience, and provides specific reasoning for their claims about stuttering causes and solutions. They demonstrate reflective self-analysis about their own patterns while explicitly recognizing that others may have different experiences.
stance_markers: ["I found it was", "for some reason", "As I got older", "I'm sure everyone is different", "but that is what worked for me"]
text:
I had a mild stuttering issue growing up.  I found it was in situations where I felt I would have to fight to get "the floor".  Things like being in a group of people or talking to someone that interrupts a lot.  

I would get a bit anxious and rush what I was saying and stutter for some reason. 

As I got older and gained more confidence, I didn't rush myself when I talked, and if I didn't get the floor or was interrupted, I just went with the flow.

I'll occasionally stutter now (almost always in similar circumstances) but I stop, take a deep breath, and talk slower.

I'm sure everyone is different but that is what worked for me.

stance_justification: The writer treats humor development as entirely subjective ('It's such a subjective thing') and refuses to provide evaluative guidance beyond 'indulge yourself in the sort of stuff that amuses you.' They present multiple types of humor without weighing their relative merits or effectiveness, and their advice essentially defers all judgment to personal preference without offering criteria for evaluation.
stance_markers: ["it depends on your own sense of humor", "It's such a subjective thing", "indulge yourself in the sort of stuff that amuses you", "let your own personal sense of humor develop", "figure out what works for you", "you obviously don't have to stick to one type"]
text:
Honestly, it depends on your own sense of humor. What's the sort of stuff you find funny? Dry humor, absurd humor, observational humor, offensive humor, slapstick/physical humor? (And whichever other varieties there are.) It's such a subjective thing - all I'll say is basically indulge yourself in the sort of stuff that amuses you, and let your own personal sense of humor develop from there. Not saying to steal jokes, per se, just figure out what works for you (you obviously don't have to stick to one type of humor, either).

From there, I think you can learn to pick out sources of humor in the various things around you, it just may take time. Just don't think you have to be funny on demand, like that "Oh, you're a clownfish?! Hey, tell a joke!" stuff from Finding Nemo - you're not a performing seal. Or a clownfish (as far as I know).

text:
Lately, I‚Äôve been thinking about that too. I think it‚Äôs part of a social, cultural and economic mindset that inserted in our minds the idea of a single and unique love forever. Just like the movies. ‚ÄúShe is the one‚Äù. ‚ÄúHe is the one‚Äù. But once you think about It, sounds weird. I mean, really? One single love forever? We are humans, we are animals and obviously we are going to be attracted to someone else. 

I‚Äôve been reading about it and all these ideas are related to the concept of romantic love; where, for example, marriage is the final step. Marriage and have kids. If that doesn‚Äôt happen, then the relationship didn‚Äôt work. So, every relationship is doomed until you find the girl you decide to marry? It is really frustrating to think about that. 


I realized there are different types of relationships, like open relationships with different names haha and I am on that stage right now, but it‚Äôs been really difficult for me to start something like that, bc the mindset we all have is like a force of gravity that doesn‚Äôt allows us to do something else. 

I also realized that if I decide to start a relationship, I will enjoy every second and moment with the person I decide to spend time with. If at some point I start to suffer the relationship, I will end it, because my goal is enjoy the process. So I can say that to you, yes, every relationship is doomed to end (also bc we die) but it‚Äôs up to you to decide what would you like to live in the present day. Who is the person you would like to spend the present day with? If you are not enjoying the present day, then finish it. And yes, there are people that will have 1 gf or bf for their whole lives, and it‚Äôs ok. It‚Äôs ok if they are enjoying it. But if you look closer, the number of infidelities is so high that I wonder if the mindset we have chosen is congruent with our feelings. I don‚Äôt know...

text:
Well, online dating is pretty tough in that aspect because we are talking to strangers that is pretty much outside of our social circle. So, naturally, initial interactions would usually be dry because its the get to know phase. 

Also, it takes both parties to make it work, as in if either one of you are not into it, then, its gonna be awkward. This somewhat depends on luck and strategy to spark interesting interactions. It is true that if you guys dont vibe, you guys just dont.

There's also the case that some people are just like that. That is, they are dry texters. You could try asking if they'd like for a voice call instead.

On the other hand, some people can also be quite shallow, in which they may seem uninteresting to talk to if youre looking for deep conversations. But, this also means that they're interesting in a different manner which you would only know when you get to know them. 

Just my two cents but hope that helps!

How you approach it depends on you and how comfortable you feel, and I get I kind of gave a non answer to the whole "how do you start a convo", and instead said "try to meet the right people." But I'm just speaking from experience of someone who's been really socially awkward and anxious and the approaches that I found successful and comfortable.

Whether you take my advice or not, I wish you luck!

I used to feel this way when I was about your age too. I'm now 23 and looking back on it because I was afraid they may have been mocking me I missed out on alot of opportunities with alot of girls. one of the best pieces of advice I've ever heard which has helped me tremendously is to always assume attraction. Assume that they are coming up to you because you are attractive and approach the situation with confidence from that stand point. You'll be much calmer, feel more powerful and in control and easily handle the situation. whats the worst that can happen? they are teasing you and then you find out? you've lost nothing, they are mean people who you wouldn't want to associate with anyway so you can thank them for showing you that upfront rather than wasting your time and you finding that out down the road.

bottom line, always assume attraction and handle situations with confidence, youve got nothing to lose my friend!(or should i say mate?)

Try to identify exactly why you feel awkward initially.  Are you intimidated, do you fear that they wont like who you are?  Identify why you feel that way and evaluate that reason:

Do you really think they will dislike you because you made one bad joke?  Would you dislike them for making one bad joke?  

Do you think they dislike you because they aren't opening up to you?  Maybe they are just as intimidated as you are, and are afraid to be the one to make the first move.

Challenging your own beliefs is the best way to overcoming your anxiety.

text: I have hard time having my sister open up to me also. If I ask her directly to address an issue, she'll respond with a one-line also (she's in bad mood and probably sees that I'm just an older brother just reacting to her bad mood). I believe having her trust you would be to show that you will be with her and listen to her no matter what. She will choose the time to open up to you when the mood is right. See how her day is. I say listen a lot but I think we really don't take our listening skill to a deeper level. At this point I am just rambling, but if you need, have her interact online maybe. text:
hey!! former F21 worker here. don‚Äôt feel left out!! the age group mindset between 18-21 is very similar (22f here) than you realize. in my experience, the best advice i can give is try not force any conversation it only drives customers (in general, not just your age group) away because it makes them feel as if you‚Äôre selling something to them (which, i mean, i am, but subtly). it‚Äôs better to start small and let it build up if it wants to!! you can start by acknowledging them to store with a welcome and a smile - throw in a compliment if you‚Äôre up to it - then leave them alone for a good 5 minutes or so use your judgment. also let them know your name and you‚Äôre available for any questions even if they don‚Äôt have any.  the more you say this the more it becomes second nature and you can focus on furthering the other part of the conversation. this all lets them know you‚Äôre there without being too pushy so when you follow up with them to see if they‚Äôre okay, they will most likely open up to you about what they‚Äôre actually looking for rather than brush you off with a quick ‚Äòyes i‚Äôm fine thanks‚Äô then a minute later they really need help (this happens a lot). i used to be the same way as you until i got placed in the fitting room. when people are trying stuff on, give a compliment! could be about the clothes they selected, their personal style, ask about the special occasion if they have something fancy - mix it up!! you‚Äôll find most customers simply want to talk about themselves which makes it sooo much easier to let them drive the conversation instead. it also helps to know your product as well!! spend an extra 5-10 minutes before or after your shift to just walk around the store to see where everything is which makes you seem more confident and helps the customer too!!

also side note: you‚Äôre not gonna connect with everyone - in retail or in life - but it‚Äôs not a reflection of who you are or your worth. it could be something the customer is dealing with personally, especially the ones who seem unreasonably rude for no reason (doesn‚Äôt happen a lot but does pop up every now and then). if needed, breathe it out in your break room, distract yourself by helping to tidy up the store, whatever works for you, then go to the next customer in a few moments and try again :) sorry this was so long but hope it helps even just a little bit!! don‚Äôt give up!!

There are two types of people in this regard- you consider being late the preferable option to being early because being early means that there is time you could have used for the things you need to do that is ‚Äúwasted‚Äù essentially. Lots of people prefer to be late so they can maximize their own time. 

Other people prefer to be early because that is respectful of other peoples time- it shows them that you prioritize their time even over your own. Your friend sounds like in this group. 

Neither is wrong, but if you did show up earlier to things they would certainly recognize the social cue you might not have noticed you had been giving off.

text:
This used to happen to me a lot, and still does to a smaller extent. One strategy I've employed is to just not think about the social interaction for at least a few hours afterwards. The first few hours, or if dinks were involved then the next day, are the most sensitive times. Do other things to keep your mind off the event. That way your mind doesn't start self destructing and telling yourself that you did this, that and the other thing wrong.

Next, practice mental habits that remind you that you didn't actually do anything wrong. Remember some of the stupid things your friends and acquaintances have done. Do you really care about those things? Have they done anything besides bring you joy by being funny moments? No, of course not. No one actually cares about your gaffes.

 Next, whenever you happen to find yourself spiralling, try to interrupt the automatic negative thoughts. Ask yourself WHY you think you've messed up. When you figure out whatever you think you did wrong, work on making yourself believe that it's no big deal. It'll take time and won't work the first few times but you'll eventually get better at it. Good luck!

text:
Well, first of all, did someone actually straight up approach you and condemned or criticized you for that? Because I personally wouldn't mind or even care if I was hanging with you and you were to pull 'that' off. And I would definitely not bother evaluating it as an observer and recipient. Purely because it's not really a big deal. It's not even a deal of any kind. People often times, especially us milennials, talk about such meaningless shit, that it never ceazes to amaze me, that actually 'those' people usually find themselves within a huge circle. Do you know why? It's the small talk and 'those' guys constantly have a mouth full of it. Though it's not apparent at first, small talk is the number 1 easiest way to establish a foundation with pretty much any human being, so long as they allow you to by listening. And it doesn't have to be about anything important or relevant. It literally can and often is about meaningless shit.
So, in answer to your dilemma: no. You're not weird. If anything, you stand out from the crowd by having those two unique traits that make you who you are.  Now, maybe if you were trying to attract a girl, that bit about you sharing too much personal information would be kinda perceived as a slight turn-off (not claiming it would for sure), but that's only because chicks prefer a guy with an air of mystery about them ;) Unless you're going for the friend-zone, then by all means! They love having emotional male friends around them. 
I speak from my experience, because in a way I too was somewhat similar to you. I thought that by being open about literally every aspect of my life, with a chick I liked, was gonna make her warm up to me and trust me and stuff like that. And it was working precisely like that, alright! But not in the right direction I wanted it to go, instead drifting off to.. where? Yes, friend-zone. So I did find myself wondering about it too. What the hell? My mum taught me to be a gentleman after all. So I was. Then, years later I found channel on Youtube called BasedZeus and everything started to come to me straight. I found the truth of the universe. Chicks love bad guys who don't give two shits about them and then ghost them, when girls try to reach them in text. And you'd be amazed, but it started to work for me like immediately, as soon as I applied those principals. I swear to God, ghosting a chick on Messenger or text is the biggest turn on for her. Because for all she knows, you have got such busy and amazing life that u didn't even have time to pick up the phone.
Nah, but seriously, you're okay, dude. Again if I was talking to you, I wouldn't even notice anything weird about this. And also, that bit about u being too open, I daresay if anything, it'll make people like you more. That's just my perspective though.

Also, sorry! I just assumed you're a dude, for the benefit of the story.

stance_markers: ["I know I'm right", "you're right in your head", "complete rubbish", "stupid opinions", "ignorantly happy", "I'm trying to have an intellectually stimulating arguement and try to use facts and logic", "you're not narrow-minded are are simply an intelligent guy"]
text:
I'm the EXACT same as you (except I usually refuse to admit we're both right). People say I'm relentless and narrow-minded even though I'm trying to have an intellectually stimulating arguement and try to use facts and logic. 

Personally, I think people who like to debate/argue are hard to like. People have a variety of beliefs about different things even if they're complete rubbish. But lots of people don't want to constantly be corrected on their stupid opinions, they'd rather keep them and be ignorantly happy. They are likely to go super-defensive and make up complete crap in order to protect their views and don't see these situations as an opportunity to exchange opinions or ideas.

On coming to that realisation, it became easier to avoid arguements because I stopped caring about trying to persuade the other person. My pride is in myself and I know I'm right, so it's fine. You have to trust in yourself that you're not narrow-minded are are simply an intelligent guy who likes to argue (it's not a bad thing). 

But then, if you want to maintain friendships with these people you have to decide. Either stop arguing so much and be happy knowing you're right in your head (you'll have to do things such as changing the subject or simply not voicing your conflicting opinions), or find better friends. Personally I find that with such people I just maintain a shallow relationship and make my close relationships with the people that actually know the rules of arguing and debating. 

If you're reliant on these friends, maybe keep them sweet until you get the opportunity to make friends with people that are more like you. 

My opinion, anyway. Dont know if its relevant :)

Either way it's your choice.

text:
You remind me of my past self. I rarely spoke, from preschool all the way to middle school. Allow me to write you a mini-self help book on all
the tips that helped me the most:
 
 For one, I have to be honest here my guy- you‚Äôre never going to gain friends from rarely speaking. I know more than anyone that it‚Äôs a hard habit to break, and it‚Äôs scary to put yourself out there. But, there‚Äôs a sea of potential friends out there, and the only reason you haven‚Äôt caught a few is simply because they haven‚Äôt found you yet. I used to be near-mute in school as a kid, until I began forcing myself to branch out. I practically binged self-help books, improved my appearance and fashion sense (not at all important if you‚Äôre fine with how you look, it just helped me gain more confidence in myself), and surprise surprise- as I began to utilize their advice, my friend count grew exponentially. School is just a practice ground for social development- when you start applying for jobs, most look for charisma, social skills, and confidence in your abilities. It‚Äôs better to learn now than to suffer later in life, even though it‚Äôs a hard change that takes time, along with mental and physical effort. Here‚Äôs a rough summary of the advice that helped me the most:

 Start with interesting small talk. Not just things like, ‚ÄúHey, did you do the math homework?‚Äù, more jokes and commentary on different things in class. People like to laugh, and when they associate you with laugher they‚Äôll want to approach you. Being witty is definitely a trait you‚Äôll have to work for if it doesn‚Äôt come naturally, but it pays off. 

 Another thing is to ask them about themselves. Most people absolutely love talking about themselves, either for vanity, or simply because they want to get something off their chest, or to express their inner thoughts and choices. Compliments go a long way- go for personal choices instead of physical attractiveness, though. If someone has dyed hair, I strike up a conversation with ‚ÄúWoah, your hair looks so cool! How did you get the color so vibrant?‚Äù. If someone‚Äôs wearing a graphic shirt from something I recognize, I go ‚ÄúYo, you like ____ too?‚Äù, which is an instant winner usually- it immediately gives you both something to talk about and something in common. These all open up ways for them to talk about themselves, and let you get to know them better. You‚Äôll make the person feel nice, and they‚Äôll associate you with that positive feeling. And when the relationship develops further, you can begin to share things about yourself too (only if you‚Äôre comfortable with it though). 

 Body language is everything- if you cross your arms or look down all the time, it‚Äôs telling people that you‚Äôre closed off and insecure, and hard to communicate with. If you sit by yourself in a class instead of sitting with your peers, they‚Äôre going to continue letting you sit there instead of coming up to you and bothering someone who seems disinterested in others. If you do that, it might be another reason why others don‚Äôt approach you. Try to have open body language- uncrossed arms, a confident stance, eye contact, etc. all go a very long way. 

 This isn‚Äôt just going to happen overnight- it‚Äôll be a gradual change, from finally having a good conversation with someone to having an entire friend group. It takes time and self-improvement, but by God it‚Äôs worth it. If all of this sounds too overwhelming or too drastic of a change from your personality, just simply smiling at people every day and saying ‚Äúhello‚Äù is enough for someone to eventually start talking to you. Friendliness trumps all. Above all, your mental health and true personality are the most important- don‚Äôt lose yourself in trying to impress others. Godspeed, dude. You‚Äôll find your friends one day.

stance_justification: The writer demonstrates evaluativist thinking by providing reasoned arguments with evidence (citing John Gottman's concept), acknowledging the complexity of relationship dynamics, and offering qualified advice rather than absolute directives. They engage with the underlying issue thoughtfully, weighing different approaches ('right' vs. 'liked') and suggesting a balanced solution based on observed patterns.
stance_markers: ["I think it's important to distinguish", "Groups generally run best on consensus", "In short, you need to decide", "I think you'd do a lot better if", "how can we do this so we're both happy?"]
text:
I think it's important to distinguish between opinions and facts.  Your post reminds me of someone I know, who thinks that "those curtains should be blue" is a fact.  Facts are things like 2+2=4.  Opinions are things like "this roleplay should be done this way".

John Gottman talks about something called "accepting influence", and basically, it means to really consider the other person's point, then form your opinion from there.  If the only input you get is your own, you're missing a lot.  Groups generally run best on consensus.  If you want a friend group, they're not going to put up with you deciding, without input, what's best.  (At least, not for long.)

In short, you need to decide whether or not you want to be "right" or liked.  Clearly, your way of handling relationships is not working.  I think you'd do a lot better if you stopped with "it's gonna be my way" and started with "how can we do this so we're both happy?"

text:
Guys perspective:
The guy is likely scared, but does not want to give up.  The simple questions and answers are likely because he's scare, rather or not he will admit it.  The reason for the fear varies, but he may not want to inadvertently cross a line.  

Think about this, how many post, stories, complaints do you hear about guy only thinking about sex, or going overboard, or just not respecting women.

Now compare that to the number like this complaining about guy being too mellow, or being boring, or not seeming interesting.  There are more of the latter then people realize, but still pales to the number of the former.

Men are given conflicting information just as much as women, just as much as women, just in different categories.  Everyone interprets it differently.  

My advice is that if you really want to know, ask open ended questions.  Not simple "How are you doing?" Type stuff, because those should expect "Fine" as an answer.   Something that he would want to answer.

It is possible he's a douche, but he may also feel he is not interesting enough, or that you would not like what you find out about him.

Edit:  I have very limited context, so could be off base.  Up to you to decide if you want to find out.

I think that's a case of the feedback telling you *some* part of the story but not what actually is going on.

Example 1:

Your choice of words and structure in the first example is both generalizing ("Anytime I see..." "usually assume") and authoritative as hell. You're putting yourself above the article, the author, the user who posted it (since they shared it because they thought it's not garbage) and for most readers you're putting yourself above "scientists" even though you meant the interpretation and not the actual science behind it.

The latter is easily fixed (and against what you're trying to communicate so I'd suggest incorporating it) by changing it up into e.g. "[...]see an article that *claims*[...]" - you're now clearly attacking the article and the "it" in "it is garbage" hopefully is harder to misinterpret.

Another approach would be to take the angle that you hate how scientific findings are misinterpreted by media (which leads to you calling the article garbage). Now that I think about it, this is probably my favorite because it's a lot more bulletproof because you're supporting one authority instead of trying to be a different one.

______

Example 2:

(Did you fuck up and meant to say "Sweden's"? I can't find Switzerland or Swiss when I ctrl+f in that article. Speaks for your conversational partner that you were told you're condescending instead of that btw. =P)

This one is harder in my opinion. You decided to nitpick a specific point and the person in question will think "BUT WHAT ABOUT ALL THE OTHER POINTS!?!" - these are the kind of spots where I'd recommend either going all out internet smackdown and mentioning all points I think that are wrong, rolling eyes and not saying anything *or* (if it's for example one major misconception in the article that really grinds my gears) appeasing to people's feelings first. "While I like most of the article I really feel the need to point out that ...", "I didn't have the time to go through everything in detail but I'd like to add that...", this kind of stuff.

In this case you picked the fact bulldozer on one spot, ignored everything else and take an easy "victory" which tends to upset some people.
______

Overall I think Example 2 is one where I'd work on a little in the sense of the above but the first case you might have the wrong friends in that spot *or* you just don't have enough friends that like how you think. Keep in mind that whoever shared it thought it's cool/funny/awesome and you're being the "buzzkill" with all your condescending attitude.

From my point of view, bullshit. They shared it, it's up for discussion and you made a strong case for why that crap shouldn't be celebrated. If you don't want to be seen as part of an echo chamber that tells everyone how cool it is they're sharing their thoughts in the first place, this is the way to go.

They provide reasoned recommendations with specific criteria (e.g., '45 degrees from the side of your body') while acknowledging uncertainty with phrases like 'I think' and explicitly stating 'This is just my opinion.' This shows calibrated confidence - they're helpful but humble about the limits of their knowledge.
stance_markers: ["I think that", "This is just my opinion", "hopefully it's helpful", "I found these tips pretty useful", "In general I think"]
text:
I used to be self conscious of the way I walked and how my arms swung too, but after googling how to walk normally, I found these tips pretty useful:

- Walk tall, as if there is string attached to the top of your head and someone is pulling up on it. Make sure your shoulders are relaxed because this is key to allowing your arms swing normally.

- Keep your arms relaxed and let them sway at your sides while you walk. The point is not to focus on how your arms are swinging, just let them swing how they want to. But make sure they swing alternately, e.g. left arm in front/right arm behind, then vice versa. Avoid swinging both to the front, both to the back, etc.

In general I think that your arms shouldn't swing up more than about 45 degrees from the side of your body.

This is just my opinion, but hopefully it's helpful >.<

text:
Does it look childish? Yea. Is that a bad thing? Depends.

If you're trying to find people with similar interests as you, shirts like this are great for that. But a lot of other people may think it's childish and weird and may avoid you for it. But consider this: are those people you would've wanted to meet or become friends with anyways?

Additionally, consider how it appears not only to your peers, but your professors and potential job connections as well. If your professor is quirky and loves Pok√©mon, that could instantly put you on their good side. But otherwise, it does look childish, and likely some adults won't take you seriously because of it.

But rather than worrying about what people will think, just do whatever you want to do. Present yourself however you want to present yourself. If you want to present yourself as quirky, then dress quirky. If you want to present yourself as mature, then dress mature. See, I have a social anxiety disorder, so I could never wear a shirt that's anime or video game related in any way, despite liking both. But if you don't have a clinical anxiety disorder like me, then for the love of God just be yourself. That's the best way to attract the right kind of people you like, and is honestly something I wish I could do.

And don't rush to get a gf. I get it, I'm in the same boat, wishing I was in a relationship. But if you make it a goal to get a gf asap, you're going to become desperate and rush into a relationship blindly, and that relationship could potentially be very toxic. Or maybe you change the way you act to impress a girl, but now you're in a relationship with someone who doesn't truly know the real you. Either way, finding a gf asap shouldn't be a *goal*. It can be a desire, but it shouldn't be something you go out of your way to do, if that makes sense.

text:
Lol that's so presumptuous to think that no one over the age of 20 knows anything about Snapchat. We were on Snapchat before you could muster up enough literacy to read the word Snapchat.

It doesn't mean anything special on snapchat. It depends on the person, and nothing is true for all people. It is not a function of snapchat itself, but rather the people who are hitting you up on snapchat are probably just the people who are most likely to send a "hey wyd" message.   
The thing with snapchat is that you can quickly send the same snap to many people at once with little effort. For many people, it is a low effort way to fish for conversation and/or attention. Even lower effort than a "wyd" text.... I would be wary of anyone who sends that as a conversation started unless they immediately follow it up with something of note. If they are just asking you what's up to try to coax you into having a conversation with them, they probably don't have anything worth talking about anyway.

stance_justification: The text presents a single, definitive approach to ending friendships as the correct method, using directive language throughout ('you should plan,' 'don't give the person an opening,' 'no means no'). There's no acknowledgment that different situations might require different approaches or that the advice might not work for everyone - it's presented as universal truth.
stance_markers: ["you should plan what you say carefully", "Don't give the person an opening", "Keep it short", "Maintain eye contact", "No means no, no matter what", "make the decision final", "be confident and decisive"]
text:
Plan what to say. If you want to confront the person and tell him or her that you don't want to hang out anymore, you should plan what you say carefully. If you have a random outburst or don't choose your words wisely, the person may not think that you're being serious or that you really thought it through. You're going to tell that person that you don't want to hang out with him anymore, so you can think of the best way to explain why.


If the person is just really annoying and you don't have the heart to say it, just say that you're not enjoying the friendship, that the friendship is harmful for you, or that you'd just like to spend some time apart from the person -- permanently.
If there's a more concrete reason, like the person makes you feel bad about yourself, the person always talks about himself and doesn't listen to anyone, or the person is even outright mean to you, then you can tell the person this.
If you don't want to be honest, that's fine too. Tell the person you don't have time for friends, that you're going through a hard time and want to be alone, or that you just want to focus on your studies.

Tell the person that you're ending the friendship. Pick a time and place where you can be relatively alone, and say what you have to say. Stand a bit far away from the person and cross your arms over your chest, showing that you're already retreating. Don't give the person an opening to try to win you over, promise to change, or even try to touch or hug you.


Keep it short. Don't give the person a lot of time to react.
Maintain eye contact. Show the person that you really mean it.

Find the person another friend. If you want to be nice after confronting the person, you can steer the person toward a club, activity, or new location that can help the person make some new friends. This can not only be better for the person, but better for you. But you should only do this if you're feeling a bit sorry for kicking the person out of your life.


If the person finds new friends, he'll forget about you in no time at all.

Follow through. If you've decided to cut off contact with that person for good (after potentially steering him in a new direction), then make the decision final. Don't let the person grovel, randomly show up, or follow you into a coffee shop and force you to have coffee. No means no, no matter what. If the person continues to bug you, you shouldn't sound threatening, but be confident and decisive about your decision.

stance_justification: The writer presents a structured analysis identifying two specific reactions people have to overly nice personalities, providing detailed reasoning for each. They acknowledge complexity ('this is where a bit of acting is necessary') and offer nuanced advice that weighs trade-offs rather than absolute prescriptions. The analysis shows calibrated confidence - they're certain about the patterns they've observed but acknowledge the need for situational judgment.
stance_markers: ["There are two reactions you're going to get", "This can lead to", "A lot of people are very jaded", "I'm not going to say this means you should", "just that you need to demonstrate", "so that is something to work on"]
text:
There are two reactions you're going to get to someone with that kind of personality:

* Someone sees prey who is easy to take advantage of. If you have a wholesome personality like Mickey Mouse people will think "this person assumes everyone is well-intentioned, and I can use that to encourage them to do things for me." This can lead to being used as a "henchman" by predators and bullies, and it can lead also to being swindled or manipulated into compromising positions.
* It's assumed the "nice" thing is an act because you want something, whether it's money, sex, a relationship, social status or for other people to vouch for you when you engage in wrongdoing. A lot of people are very jaded and cynical because they've been around folks who act all buddy-like with the hopes that it will be "rewarded" with some specific type of payoff. This can make people feel a little bothered or uncomfortable if you present in that kind of way.

It's absolutely essential to be kind, but this is where a bit of acting is necessary. Being kind in a sort of Silas Marner way that shows that you're on your guard and have an edge is going to temper some of these assumptions a little bit. I'm not going to say this means you should act like a dickhead while offering to fix someone's bike tires or spot them a dollar, just that you need to demonstrate awareness. A lot of people who think of themselves as "nice" or "kind" lack the theory of mind to know how other people might perceive this and react accordingly, so that is something to work on.

text:
>Attractive women don't buy drinks

You think this is a categorical law of the universe? 

Believe me, attractive women buy drinks. Buying a drink does not necessarily mean they want to sleep with a man, though they might just want to talk.

You described yourself as just sitting at the bar, kind of aloof from people. Maybe she thought you looked lonely and could use a conversation?

Is that an "ulterior motive" in your opinion? Simply being friendly? Because it is highly, highly unlikely to be anything beyond that or an attempt to flirt.

Probably she had no agenda. Let's just do a thing and see where it goes.

>getting compliments at a bar about your clothes just screams "nice outfit, but I'm not attracted to you" lol

Come on. You don't seriously believe this, do you? Talking about peoples clothes is a tried and true ice breaker. 

Most people go to bars to meet other people and have a good time. They frequently say, "hey nice shirt" and much like buying a drink, it often means they are attracted to you, but doesn't necessarily mean they want to sleep with you, just a friendly way to start a conversation about something more interesting than clothes.

It CERTAINLY doesn't mean they think you're ugly. 

You know a good way to determine how someone actually feels? Talk to them for a little bit. Everyone is different. There's no mathematic THING 1 = THING 2, she did this and so this means that.

These are strangers. You're making wild assumptions about what they think instead of talking to them.

It sounds like you're obsessed with 2 things: your clothes are nice but have nothing to do with your personality 2. You are ugly.

Not everything that happens is related to those factors. And from the story you told, even through your own lens, it's quite obvious that NONE of the events that occurred had anything to do with those 2 factors, except for how you behave.

You're overthinking this, and your thinking is off base.

You come here with the question "what ulterior motive would a pretty woman have to buy an ugly man a drink". 

There are 3 assumptions in that question that dozens of people here are challenging.

There's a benefit to coming to a forum on social skills and saying, "here's how my anxiety causes me to interpret the situauton; what am I getting wrong?"

But you don't seem open to accepting that you might have made an incorrect assumption or two.
