text:
I have no idea why would you bring the "sorta..." thing, but I understand your shame, which is not uncommon thing after those experiences...

My question is a bit practical, but also clarifying. Do you want to learn to dance and enjoy it as some other people do? Or do you want to learn how to feel better about yourself and clear out the insecurities you carry in your mind often times during social events? You may pick both actually. If dancing is something you really would love to be good at.

Let's start with You. Why do you believe you feel that way? And why do you believe it's not a good thing to happen to you - to have such feelings? In my understanding those feelings are perfectly fine for a person with undeveloped emotional body. Whether you'll carry them through your life or let yourself understand and accept them is really up to you. Having feelings is normal. Having feelings you decided to label bad is normal as well. Being suicidal because of that is not uncommon but it's in most people's understanding not healthy. Back to the basics. What world do you believe you are living in? Is it a hostile place, or is it a friendly place? That's a core believe, but it also reflects how you treat yourself. Do you love and appreciate yourself or do you treat yourself badly? And if you treat yourself well, probably you would not imagine yourself to be living into a hostile world. You will pick the friendly world. Are you ready to understand that you are making this choice all the time? By deciding what other people's behavior mean to you. But not only that. You have the Creator's power within you, and from that core understanding and belief, you paint on top of reality your version of it and experience it the way you believe it to be in your core. You can at any given tume change your core beliefs and the relationship you have with yourself. You can also be aware how that fulfillment changes your capacity to recognize certain things in other people's behavior. Your interpretations and reactions change, based on your way of perceiving.

Dude, it's normal to be awkward. Period. Love and appreciate this awkwardness (yourself really)! Check how Elvis Pressly was dancing back in the days. That was one of the most awkward thing people have seen at that time, and considered as a way of dancing. You can always go and visit some dancing lessons and even meet some great people and friends there. People you've never knew existed before. You have the capacity to connect with and relate to those people. You may even become passionate about dancing. It all starts with how you treat yourself, how you think about yourself, how you feel about yourself, and do you enjoy your own company! Next step based upon that clarification and if you decide to treat yourself better by your own love and appreciation towards yourself, you will really choose to believe that you are living in a good and friendly world. Because you can be good and friendly, actually everyone can if they choose to. And many choose to, after they meet another human being that has already chosen for himself/herself. Because it feels good. It feels good to be. It feels good to exist. It feels good to be yourself. And even when bad things happen and unpleasant feelings arise it's all right. That's also a way of being good to yourself - to let yourself experience those feelings and to appreciate yourself - the one capable to experience such feelings. No need for the blame game, no need for the shame game. They may happen on the surface as some form of joyful entertainment, but the core is different and everyone understands it is a joke and some of your friends may decide to perticipate in such a game for the joy of it. It becomes superficial. It always has been. You were not in the know of it. It's normal. Most people go through this one way or another. Some keep themselves away from themselves for their entire life. But even they at the end of their lives usually realize it for what it really was and let it go/get free from what they misbelieved to be true. Don't wait for the end. Do it now. And don't rush to end the life you are. It may end in its due time, it may not (most people don't know about this possibility). Live it fully and happily and joyfully and lovingly as much as you get capable of and then even some more. In a way you deserve it. In a way you owe it to yourself. In a way it's your inheritance. And I won't wish you happiness, I'd allow myself to feel happy for you right now. Because I choose to and it's my selfless way to be selfish. üòÑ

Enjoy your voyage, my friend! And don't forget to shere in here your happy experiences from college as well. We'd like to know what (and who) makes you laugh there. For the creepy peeps we all happen to be that will be something good to peep into. ‚ù§Ô∏è

text:
that's fine, I'm not going to explain how you should do it, since everyone has their own ways.  But i'll give you my detail of some people i started knowing in my classes and how i met them.  Usually the people in my class whether they are a little bit further away or next to me.  The ones next to you are easier because they're next to you and you can just make a small conversation of like.  How did you do on the exam? or How was the homework?  Eventually you guys can lead to small subjects.  I sometimes compliment them on something if I really mean it.  Don't do it just to compliment but if you actually mean it, it has a bigger effect.  This girl I remember we just talked about school most the time.  I usually ask oh you taking any other classes besides this?  What's your major?  IF they're undecided, i usually say something to uplift them like im sure you'll find out what you want to do.  There is something you like to do right? :)  

I mostly talk about them and what they're into.  If you notice they seem to be a little bit annoyed then its time to back away.  You don't want to be the pushy interrogation guy.  You just want to know enough, and let it be.  Let them talk to you again instead.  Start over the next day.  Good morning or hows it going *name*.  How's ur day been?  and you can reset it again.  After a while you guys get used to each other depending on the person.  Everyone is different.  They have different people they prefer to hang out with.  My group around me we hung out together during the breaks of our classes because it was a Lab.  And we talked to each other because we needed help.  We ended up asking for each other's facebook.  And was like hey, what's do you got a facebook?  We could help each other on the work if anything.  That's just my to go advice.  Good luck!

I can‚Äôt trust either of my brothers and they usually yell at me too if I try to talk to them.

On the flip side I have a friend who‚Äôs family hardly yelled and let‚Äôs them pursue what they want. He calls his family regularly at school and they all laugh and have a good time. He‚Äôs way more confident. My priest does the same thing with his family. His children are so happy all the time. Anger only breeds more anger and hate.

As for friends / friend groups, they will subconsciously test you by making jokes about you. It‚Äôs up to you to react properly or else you‚Äôll be the cuck of the group. All you have to do is agree and exaggerate

I can‚Äôt speak for relationships because I‚Äôve never had a GF

text:
The comment about writing down your feelings is solid and I too suggest you do that. But here is something I think might help. 

I keep hearing a lot of people in this forum bring up the idea of "not being invited to events by their friends". And here is my take on that. 

I think there is too much of a focus on "me" and not enough on "them". In other words, how can you ADD value to others in a way that will make them want to hang out with you?

Let's say your friends are throwing a party soon and you hear them talking about it. 

How could you add value to that party? 

Well, if you worked at a place like Jimmy Johns(sandwich shop), you could say, "Hey guys, I heard your throwing a party. If you need food or catering, I could talk to my boss and see if he'd be willing to give you a discount if you bought enough food."

Now imagine if you are those other people and someone came up to you saying they could possibly get you a discount on catered food. 

You'd be like heck yea, this dude is awesome! Even if you can't get the discount from your boss and they have to pay full price, at least you come off as a guy/gal who knows how to add value to the situation. 

Do you see how if you adopted this mentality, you would probably be sought after more often. And again, you don't have to work at a sandwich shop to do this. It could be anything. But think of how you could add value and start doing it. 

Hope that helps. 

-Carlos

text: This situation can be relatable to anyone of us, even any teenager in the world. The good old ‚Äûnew boy in class that knows no one‚Äù. I think best you can do right now is start aproaching a group of your choice. And by ‚Äûaproaching‚Äù i DON'T mean agressively aproach them, like "hey what's up guys can i stay with you?". You can always just randomly show up to them and ask them why are they laughing, for example. Or just sit by them in a break between classes. You'll slowing be getting in one of the groups in no time. At least this worked for me. As for knowing particular individuals, outside a group, it can get harder because of the more intimate environment. Best advice that i can give it to you is practice. It can be done any way you want : either saying randomly hi to a class mate, or sending good night messages to a girl or something, or even setting different social tasks in your mind for every day. Like "today i want to make someone laugh. Tomorrow i want to find out someone's crush. etc" things like these. Being socially active is just like a chore. It's something that needs to be done actively and consistently. It sucks, i know.

text:
oh man, im sorry to hear that.  I understand what you mean by Chernobyl of social interactions!  Thanks for telling me your story, makes me happy that you actually tried to work with my way of interacting and responding to me looking for more advice.  Especially out of all the other people there is in the thread :].  

Yeah i had a similar experience before where I would ask how to do the homework, and try to create small talk, but all they responded was either one word answers or prefer not to keep a conversation going or show no interest.  Man, imagine how I felt, or me and you.  We're just trying to connect with a couple people but they don't seem interested in getting to know each other.

But, the honest truth is that not everyone is interested to make more friends or interested in learning more about a person or getting to know them.  Everyone has a different personality and they would only click with you if they had something in common that they love and you love.  I already explained about complimenting something about them that not everyone has.  But, that's more for trying to pick up a chick/guy or you're interested in complimenting them.  But don't be too hard on yourself.  I know a couple of friends that when people barely meet them, they just answer the questions and keep to themselves.  They don't put the effort in trying to know the person because they just simply don't care.  They might just be there just to go to class and leave, or they already have a boyfriend/girlfriend and not interested in meeting more people.  People usually connect through having same interest.  You would need something that would make them go, Interesting or WOW, i would like to know more about this guy or what he's done.  But mostly people enjoy talking about themselves other than listening to other people.  

Everyone is different remember that, so don't take yourself down too hard.  Matter of fact, this semester in school, i don't have any friends in class.  I mean i talk to a couple people, but it's not like we stay connected.  However, Last year, I made two friends that i eventually got their facebook and we hung out after class and got food together.  We just clicked.  I don't talk to them anymore though, it was just a short Chemistry hang out buddies because we had same class and studied together.  Just try to pass this semester, and try again next semester.  Next semester you can be more open because you're used to rejection now.  PLUS, they never met you before so it may seem like you're an outgoing positive person and easy to talk to.  It basically means that your comfort with everybody is at neutral in the new class.  SO that means you get a fresh start.  Sometimes in the 1st day of class, i just introduce myself to people who sit around me and i get to know their name.  and ask about their major, why they taking this class, how was their summer or winter.  I then talk about their hobbies and try to see if we got any similar interest.  Most important of all is be yourself and don't try to force it too much.  Sometimes talking to someone too much, will annoy the person.  

Sorry if i made the message too long, i like to sometimes repeat or be descriptive.  Hope this helped a bit!

text:
**Disclaimer:** I am by no means a social authority.

What works for me is a positive and succinct explanation. 
e.g. See someone else you'd like to speak with? "Oh, hey! My old friend ____ is here, I wonder what they're up to. I'll go say 'hi', catch up with you later?" It's reasonable reason to leave but reaffirms that they are worthwhile *and* that you're interested in further conversation.

A favorite of mine is "I'm so lazy at social events; I just want to talk to the people I already know I like. I'm going to go mingle... I'll catch up to you when I give up in three minutes."

*Note:* You don't want to leave in a hurry. You could even lead up to leaving by having a conversation related to what you're leaving to do. "I think I may go get a drink... by the way, were you there at so-and-so's party with that failed keg stand?"

*Additional Note:* Leave on a high note. If you leave when conversation lulls, they'll think you're ditching them. Leave 'em wanting more. **(This part took me way too long to figure out.)**

text:
> If not, don't.

If I can add a counterpoint, you should not feel social pressured to do something you dont want to do just because everyone else in the group does.

The peer pressure argument of "well all the other guys in the group do it so you should too" argument can be very compelling. But nobody should ever be shamed or guilt tripped into doing something they are not comfortable with.

I have a grand total of 6 people on my "hug friends" list. And there are some social circles where a hello-hug or goodbye-hug is the default standard. I have had to explain on many occasions that I simply do not know the person well enough that I feel comfortable with a hug. (They do get a high five if they want though!)

Your personal boundaries on who you do or do not feel comfortable hugging is entirely your choice. If the two other guys in the group think that is "rather weird" then it is them who has the problem and not you.

It comes in form of aggregated knowledge and observation from people interacting with you or others. Try to set your state of mind as being just a mere observers in these interactions. Hopefully that will ease your uneasiness. Pay attention to topics or subjects that relevant to day-to-day with your local folks.  It is perfectly fine to just be quiet and softly smile and nodding at what talking.

Look up on some tips on how to read body language could be helpful too. This way you can quickly tell if a person feels comfortable to interact with other people or if he/she wants to be left alone. Don't over-analyze on how people would think of you. As long as you don't say something offensive to other people, you should be fine (the catch here is that it is not up to you to decide what is offensive to a person).

However, avoid getting into religion and politics at all cost unless you and other people are in more laid back environment.

Just keep doing trials and errors (within the acceptable boundary of your local custom), learn from mistake, don't beat yourself too hard if you did it wrong.

text:
Look friend, here's the skinny.  Life is hard.  Life will always be hard.  Don't think that your life would suddenly be all peachy-keen if you had the respect/love from people that you're after, that's not how it works - but I can understand how it can feel that way.  Right now it sounds like you're placing a lot of your self-worth into how these people view you.  NOT HEALTHY.

You need to start talking to yourself differently.  You need to tell yourself that your worth is NOT based off of what anyone else thinks of you, and then go out and live it.  Do things for yourself.  Do things for other people.  Pick a day and go find some activities that you would NEVER normally do otherwise.  Get out of your fucking comfort zone!  Get better at your hobbies.  Be a better boyfriend.  Having zero idea of what to do is the PERFECT place to be because it means you can do ANYTHING.

I have a voice in the back of my mind that calls bullshit on me whenever I would complain or whine or feel bad about myself, because I knew that I wasn't really making the effort to fix my own problem.  YOU HAVE TO FIX YOUR OWN PROBLEMS.  You're not respected the way you want to be?  Take a step back... are my flatmates douche bags or am I the one who's awkward and not all that fun or adventurous?  Be honest with yourself.  Be brutal.  Then go fucking fix it and stop whining.

That's harsh, but I hope I have shown you that it's not coming from a place of anger or contempt towards you - this is what worked for me.  Practice ignoring your stupid brain when it tells you all this negative stuff.  STUPID BRAIN.  If your friends are dicks, drop them.  If you're awkward, watch videos & read books on how not to be.

Are you being honest with that voice inside your head?  Sure, maybe we can help you a little bit; but you're the only one who can REALLY help you.

text:
No problem, I completely understand. 

That is exactly what a soft plan conversation would be like.

It is entirely possible for your coworkers to like you and not invite you to after hours activities. When people are in long term relationships or married, they tend to socialize more with other couples. Do not take it personally. Even some of the strongest friendships can be strained when one friend enters a long-term relationship.

It could still be possible to initiate an activity without needing to invite them to your place. Try to find an organized event hosted in a public space like a bowling league or pub trivia night. Depending on your personality, you can go alone, see what it is like, and find out the rules and how to enter. Then you can talk to your coworkers or other people who you think might be interested and see if they are interested in starting a team with you (you may not want to mix the two groups of people). 

If you figure out what the questions are, feel free to ask here or in a private message. I won't judge!

stance_justification: The writer provides reasoned explanations for their position about how to interact with children, offering multiple viable approaches while acknowledging that different responses are appropriate in different situations. They demonstrate evaluative thinking by explaining WHY certain behaviors work ('they're just checking you out and investigating like the little scientists they are') and providing nuanced guidance that weighs different considerations (being polite vs. not being obligated to interact extensively).
stance_markers: ["just like with any other human interaction", "You could... or you could... or you could", "Just keep it relevant and age appropriate", "90% of the time", "that's normal", "Just try not to be too put off", "they just don't know any better"]
text:
Children are people too. Just smaller people with less life experience and they're still learning how to handle their emotions and behave properly in society.

When a kid comes up to you and stares they're just checking you out and investigating like the little scientists they are. You don't have to acknowledge them if you don't want to but all you have to do is be polite, just like with any other human interaction. You could nod at them and then look away or go back to your business, you could give them a little wave and a smile, or you could say hi and ask them how they are or let them know how cool you think their batman shirt is or whatever. Talk to them like you would talk to anyone else. Just keep it relevant and age appropriate.

You're certainly not expected to play with a child that you don't know, all that's really expected of you is to not hurt them or be mean to them since 90% of the time the child isn't trying to hurt you or be mean to you. It's ok if you smile at a kid and then they get shy, that's normal, you didn't do anything wrong.

I love children but I'm not one of those women that goes "Ohhhh my gawwwwd you're so cuuuute! Hi! What's your name??" I'm a quiet, chill kind of person and I like to let kids approach me if they want to rather than the other way around. You don't have to be super loud and active to be "good with kids". And it's ok to just not interact. Sometimes on the bus a kid will just keep staring at me and I won't really want to talk or interact. I just smile at them and then look away and do my thing. They're going to meet all kinds of people as they grow up and it's important for them to learn how to leave people alone too. Just try not to be too put off by the staring, they just don't know any better.

One is simply that", "It usually ends up exploding later on", "trust me, you don't want to be approved of by people who", "they stand a much better chance of making real, healthy, lasting connections", "It's obvious that your childhood left a lot of scars", "Yes, it is very unfair that your parents didn't give you the early love"]
text:
You're right, you are projecting quite a bit. 

>- it makes others feel at ease. When you're carrying yourself confidently, it might piss others off ("who does this guy think he is"). Others might test your confidence - women often do that to men

Confident people may make *you* uncomfortable because of your own negative self perception and self comparison to them. They may piss *you* off because of your opinion of the unfairness of it all. But that's not actually how most people feel.

Self confidence is actually what puts a lot of people at ease. That's one of the main reasons that confident people experience more social success. For many reasons. One is simply that when you're with a person who feels secure in themselves, you feel more honored because that person has chosen to be in your company. They're not just with you because they don't think they can do better.

Self confident people are also more generally fun to be around because they're able to engage in the present moment instead of being stuck in their heads. In closer relationships, authentic confidence allows partners or friends to also freely grow, enjoy life, and be themselves because they don't need to be worried about catering to insecurities. 

>- it avoids conflict. When someone is angry at you and you're insecure, you don't fight back and there is no conflict.

Conflict avoidance and not standing up for yourself are not good things. Well adjusted people don't generally want to deal with those who just bottle everything up inside and don't communicate. When we care about someone, we want them to be able to express if they're upset so that we can genuinely work on resolving the problem. I don't trust people who bottle shit up. It usually ends up exploding later on and way worse than it would have been than just communicating like adults to begin with. 

Also, trust me, you don't want to be approved of by people who like you because you avoid conflict and just do what they want. Those are the people that will take advantage of you and hurt you. 

>- it makes others like you. When you're insecure, you do what you think others will like, which gets you accepted. When you're confident, you don't want to change for others, which might mean being alone forever.

That goes against your other claims. Obviously insecure people aren't getting accepted. If they were then you wouldn't be making this post. Confident people are not doomed to be alone forever. In fact, they stand a much better chance of making real, healthy, lasting connections. And they're better able to enjoy life even when they're more isolated, because they can find value in their own company. 

It's obvious that your childhood left a lot of scars on you. I'm sorry for that. Yes, it is very unfair that your parents didn't give you the early love and acceptance that they should have. It is unfair that it's now up to you to learn the self respect that they should have taught you. But it is what it is. I hope you can find what you need.

They share personal experiences without claiming these approaches will work for others, and explicitly avoid making evaluative judgments about what the reader should do.

text:
Hey man. I just wish you would take time and read this completely because I feel it's going to be a little long. Firstly, I am sorry for what you are going through and I hope you will find what you are looking for. **Disclaimer: these are just my thoughts, you don't have to accept it, you can just unlike it or delete it even, I dont mind.** And also I am younger than you and I feel like I have my shares of loneliness (no friends I could share my deepest secrets, just friends in names, there are nobody I have nearby that I could share my interests with, I don't hang out with anyone in my own class and I might be like a shadow lol) and I am not saying that I know exactly what you are going through because that doesn't bring justice to what you are going through as I don't know if it is the same as me.

First of all I am not going to give you false hopes saying that it is going to work out if you think that people love you and stuff. But that is a part of it. Just have positive thoughts. And you know how you could be positive? Here's what I figured would kick-start us to be positive. I started to find things that made me curious and exciting, and I work on that. I was lucky to have found out my interest at a young age (I am still young by the way :P lol) and I am intending to take it as my career. I realized this recently as I was really depressed for maybe two months and this week I found something that is in my interest and I started working on it by creating a small goal. I was happy to be able to be consistent with it and working on it. I get excited when I see that I am progressing little by little. Also, I enjoy the working part more than seeing my goal accomplished. But I also know that if I drop this goal at some point, depression will be back in the house. That's why I am trying very careful not to be burnout and try to complete it, so I get an accomplished feeling and use that for the next thing I might be doing. 

I believe that there are many things that as an individual we are interested in it and I don't think that there is a magical destiny for each of us or magical talent that we need to discover inside us blah blah blah. So just give a thought in what you are interested in and try to work in it. It doesn't matter, it can be anything. Painting, dancing, music, instrument, programming, tinkering with gadgets, designing, martial arts etc. etc. And you know what, maybe you might find people who share the same interests as you, and you might hit it really well. Try being curious like a kid and explore - that's what I will say.

Also, another thing I will give a lot of credit to in my life was when I started to meditate. Well it's not when I started, it was maybe a long time after I started, like three months after I started. That's when the effects of my daily-two-times-15minutes-meditation started to kick in. At the beginning I was like "what is this, will it ever work?", well I was really convinced when I started to experience the true results. It will take time for some to see the effect of meditation. For some it will be really quick. Fact is, it doesn't matter what the result is, just do it for the sake of doing it. 

Enjoy the path to your destination rather than waiting for the goal to complete to celebrate. Celebrate every day. Who cares if someone ignores me. I like it when I work on the stuff I like ü•≥ yay. This is my current state. Me, who was just one week ago, was trying to think I might be alone for my whole life started to think that maybe I will see someone who have same interests as me. **Again, I am not saying that you should accept this as it is, you can just close this comment and move on with something else if you want and just forget what I said, it is completely up to you.** Everyday something good might happen, something bad might happen. It might be the best day some days. It might be the worst day some days that you feel like why go on more. But who cares if it is a bad day, **let it go**, it doesn't matter in the end.

I just said my experiences and my opinions and the way I tried to tackle my loneliness. I might not have tackled my loneliness, but oh well I got at least my parents who do take care of me, and now I am realizing that there were people who have actually cared about me at some point. I don't think I have to try to tackle my loneliness, I think I have to change my attention to something else. Sorry for making it so long, if this helps you in any way I am happy, if it didn't, well maybe someone else might be able to try and help you. I didn't mean to offend you in any way, if you feel like that anywhere.

text: Don't, there's only a few people that can handle that information. Some ignore it, some don't know how to interact with you afterwards to make you feel at ease and some exploit you. I have kinda figured out that 'whining' is a no no. It makes them feelforced to be nice to you while it should come as natural, tell your problems once you are sure they wanna help you. I am going through a tough time, my parents are fighting/ignoring eachother more and more, my group of friends that I used to hang out with stopped doing that with ME, I am out of shape/not confident with it and a washing list of other stuff  and as a 18 y/o trying to secure a future thats not perfect, but just keep your head up, smile and interact. Even just a simple friendly hello. The way you see the world is entirely up to you, fuck the rest if they dont want to help you, but also know that people want to know you because they like interaction in general(I have missed all the girls that were attracted to me and noticed too late for instance) Dont force a friendship if you dont think its gonna work. Read the newspaper occasionally, sport, listen to music and you will have some talking material. But dont keep blabbing about your achievements at the gym cuz that makes you arrogant and boring. No one can become a social person just like that. Let it grow and change your attitude. Dont 'feel' like it should have happened, just get the best out of it while you can.

text:
You either lie to them or go out of your comfort zone, show confidence and tell them to stop overreacting and trust you and your decision.

Since you are just 18 and these are your parents, they will show resistance and it will cost you probably a lot of energy.

When I had to confront my parents to stop being over carrying, never letting me do something because "I might do something wrong", it was obviously not easy because this is what they conditioned themself and what was "normal" for them. This behavior leads me to lack taking responsibility and be overly fearing doing anything on my own without having anyone to give me the "safety".

It took tons of energy and work to get out of this, including open communication with my parents, telling them to stop being that overly protective and let me do my own experiences EVEN if this means that I will do something wrong and might "burn my fingers".

Even today they are like "Double/Tripple check that you turn off the grill, the lights, the fridge, the oven,.." and I have to stop them proactively like "Hey, thank you but as I already said, it's okay. I am not stupid, it's not like I don't know this stuff. And if something happens on accident, it's called an accident with a reason because you do something wrong even if you know its wrong and even when someone told you to take care of it, so the only thing you do with this overprotective mode is to programming me into becoming insecure and losing responsibility, stop that please."

For me, it took me like 26 years to stand up for myself because I didn't know it better. I thought there is nothing wrong with it until I learned how much it was harming me and my personality.

For your parents, you will always be their sweet little child which they have to protect and it's not always easy to get out of your bird's nest. But it\`s a necessary step to learning responsibility. This doesn't mean that you have to start a fight, just open communication for what you want and what not and that they please tolerate your decision. If you ever need help, you will ask them for help. And you might repeat this over and over until they finally let you do what you want.

text:
I'm 26F and I had a very similar experience to yours. Spent most of my time in college depressed and barely socializing. Actually now that I think about it, I don't have any friends from college lol. Didn't date either. I'm doing a lot better now. Here's some advice:

**First and foremost, you need to address the depression.** 

I say this because depression clouds your judgement. You could've went through college getting to experience all the things you missed out on, but still felt like shit at the end of the day because you're depressed. 

You could've gotten invited to the best parties but your depressed mind would be telling you shit like "So what? Those people don't like you anyways!" You see what I mean? So you gotta get this under control first so you have a clear picture of your situation, the obstacles (often times they're not as high or daunting as our depressed minds make us feel they are), etc.

If you're open to taking medication: Have you talked to your doctor? Have you tried anti-depressants? Everyone is different but I had good experiences with bupropion personally. Stopped taking it about 3 years ago.  

\- Don't dwell on the past or over what could've been. Acceptance is key to moving forward. You have to accept that you didn't have a typical college experience and then let it go. 

\- It sounds like you need to do some soul searching. What are your hobbies? What do you do for fun? What kind of person do you want to be? Why are you "not good at friendships"? Etc. 

\- Your financial situation: What is your degree in? What job do you currently have? It also might be worthwhile to try asking career centric subs for advice. 

\- If you think it might be worth trying to reconnect with old friends, I say give it a shot. Ask if they'd be down to hang out or meetup to do something. If you don't want to reconnect with old friends, it's time to try to make new ones.

They engage substantively with the problem by addressing counterarguments (explaining why romantic love isn't the biggest part of life) and provide evidence-based recommendations while maintaining humility about their perspective.

text:
Hi OP. I'm around your age with similar interests/disinterests. You need to think about how you can ever expect someone else to love you if you can't even love yourself. Women are people, just like you, with the same fears and wants and dreams, but they're not walking around asking how they can make somebody else complete. I know love is often presented to us like that (he was a drug addict until he met HER, he was kind of a shithead but SHE changed him) but women, like men, just want to have supportive relationships. They don't want to be under pressure to be a cure for your depression. 

Imagine the kind of person you want to be in a relationship with‚Äîmaybe she's supportive, confident, has big dreams that she works hard towards‚Äîand that's the kind of person you need to strive to be, because that's the kind of person that she wants to be with. It's not impossible to become those things, it just takes work, time, and patience. You have to work on yourself.

A lot of people have given you good advice for working on your anxiety, so I won't address that‚ÄîI'm going to focus on the "working on yourself" part. 

* It's good you have some interests, focus on feeding those, and trying something new. If you have a tight budget you can search for "free hobbies" and "free skills"; I've seen a few popular posts like that. You could volunteer and find meaning in giving back to your community. The goal is to enjoy spending time alone, and to find communities of people with similar interests, if you are a social person.
* Go to the gym a few times a week and build up a routine. Everyone is different but personally I would recommend Stronglifts 5x5, there's a free guide and app if you google it. I have found continuously going to the gym helps my anxiety, and has helped me build confidence in myself. It's also helped me love myself, at a very basic level‚Äîsure I don't look like a model, but I know exactly how strong and capable my body is. It's also a good place for me to compete against myself, and to have solid evidence of progress.
* I would STRONGLY encourage you to take a break from dating sites/apps while you take time to focus on yourself. In your current state, you are most likely giving off really strong desperation vibes, and run the risk of attracting someone who is interested in you for the wrong reasons. Give yourself some amount of time‚ÄîI think 6 months would be a good start‚Äîwhere you aren't allowed to use them, and you focus only on yourself. 
* AFTER you have worked on yourself and you return to these places with confidence and love for yourself, you should think about why and how you are messaging these women. They likely get about a million "hey how are you" messages just like yours, and have to try and guess as to who is a genuinely good person they might click with, who is a weird creep, or worse, someone who could hurt them. Make it easier for them. Read their profiles, reach out to people that you are interested in for some reason other than just that they're attractive, and show that in your message. "Hey, I noticed you like nature‚Äîhave you been on any good hikes lately?" Your intent should be to meet someone that you get along with and want to spend more time with, nothing more. If you click, suggest meeting up in public places for casual dates. Be aware that women are often fearful of saying no because they have no way of knowing how you might react‚Äîwill you swear at them, stalk them? Take rejection in stride, politely, and recognize some "soft" forms of rejection (like dodging the question) and leave them alone. 


Finally, you need to deal with this:
> 
> I'm terrified, I'm severely depressed, as I'm writing this I'm crying, I feel like I've failed at life, everyone I know my age has had girlfriends or is with a long term partner.

Romantic love is frankly not the biggest part of life. You've likely already experienced love from friends, family, etc. Focus on what you really want to accomplish with your life‚Äîexcelling your career? making a difference in the world? treating everyone you meet with care and respect? These are all much, much greater things to do with your life than having a girlfriend. Also, what people your age is doing shouldn't impact your happiness so much. What matters more is the kind of people they are than whether or not they're with someone, and you should hold yourself to that same standard. Good luck.

text:
talk to them little by little.  A little more each day.  Get there early, ask how their weekend was.  Ask a question about some homework or something you're having difficulty with and want to really learn.  

I used to have the same kind of problem, and looking back I wish I would have even thought of wanting to speak more to my teachers, like you.  I never gave it thought, I was just tense about it, and dealt with it.  

But talking to authority figures is like doing anything else...catching a football, shooting a basketball, talking to girls, returning something to a store, or whatever it is that is uncomfortable.  Its practice/repetition.  But start slow.  Friday "Bye Mrs Smith, have a good weekend, don't party too much."    Monday, "SOO, how was your weekend?" with a big smile.  Or if that is too much, just hi and bye, or thanks for helping me on that question earlier, I appreciate it.   Stuff like that.  

Its normal for many to feel this way, so understand and remember that, because sometimes just those feelings and thoughts make you tense.  When you realize its normal, it may take a little of the edge off.

edit, also, progress at your level.  If hi/bye, how was your weekend is too simple for your, ask them about where they graduated from, or their family, or more personal stuff.  Its up to you.  But I always think its good to progress slowly and get comfortable in what you talk about.

text:
How do you feel about being introverted? Is it something that you would rather not feel, or is it something you're proud to have as part of your personality? Do you feel like staying in touch with friends over the break would be good? 

The reason I'm asking the questions is because a LOT of this stuff is very subjective. It depends on how you feel about your interactions with the people around you. 

If you own your introversion (I call it the ability to recharge), then it can be a great thing. But if you feel uneasy and anxious about it, then why not take some steps to ease that feeling? Meaning, call up a few friends, send some texts, check in on people. Treat them as you would like to be treated. 

Just my 2c

text:
Okay first of all the answer to all is incredibly situational. My first piece of advice is learn how to read body language and non verbal ques. This might be really hard for some people but timing and reading someone's energy as to whether they're even receptive to initiating conversation is huge. 

Timing in a conversation is also really important. As is receptivity. If the person you're talking to is in a rush or seems unenthusiastic about continuing (try to leave, backing up, doesn't offer conversation back) let them go. They might be into it another day or they might just not like you. 

Not everyone is going to like you. A lot of people literally hate me because I project authentic self -confidence that they are trying to project. It's very much a narcissist/empath dynamic that I've fallen into in many situations. Don't sweat it. They probably suck. Not everyone is good people. 

Listen in a conversation. Don't be planning what you're going to say while the other person is speaking. People LOVE to talk about themselves...LET THEM. I passed my drivers license because I asked the exam lady questions about her son and her experience in her job and she happily talked the whole time. I passed with flying colours. People will get turned off if you start with a lot of I statements and only seem interested in yourself. 

Start slow. You can't become friends with everyone and nothing happens all at once. I'm a social butterfly and there have been times in my life when I had no friends. Get to be your own best friend. Yes I went to movies and got food and even went travelling and to plays alone. If you have an authentic relationship with yourself you'll attract similar people. Find something you're interested in and participate in that community. It's the most organic way to meet people. And you're more likely to find people with the same personality types as you. I made the most friends with people who shared my passions and interests. 

I've joined many clubs and taken classes. Sometimes I don't click with anyone and that's cool. Sometimes I meet an acquaintance and a few times I've met a best friend. It's not the number but the quality. If you have one or two friends work on those relationships and learn from them. 

Not everything is easy. There have been many times I'm shy or insecure or have been young and anxious socially. It's normal. Most people feel some degree of social anxiety and nobody feels that relaxed. That's why people like me often become the joiner of people at parties or the entertainer. 

ALWAYS INTRODUCE YOURSELF WITH A HANDSHAKE. Don't make it wimpy or too aggressive. Short and sweet. Physical contact immediately reduces people's defensiveness and opens them up to you. 

Approaching a group. Make your way into the group and hold space by slowly making your full body facing with everyone else. Most groups naturally gather in circles so everyone can see each other's mouths. Don't lurk outside or to the side it's weird. Don't charge in either. Remember timing and reception. If you don't know anyone when there's a gap in the conversation introduce yourself to the person next to you. Say how you're affiliated to the group "I know So and so from such place". Often times someone else will be watching you two shake hands and if you catch their eye you can open up to more handshakes and introductions. 

Ask a relevant question. How do you guys know so and so? Or how do you like that class you're all in? 

Asking questions, listening, adding more, allowing them to add something, listening and responding. 

Give non creepy compliments. Nothing opens someone up faster than a well-placed NONSEXUAL compliment. 

Example: hey that was a really good question you asked it really helped me. Don't expect anything in return or even a conversation. Give it as an offering. The next time you meet they will likely be more open to talking with you. 

I love your outfit. This looks amazing on you. Can I just say that haircut suits you so well. 

Or. I just wanted to say that you did a really good presentation. I thought you were really confident while public speaking. 

Be specific not creepy. 

A well timed joke is a great way in. If you're not the joke type then laugh appropriately when others make jokes. People look to see who approves of their humour and will be more open joking with you. 

Have a pleasant look on your face. Smile. Laugh. 

Fake it til you make it. I don't always feel confident. But in situations that demand confidence I make sure to stand or sit up straight and project confidence. The energy your project is really important. If you're freaking out people can feel it and it doesn't feel good does it? Everyone likes someone who has a relaxed and self assured way about them. Even if you don't feel it, look and be the part. Wear fitting clothes and decent shoes. Smell good. If someone is close enough to smell you make sure it smells good. Scent and memory are super tied together and a good scent will linger longer in the memory than you think. 

Shoulder back. Back straight. Head up. Wear sunglasses if you don't like to look people in the eyes but at normal times and not indoors obviously. Nobody is perfect looking but if you're put together neatly then you won't stand out or set off alarm bells. 

Most people are as scared of you as you are of them. Like spiders. Be friendly. Receive friendliness.

Be yourself even if you're weird. Be your weird self and find fellow weirdos. If someone doesn't like you fuck them seriously. Just move on. Cultivate good people by being good people. Be helpful and honest and yourself. Put effort into your relationships. And put effort into your relationship with yourself.

Edit: Thank you for the silver! I wrote this massive essay last night not thinking it would help anyone but I'm really glad people found some valuable advice in it.

stance_justification: The writer presents their advice as personal judgment based on experience rather than absolute truth, using qualifiers like 'I don't know if this is the right way' and 'it's just how I do it.' They provide reasoning for each recommendation (e.g., explaining why stupid jokes work to put people at ease) and acknowledge their approach may not work for everyone, showing calibrated confidence appropriate to giving social advice.

text: Hey, sooo I don't know if this is the right way and that it's good for everyone it's just how I do it. Firstly try to act easygoing like your mind isn't going 100 thoughts a second. Make a stupid joke that you know it's not the best but if you start that way a person you talk to will find it easier to have a conversation and be more at ease. I know it's stupid but I usually go for hi how's life, wife, kids even though they don't have a wife and a kid I get a small smile and depending on person we either countinue joking or the other person shares something. The most important rule in my opinion is do not ever ask how are you, that conversation is dead before it started. Secondly, try finding something relatable you both have in common. Everything from irritating teachers in high school(I mean everyone had at least one) to clothes and music. From experience that works the best. Even though we don't talk about smth I find very interesting it's still a conversation and not awkward silence. Thirdly, no pressure. Don't ask personal questions just accept information that the person shares and after time if you're patient he/she will open up to you.

text:
Well my answer to you is the same as it is to 99% of the other posts I see here: you're overthinking it. By putting it in terms of algorithms and reverse engineering a thought process, I think you're taking a lot of the emotion out of it. Let me guess, former STEM major or working in a technical field? I'm joking, but only kind of. That's just how I'm reading into this based on the language you're using.

I feel like I should preface this by saying I have no experience using this technique (at least consciously, in the conversational way I'm talking about here), this is just a totally off the cuff answer. But I think maybe it'll be useful if my assumption about the STEM thing is correct. I studied liberal arts in school, so maybe a different perspective is what you need. 

Have you ever heard of the inverted pyramid in journalism? Basically it's a format for writing a newspaper article, a way of organizing ideas. You start with the broadest, most newsworthy information first. Something extremely general. Then you move to important details. Then other general background information. The reason it's called an inverted pyramid is because the information becomes more specific and focused the more you go down the page.

Just as a rough example:

Last Friday, police arrested a man suspected of three bank robberies in the area. The manhunt has been ongoing for weeks, and the commissioner estimates over $100,000 was taken. The suspect was caught after a brief chase, and is being held on $1 million bail.

I guess I'll let you be the judge, but I think that sounds like a fairly realistic, professional news article if you ignore the fact that it's only three sentences long. That's because it follows the inverted pyramid structure. The first sentence tells what happened: a guy got arrested because the police think he robbed some banks. The next goes into specifics: they've been looking for him for a while now, plus an additional detail of the crime. The third provides more focused detail: how he was caught and what's happening with him right now. I mean there are entire college courses on this, but that's the gist of it.

So to translate that over to something you might say in conversation:

You: Man I love penguins. Just can't get enough of those little guys.

Friend: Why is that?

You: Well I just love how playful they are. They look so happy, you never really see a sad looking penguin.

Friend: I suppose you have a point.

You: Exactly. There was this one time when I was a kid and I went to the zoo, they were feeding the penguins and this one kept tossing a fish up in the air and catching it. So goddamn cute.

Hopefully you can see where I'm going with this. As before, you can judge for yourself, but that's a basic example of a realistic conversation in my opinion. It follows a natural progression beginning with a general thought: I love penguins. The next point is that you love them because they're playful. And the next is an example of a time you saw a penguin being playful, a supporting detail if you will. 

It seems overly basic when I spell it out like that, but if you're having trouble organizing your thoughts on the fly, maybe a visual like the inverted pyramid is what you need. Anyway, I don't know if you'll find any of that useful, but I saw this question and this is what came to mind. The key is to start with the big picture, leaving room for people to ask follow up questions. If you can get them asking questions, they'll have invested something in the conversation. And that is one of the most important parts of being a memorable, interesting person (and writing a memorable, interesting news article!). Just my two cents.

text:
I can totally relate.  And especially understand the comment about wanting to be a good role model for your daughter.  My mother and I share a lot of the same weaknesses when it comes to forming and maintaining friendships, and I feel like I've inherited a lot of the same weaknesses and insecurities.  This makes me think of one of my favorite films Odd Girl Out, where the mother hid her friendless past because she wanted her daughter to be popular.  Probably because she had that same fear of not wanting that to carry over to her daughter.

I don't know if I'm one to give advice since I have the same issues.  The friends I attract most of the time are just not on my level in life.  Have no education, no ambition, etc.  The ones I want to be friends with that are smiley and social and intelligent, even though on my level in many ways, seem out of my league for whatever reason.  I have severe social phobia and anxiety and am a bit of a hermit...all handicaps that work greatly against the easy to say hard to do advice of "just get out there and meet people, it'll happen!"

So about all I can say I think is just stick with hobbies and activities that make you happy where you are truly comfortable being yourself, and try to manage expectations about the kind of people you will meet (age, gender, etc.).  That way you're less likely to feel like you're wasted your time if you didn't meet anyone, because you'll have been doing something you enjoy anyway, if that makes sense.

text:
My childhood best friend (3rd grade through senior year) 100% ghosted after confessing to the life she‚Äôd actually been living.
My parents called her their adopted daughter, her mom called me the same. She went on our family vacations - which was NOT a normal thing in my family. I can‚Äôt place enough emphasis on that. My parents neither could afford an extra body nor wanted the responsibility/discomfort. But she had become FAMILY. From 8th grade to junior year, I knew she was experimenting with things that I wouldn‚Äôt take part of. I knew she was more comfortable with boys than I was- by far. But I had no clue just how far she‚Äôd gone, until she admitted everything to me. We were going to bed, talking about the fun we planned to have that summer. She slipped and said ‚ÄòI‚Äôm going to have so much sex this summer!‚Äô It wasn‚Äôt a joke. It wasn‚Äôt funny, either. She was not being responsible in any sense of the word. That was one of the last times we ever spoke. I couldn‚Äôt understand why for the life of me- I hadn‚Äôt berated or judged her. I only asked her to be careful and think about what‚Äôs best for her both short and long term. Now, I was no angel. Please don‚Äôt get me wrong. But I had boundaries that I stuck to. 
Fast forward 2 years. I run into her mom. She was working seasonally beside my permanent job. I was happy to see her but didn‚Äôt get the same reaction. She informed that she well knew what influence *I* had on her daughter, and what it had done to her. Told me that she moved to get away from the ‚Äòbad‚Äô people in her life- insinuating me and a boy she had admitted to sleeping with and smoking crack with (I‚Äôd never met him, still to this day -more than 12 years later- I‚Äôve never smoked crack). I explained that I literally had NO CLUE what she was talking about and that frankly, if anything, she was a ‚Äòbad influence‚Äô on me. That I‚Äôd had nothing to do with any of the shenanigans she‚Äôd gotten herself into over the years. 
12 years later, all of her sisters seemingly still believe this crap. IT BROKE ME. It didn‚Äôt just break my heart, it broke ME. I had never been so confused, so mistaken, never been the ‚Äòfall guy‚Äô to this degree. We still haven‚Äôt spoken. I still think of her often. I still wonder WTF she would blame ME of all people. I still love her. 
I can honestly say this singular experience has burdened every relationship I‚Äôve had since. I can‚Äôt fully trust, in any sense of the word.

text:
I am not the best at social situations but that is more for me not caring to follow the *"rules"* than not knowing them, even if it did take me a long time to learn them. You did what you are supposed to do with that, you were polite and asked if something was wrong, if anything, they were the rude one for not explaining why they were acting like that. Me, though I tend to outright ask "what's wrong with my \_\_\_\_\_\_" whatever I think they are noticing. It's never the same thing even if it's two people together they can be deciding two different things are wrong about me or what I am wearing. I've had a group of older ladies comment on four separate things wrong with my appearance at the nursing home I was visiting then looked surprised at each other that they didn't agree on what was wrong with me.  It took me turning to people I trust to learn that almost everyone has that internal this is allowed this is not allowed thing and some feel they can enforce their views on others.

It's a personal opinion that they are expressing and are deciding to judge others based on that personal preference. It could have been something as simple as them not thinking those boots went with what you were wearing or as complex as your features/hairstyle/accessories didn't match your clothes.

I have a more rocker style with touches of gothic pieces (Hot Topic has been a go to since I was in high school) and calling out people has gotten lots of responses. I had one really rude old man comment that someone like me didn't belong in *his neighborhood* when I was house/puppy sitting for a relative. Found out later he thought I was gay because only a gay female would have hair that short(it was a pixie cut) in his opinion though he didn't use nice words to explain it. That somehow my doc martens somehow proved I was gay as well that *real woman* didn't wear boots like that. The least I could have done was pretend like I fit in and not expose people to all of that was his complaint to my cousin. I didn't even know his name until after that day and my family only knew him by the classic car he drove but he decided things about me and that he could call me out for things even though I was a complete stranger. 

If it had been my cousin who made a comment about my hair or shoes I might have put some weight in it but some random person I don't even know the name of commenting they are not important to me so their opinion of me is not important. It took me a really long time to get to that point and I hope you get to that point too because that's all you can do with something like this.

text: First and foremost, address the anxiety. how? exposure. When you get triggered, you have to learn to get still and sit with the feeling until it dissipates, by sitting with the feeling, I mean, being present with the sensations in your body (tightness in your chest or belly). Second, when it comes to social skills, the more you go out and practice the better you get. Also try not to go alone to social events. Bring someone you're comfortable with and you will be less inhibited. Wear clothes/makeup/anything that makes you feel pretty/handsome. Acknowledge that most people are self-conscious and they're focused on their own shortcomings. They will not see whatever you're worried they will see, they don't care that much. And if you plan to change yourself to fit in, don't. Be brave and advertise yourself for who you are, and thus you will end up with a crowd that "gets" you. Question whatever you think is the worst that can happen, you will be surprised to see it's not that bad. Think of the things you don't like about yourself and then try to look for these particular "defects" in people you admire and you'll see that it's actually not a problem. =))))

text:
Do this.

Take a good look at yourself in the mirror and ask yourself, "Who am I?"

You and you alone get to decide who you are.  But you have relinquished your right to decide to your past.  You're allowing your past to decide who you are.  You're allowing all the stupid kids from school to decide who you are.  You're allowing everyone else to decide who you are.  And this will continue to happen until YOU decide who you are.

Once you figure who you are, then you need to decide who you want to become.

Only when you make decisions to change can you actually change.  Once you've decided to change, then  you need to plan how you're going to change.  A new hair cut.  A different wardrobe.  Lose/gain weight.  Contacts vs. glasses.  Etc.

It'll be hard, challenging, and people will continuously try to stick you back into the role they remember about you.  Don't let them.  Don't try to prove anything to them.  Don't seek their approvals.  The only person that has to approve of you is you.

text:
So, before I begin, I'm a college student working part-time at the Apple Store.
Personally, I really enjoy my job. However, one of my coworkers sees it as "just a job" and is never in too great of a mood. So, sometimes I find it hard to talk to him.

Anyways, during my shift today, I saw him looking unhappy and stand-offish, as always, and decide to say hi to him. In an effort to lighten his mood I ask, "you're graduating from college, soon, right? Must be real exciting."

He says, "I'm a bit nervous, to be honest. I still need to get a real job, though."

I put on my best smile and say, "But, you can work here full-time maybe, you know? Work your way up to Apple corporate."

Here's what I was trying to do: listening to my coworker made me think he needed some reassurance things were going to be okay. I tried to accomplish this by reminding him he has a job now and could try for a higher position once he has a college degree. I understand his situation so I tried to help him look on the bright side, and replied in a way that could keep the conversation going.

He responds, "Dude, we've talked about this before. You still don't get it." So, naturally, I let him be. If he didn't want to have a conversation, then I wasn't going to force it.

A few weeks prior we had a similar conversation in which he also acted like a complete cunt.

So, lesson is: If you want people to warm up to you, empathize with them, and understand that they might not share the same worldview that you have. No one wants to join your self-pity party. Be appreciative towards anyone who is trying to help.

text: Try and remember that the feelings you are having are probably being shared by most people at the bar or anywhere for that matter. Remember that your brain can start having a discussion with itself as it usually does and create a conflict with itself in order to find a solution to an imaginary problem. The brain will always try to keep itself safe, so think about what that means: You go out , which is a little out your comfort zone, so your brain starts thinking of ways to make you uncomfortable enough to make you want to leave or not go out in the first place. With you, and forgive me for assuming, it seems like your brain makes you feel like an outsider, WHICH YOU ARE NOT!. Try next time to see what it is your brain is doing and recognize it as nothing more than a safety mechanism brought on by millions of years of evolution to keep you safe. Identify when this starts to happen, shine a light on it and move through it. The more you do it, the less it will happen. And please remember that you are just as connected to everyone as anyone you see is, if that makes sense.

text:
I hesitate to post in this subreddit ever because frankly I really can't relate.  But I'll say this:

>There, I always had the highest marks and graduated from high school with an overall average of 98.4%. This, however, meant that i was the kid that got picked on automatically and people distanced themselves from me so that they wouldn't be associated with the nerd. This isolated me and turned me into a social outcast with no social skills.

This is bullshit.  You got great grades and were focused on school, but people don't actually pick on and isolate kids because they are intelligent. 

I see that stuff all the time on this subreddit...and elsewhere.  This is an attribution problem.  Your intelligence and inability to socialize are mutually exclusive.  I know this because some of the brightest kids in my high school went on to great colleges and continued to be brilliant, and guess what? They had a great social life too.

If there weren't big ramifications to this flawed thinking, I could leave it alone, but I think you handicap yourself by failing to identify the actual problem.  I can't say what the actual problem is, I don't know you, but passing it off onto the fact that you care about and are good at school is just bullshit.  

I'm sorry for your situation. I can't relate. But take some personal responsibility for the situation. It's honestly the only way you're EVER going to turn it around.

text:
> You're saying everyone is entitled to an education in academic pursuits

Society voted to create a system of public education, because universal education was seen as a social good to lift society out of poverty. The people involved in the system are *employees of the state*. It is their *job* to educate and they are *paid* for it.

>  no one is entitled to an education is social pursuits

I didn't say that. I said that society has not decided to create an institution for this. No one is paid to ensure you're socially well adjusted. Instead, you are expecting these services *for free* from others who otherwise have no obligation towards you.

> You're imposing a system the selects for innate social skills over 
> academic prowess.

I'm not imposing any system. I'm asking that you not impose on others for understanding of your social foibles, when they weren't paid to give you understanding. There are plenty of people *you* can pay, however!

text:
You can learn to be funny, it's just a lot more complicated and nuanced than anyone lets on. Theres like 8 forms of comedy or something, idk it's not an area I know much about. Some people go to comedic school. And on top of that it's all based in social interaction, so having good social skills is almost a prerequisite to be funny. On top of that, comedy is what other people find funny, so you have to know your audience. Doesnt matter what you find funny, because that's not making other people laugh. 

In general I think part of the problem is that you are underestimating the effort involved in performing any task because you aren't used to it. Guitar practice isn't fun, playing guitar is. Many hobbies take a level of proficiency before they can be "enjoyed". 

When I'm trying to teach myself piano, it's real easy for me to look listen to some bach or Mozart and get discouraged because I can barely play basic pieces. It took me half a year to get there AND I can already read some music and have all the basic skills necessary to read and comprehend musical notation because I took 8 years of band in highschool as a trumpet player. 

Most of my hobbies that I'm REALLY good at have years of relevant experience from my youth. Honestly, a good chunk, that's why I enjoy them. Distance running sucks, but I miss my highschool cross country team and the team comradery so I seek out team sports and team based hobbies.

Hobbies won't stick if you're not doing them for you either and it sounds like you're using them as an extension to get something else. I used to use guitar because I wanted to be a rockstar and perform on stage. I still want to, but I can't do that if I'm not good at guitar. The problem is, if I don't enjoy the act of learning to play and the instrument itself, I can't have the end goal. If the end goal is all I want, I get no reward for my daily effort, I won't play guitar.

You have no reason to stick with your hobbies because they aren't what you want, you aren't getting any enjoyment from them. Honestly, for most people, you don't need interesting hobbies, I never talk to my coworkers cause they're always going on about some TV show I've never seen and have no desire to. 

Another problem I've faced in the past was that when I was actively searching for a relationship, I focused my social skills too much on dating and that I was LOOKING to meet a person I had already defined in at least one way; a woman that I'm physically attracted to. How many social connections I could have made that might have led me directly to that woman if I wasn't so blind as to be looking for a rose in a field of wildflowers?

I don't have a good solution for you on that note because some of it's really personal. No one can tell you how to find another person interesting. There is probably a magic formula and you'll get a few of those tips and you can find textbooks on being a conversationalist and that'll get you pretty far. But you have to find that thing that make other people interesting to you. Same thing for all things that involve effort

If you can't find a personal reason to enjoy the effort involved in something, then it's always going to be a miserable experience no matter what you do.

Edit: I'm gonna just throw a tl;dr summary of my ramblings. You want something that you can't get without something else, but you can't find a way to enjoy the other things that you feel you need to do to get what you want so you aren't improving because you aren't putting any real effort towards those things. You can't put effort towards something you don't enjoy without a reward (unless it's for survival, but different topic). We work because we're paid or we wouldn't do that bullshit. You have to find a reason to enjoy what you are doing if you want to be motivated to keep doing it. And that motivation is internal. I enjoy the effort and difficulty and the feeling of accomplishment of learning new skills, that motivates me. It might or might not motivate you. You'll have to find your motivation and sometimes, the motivaters are garbage and need changed (i.e. finding a girlfriend, or as I like to call it HAPPINESS IN ANOTHER PERSON, a terrible motivator, even worse since it's about something you don't have in this example. Also not to be confused with happiness OF another person which is a place where narcissists and people with obsessive tendencies can get mixed up in particular.).

stance_markers: ["Stop eating bullshit", "When your mouth and body feel gross, you feel gross, because you are", "Get the fuck over it", "Just do it", "it needs to be done", "Fuck those people", "This one is tough, but it's easy too", "You're going to do this a lot in life. Get used to it"]
text:
All of those things are secondary goals to improving yourself.

This seems like a lot, and it is, but it's not. It's work on one of these things at a time. Once a day, once a week, once a month. Who cares? Just do that and eventually you'll get there. I suggest going in order at least to begin with, but I think this floats together well. 

First, the easiest thing, improve your hygiene. Brush your teeth every day, make sure your skin is healthy and clean, finger nails are clean, and your hair is nice. When your mouth and body feel gross, you feel gross, because you are.

Second, your diet. Stop eating bullshit. Not all at once. A) cut out is soda. Want a soda? Chug a glass of water. Thirsty for juice or milk? Chug water first. B) avoid carb heavy food like pasta and breads. You can eat them, but the are NOT your friend at all. Always make yourself vegetables, and eat them all before you eat any other part of your food. C) If B doesn't apply, change it up. D) don't eat fast food or pizza. This helps keep your mouth and skin healthy and clean.

Third, exercise. You can lift weights, you can do cardio, you can do a martial art, swim, bike, climb. Do any of it. Just do it. And when you do keep a log of what you're doing and get a routine going. Give yourself incentives for following the routine. Have you gone to the gym for two weeks and not missed a day of your schedule (MWF split let's say), eat some of that shitty fast food you cut out in your diet.

Fourth, spend time on your hobbies. Don't have any? Find some. Need help finding hobbies? Google it. Find out what they entail. You can also start by determining what you already own that relates towards some single hobby. Don't blow $200 trying rout a hobby. Spend $20 on something, like painting supplies and use them until they're gone or broken.

Fifth, dress your best. All the time. This follows the clean mouth and body. You look good, you feel good. Get clothes that YOU like that fit you. Since you should be dieting and exercising, don't blow a ton of money on clothes (like hobbies) all at once. Shop at thrift stores, don't buy stuff brand new, because your body is going to be changing, and if you spend $100 on clothes, you're going to get discouraged to improve your aesthetics (both improving your body and improving your style). You don't want that. Don't know what styles you like or want to pursue? Google it. Instagram, YouTube, pinterst, GQ, etc. There's so much out there. Go to stores and observe people.

Six, talk to people. Standing in line at the grocery store? Ask the cashier how their day is going? Force them into a conversation because you need to practice and while it's not their job, it is right now. This is one of the best places. Be nice, encouraging, positive, and friendly.

Seven, improve your outlook. Be positive about things. Had a shitty day? Get the fuck over it. So did everyone else, and no one cares about their day, and no one cares about yours? Had a 15 hour work day? That sucks, but at some point something good happened, focus on that. Or if it didn't, find a new job or environment to work in.

Eight, remove toxic people. This one is tough, but it's easy too. Especially when you're improving yourself. You can find toxic people quick in transition phases. People will give you shit about you doing different things, those people are toxic (in general). The distinction needs to be made between constructive criticism and putting you down. People may be voicing concerns about changing because they care about YOU or they may just be talking shit bc they're projecting their insecurities outwards. Fuck those people. You know the people in your life the best, so you need to decide that. This might be your best friend, or simply a coworker, but it needs to be done.

Nine, learn to read people. This one is tough but it's essential for the previous and also subsequently dealing with new people. You can learn a lot about someone by reading them. Are they interested in speaking with you, are they mad at you or is there something going on in their life that is bigger than you and you're just inconvenient at the moment, etc. You can do this while practicing talking to people and observing people (while looking for new clothes for instance) which is helpful.

Ten, fail. You're going to do this a lot in life. Get used to it. Strive to fail. Set goals that you know are achievable but not a big deal and fail at them. Failure is rejection. Failure is being tired. Failure is pushing yourself as hard as you can, and not making it. Then accept it. All this means is that you can improve. You have a clear definition of what a better you can be.


I don't have time to finish this, was planning on adding examples. I will do that if there's interest.

Either way, good luck brother.

text:
These guys sound like they're still in highschool. I've had friends like this. Actually, it sounds almost spot on to all my highschool friends. I was the only one who didn't enjoy drinking, preferred to save and spend my money on experiences and travel instead of getting wasted every weekend.

The way they talk to you, is the way they think about themselves if they don't up hold their macho image; "don't be a pussy" "man up" "don't be such a bitch". Think about that... they talk to themselves like shit. The only way they'll feel better is if they're not alone in their own cesspool of degradation.

In my experience, I set up my own personal rules for life. Moral principles and things I wanted in life and if I didn't think it matched my future life, I tried to avoid it. I'm not saying you have to cut them out. You could even be the voice of reason. Tell them why you don't want to do these things. Stand up to them and call them out, even if you're the outcast of that group. You're only seen as the outcast cause it seems you want to make something of your life.

If you stand up for yourself, maybe Larry or Kevin are the scared boys they seem to be and can look up to you, even if it is in silence. I distanced myself from my highschool friends and slowly made new friends from work and sports teams. Eventually, one ended up having a breakdown and is alone, one came back and he turned his life around and now I'm standing in his wedding party, one became an alcoholic and didn't get clean for 12 years after highschool, one has no prospects, no savings, no education and chases women from the bars and gets used over and over and over again. The other one... I'm not even sure if he's above ground tbh.

My life... I was depressed. Hopeless being around people who felt like me inside. I was 340lbs and played WoW 16 hours a day. I had enough. I put my education to use, got a job, lost 140lbs, traveled the world, started mentoring around my city and fostered healthier relationships. We're all 33 now and out of the 5 of us, 2 of us tried to make our lives better. The other 3, still struggling, still doing the same shit.

Be who you want to be. Be who you would look up to and others will follow.

Ohhhhh this one is a tough one my dude. First, you're completely fine. Try to look at yourself in a different perspective. Why are you feeling this way? Why should you express emotion you don't want to express? Why be happy when you don't wanna be happy? Why feel remorse when you don't give a f?
