People love sharing emotions with others and that's a mean to connect with others and when that happens, brain let's them know that they are socially excepted and they are doing good. It's our instinct and brain does that stuff which isn't bad, it's necessary.

Now the problem is how do I genuinely become happy or sad or hyped? Maybe something in life is bugging you? Is life bringing you down? Your social circle is fill of toxic people? Your focus is being carried away by something and you focus on that everytime? I don't know which one it is for you so you have to decide. And if it is any of them I listed, go to your room, lock the doors, and get to learn yourself. Who am I? Why do I think that way? Why is this bringing me down? Either solve that thing or get rid of that thing. Maybe you need to find a purpose in life? Maybe you need to stop expecting s lot from people or expecting a lot from yourself? Maybe it's okay being relaxed and loose and not so focused or self aware. Actually being self aware is an amazing thing but sometimes you just gotta let it go.

Sorry I went off track a bit. I was thinking about those moments where I was monotone and it was always because something bothered me so that's my .02 dollars. Hope it helped.

text:
I can tell you one thing already;

You are still relatively young and you will definitely make one or more friends until your death, although I would advise you not to talk about your eventual life like that.

I know your current situation to the extent that you feel very lonely and empty right now and don't know whether you really need friends or should look for friends or whether you need a relationship.

In your message you talk about a lot of small problems and it is difficult to go into everything individually but i try my best  


1. &#x200B;

It's your life and of course you have to decide for yourself if you want to have friends. We can't dictate anything to you. But having one or more friends will help you in every point of view. You can go out with friends and do something, you can meet them, play games or travel with them. You can talk to them, talk about such problems/thoughts and get their opinion. you can do so much

Of course there will also be arguments, a possible break or you might get injured, but that's all human.

2

Having a relationship can also improve/beautify your life in many ways. You have someone you trust very strongly, who loves you as you know it from films/series/books etc. Hugs or sex will give you a lot of feelings of happiness/moments that you probably haven't really known before or can imagine.

Of course, problems can also arise here, but they are human again.

So in short:

Having friends or having a girlfriend has so many advantages and it improves your life in every aspect.

The other problem you indirectly posed is how to get there.

For that I can recommend you the posts in the pinned post on the Reddit server or you can read my older messages on other posts that (almost) all had the same problem as one should/can friends.

text:
>1) because he‚Äôs currently a student. Nothing should matter more than studies. His time should be fully dedicated to his studies. Maybe there should be some room for relaxation, but not too much time should be spent on relaxation. Relationships will take too much time off his study time.

I suppose that's something well have to agree to disagree on. His studies should be his focus, no doubt about that. But they shouldn't occupy all of his time. That's for two main purposes, in my mind. Firstly, doing nothing but studying and a *bit* of relaxation for 4 years will drive you insane. Besides that, it could lead to an immense amount of stress that could leave to harsh health problems. I mean, I'm speaking from experience. I'm in uni, with a double major and a minor plus research plus extracurriculars (clubs and such) plus a decent social life. I've tried the whole "doing nothing but studying" schtick. It was awful and completely unsustainable. Which brings me to my second point: there's no need to. You're presenting studying and a relationship as mutually exclusive, but they're not. You can have both. Maybe you're GPA will drop 0.2 points, but that's nothing in the grand scheme of things. Plus you'll be healthier with an outlet for stress. 

2) humans crave intimacy because nature wants humans to mate. The second you ejaculate, boom, desire for intimacy is now gone. Why do you think you feel weird and slightly disgusted after you masturbated? That‚Äôs right. That‚Äôs just nature trying to drive you to reproduce. That‚Äôs why you have the desire for intimacy in the first place. Once you ejaculate, you have basically tricked nature into thinking that you have successfully mated. And as for the desire for connections? That can be achieved with Male friends. It doesn‚Äôt have to be female

I'm not a psychologist, so I'm not going to try to disprove any of the points you make here about it (although I doubt that you have a huge amount of psychology trying either). But anecdotally, I feel that you're wrong about most of these points. I'll address these point by point.

> humans crave intimacy because nature wants humans to mate.

I don't know enough about psychology to comment, but a citation wouldn't be unwarranted.

>The second you ejaculate, boom, desire for intimacy is now gone.

Except it's not though. Feeling horny and wanting close emotional intimacy aren't synonymous. One is a physical desire, and one is a mental, emotional one. One I crave intimacy I want to experience a close emotional bond, where I just feel comfortable with someone and they feel comfortable with me. 

>Why do you think you feel weird and slightly disgusted after you masturbated?

I don't? I feel pretty alright after masturbating. Not weird or even slightly disgusted in the least.

>That‚Äôs right. That‚Äôs just nature trying to drive you to reproduce.

Eh...I'm not a psychologist, but a citation wouldn't be unwarranted.

>That‚Äôs why you have the desire for intimacy in the first place. Once you ejaculate, you have basically tricked nature into thinking that you have successfully mated.

Not commenting on the wonky masturbation point (citation needed for it), the fact that you can have or desire close intimacy with friends that you don't want to have sex with kind of disproves your point. 

>And as for the desire for connections? That can be achieved with Male friends. It doesn‚Äôt have to be female

My point exactly.

>3) being a good partner shouldn‚Äôt be his primary concern now. 

It shouldn't, but like I said, there's no reason why you can't work toward it. There's enough hours in the day. Learning guitar or playing Overwatch aren't my primary concerns but I sure as hell find time to do them.

>4) good memories can be achieved with Male friends. Memories coming from relationships specifically is not necessary as long as good memories are formed

Yeah, but like I said. If someone wants to get into a relationship, there's not reason to ignore that desire. I mean, you're even saying that you can have time to hang out with male friends and study. Under that logic, why can't he spend some of that time working towards being more comfortable with girls? Besides, you and I both know that a romantic intimate relationship is much different than hanging out with male friends. Putting both under the umbrella of creating "good memories" is disingenuous.

>5) if I could have an awesome life where I don‚Äôt have to worry about money instead of having a life in which money flows out of my pockets like river water but I get to have a life partner , I‚Äôd rather not choose the latter.

Ok, and that's your choice. But again, it's a false dichotomy. *You can have both.*

stance_markers: ["That's only half the truth, though", "I like the old U.S. Army saying", "Part of it is", "Another part is", "You can try to tell", "but it doesn't want to", "For example", "Those are things that your instincts could theoretically figure out"]
text:
> The advice: don't pre-think social interactions, just go in and adapt. 

A military metaphor for what you are saying is that no plan survives first contact with the enemy.  That's only half the truth, though.  I like the old U.S. Army saying that Dwight Eisenhower made famous:  "Plans are useless, but planning is indispensable."  Even though unexpected events will render your plans irrelevant, the thought that goes into creating them prepares you to improvise in an intelligent and informed manner.  

> The request: how can I stop doing this?

You think because your thinking brain doesn't trust your instincts.  It tries to take over, but it isn't quick enough, so you stumble.  To fix this, you need to cultivate confidence in your instincts.  Part of it is just reminding yourself that your instincts have served you well in the past.  Another part is to ensure the right division of labor between your rational brain and your instincts.  Think of your rational brain as a corporate manager.  Right now, it's acting like a micromanager:  it doesn't trust your social intuition to do its job, so it attempts to dictate every detail so your social intuition doesn't have any leeway to screw up.  You can try to tell your rational brain to stop doing that, but it doesn't want to stand back and do nothing.  It needs a job to do, and it has a job to do: like a good manager, it should make sure your social intuition has all the support it needs to work effectively.  Then it can get out of the way and trust your intuition to get the job done.  

The support your rational brain can provide is planning.  Your rational brain can survey the situation, review relevant information, and anticipate different scenarios.  Everything your rational brain thinks about will prime your instincts to respond appropriately.  For example, if you're going to talk to people you know a little bit but not well, you might review basic information about them that will affect your choice of banter:   so-and-so has cancer, so don't compliment her on how much weight she has lost; another person's daughter won a school prize, so you should congratulate them; another person is a Trump supporter but has a great sense of humor about politics, so it's safe to joke with him about it.  Those are things that your instincts could theoretically figure out on the fly, but you can ease the burden a little bit by reviewing them ahead of time.  Then you'll have more confidence, and your rational mind will be a little calmer, because it will know that it has done what it can to ensure your success.

Personally, I wouldn't start a conversation with these because I wouldn't want someone to start a conversation with me using any of these examples. 

If you are introducing yourself to someone you haven't met, casual questions are a much better bet in terms of actually engaging with someone. After a few moments of *casual* conversation, you can both sort of gauge the interest in/of each other - maybe you want to continue talking to them (in which case, the examples above *would* come in handy), and maybe you don't (Well it's been great meeting you! I'm gonna go do that thing...)

If you just walk up to someone and open with these deep questions, it's likely they don't really want to answer (because they're at a party with people they know they like, and one of the people who they don't know just asked them a soul-searching question) or will just answer quickly and move along because that's a pretty awkward situation.

Just my opinion.

stance_markers: ["I don't think", "Life is complex", "How good can advice be if", "a better way to look at it would be", "you need to know what values you hold", "Is there a way to compromise", "naturally so, because how *could* you"]
text:
First of all, I don't think there's any life advice in the form of just a short imperative ‚Äî Be yourself! Be kind! Don't listen to what others say about you! Treat others as you'd like to be treated yourself! Etc. ‚Äî that's actually meaningful on its own. Life is complex, people are complex, society is complex, cultures are complex. 
If you want good advice, you'll have to look deeper than that, which is exactly what you're doing here. You're wondering how to apply all that conflicting advice to your own life, yet find you can't always follow it  And naturally so, because how *could* you always be yourself if there are so many situations where that would either be detrimental to yourself or to others you care about? How *could* you love yourself unconditionally when there are aspects about you that don't align with the kind of person you want to be?

As a general rule: How good can advice be if following it would make you become a person you'd despise? If giving in to your urge to punch someone means stooping to the level of an animal, it can't be the right option, if that's not what you want to be. Is there a way to compromise, i.e. can you express yourself in a way that you don't have to do things that don't align with your own set of values? 

You're not your urges. You're not the first thought that pops into your head. If you want to love yourself, yet keep improving, remember that your choice not to punch the guy ‚Äî for you know it'd be wrong ‚Äî is just as much if not more a part of you as is your urge to do it, for you *chose* not to do it. Those urges may be a part of you, but you don't need to love *every aspect* of yourself in order to love yourself. Your wish for improvement is a legitimate part of you, not some sort of betrayal for your self-love.

So, a better way to look at it would be to ask: What's the point in this specific piece of advice? How does it help you live your best life? And for that, you need to know what values you hold and how important they are to you.

text:
I know EXACTLY what you mean! I have the same problem with a lot people, especially my family. My Mother felt that being direct was low-class. For example: if you're offered something to eat/ drink that you don't like, you're to say " No thank you, I don't care for any. " because it could be thought that you just don't want any. When I asked her why I couldn't just say I don't like it, she told me that it just wasn't done. You weren't allowed to do that if you were a person of 'refinement'. ( rolling my eyes and shaking my head)

I've thought about this very subject and I came to the conclusion that my way of thinking was like being visually impaired; my family is like a hearing impaired person who can only understand sign language. When I hear someone near me, I vocalize. I can't see so I don't realize that they are signing to me. They don't realize that I can't see so they keep signing more and I keep vocalizing louder, and so it goes.

For the record: neither way of communicating is 'right' or 'wrong', it's just different. Somehow or another, there has to be a way for both parties to communicate and be heard.And it isn't going to happen if we keep doing what we're doing and taking the attitude that the other person's way of communicating is 'wrong' and that the the one who's 'wrong' needs to learn the 'right' way.

Again for the record: I expect the program to show me the scenes that are important to the understanding of the story. I've not seen the program, but I agree with the OP of this subject.

text:
Have you ever actually studied fighting?  Perhaps boxing?  "Learn to take a punch (and keep going)" is one of the fundamentals, and the only way to do that is to get punched, repeatedly.  Yeah, it sucks, but no matter how good you are at dodging or avoidance, sometimes it's unavoidable.  A boxer who gets KO'ed after one punch isn't a good boxer.  Have you done any strenuous exercise, like long-distance running or weight-lifting?  I can tell you that that shit hurts and is strenuous; sometimes you *do* just have to tough your way through it. Learn from the experience, and using that wisdom, lessen the aches.  With experience, you *do* get better at handling missteps.  

Not everything that hurts you should be viewed as an antagonistic combat sport, because most people aren't out to actively hurt you (and those who are should *absolutely* be avoided).  

Asking someone out and getting rejected *is* practice for future encounters.  We all suffer in life, and it's your choice to either learn from it or not.  Hiding in the basement is still a form of suffering, you know.

text:
Happy birthday!!!

If I were you, I would **shift the frame of reference**. 

Meaning that: instead of caring too much if people care about my birthday, I would care less about what other people think of me and more about what I think about myself.

Things like: Another year has passed for me: 

* How I improved myself? 
* Is my health better or worse than last year? 
* Are my finances better or worse? 
* Are my relationships better or worse?

You see, our minds can focus on very few things at any given moment so if you focus on what matters, you don't have to spend mental energy on things that don't matter (again this is just my opinion but honestly, it couldn't matter less to me if people even know I have a birthday).

The paradox of that is that if you do just that, you will increase your worth in society as a healthier, richer, happier person. **And more people will start being attracted to you**. People that matter, people that want the best for you and will contribute to your well-being for many more happy birthdays :)

My best from [Social Dynamics Academy](https://socialdynamicsacademy.com/)

text:
Like everyone said, the age gap is negligible. I also come from a military background, entering college at 24.

IMO college is one of the last environments that provides daily opportunities that encourage social interaction. Although it can seem like there is social pressure, remember that the population of the school means you can be as memorable or unmemorable as YOU want.  There are 25k people all carving out their individual lives. No, they don't all hate you. No, they aren't ignoring you. 

I'm not sure what you want. Do you want to be more social? Do you want more friends? Or do you want general social tips? In general, everyone is doing their own thing. Its entirely up to you on being social, and conversely nonsocial. 

The best thing about college social interactions is there are MANY default conversation starters at your disposal. For example: "Man, totally don't feel like being here today." "Did you do the homework?" "How do you feel about this test?" "Do you mind comparing homework." "I couldn't figure out number X, do you mind explaining it to me." "Hi, my name is X. I'm having a lot of problems in here. You want to join a study group I'm helping organize?"

The possibilities interacting before and after class are literally endless. You share one thing automatically with every student, that you are in college. Its like going on a date. You can be friendly asking simple, normal questions. What is your major? What job would you like after college? What do you do for fun? Hell, make it a point to introduce yourself to your neighbor in class, every time. You'll start running into people in other classes you share. You'll run into them at the coffee shop or grocery store. Who knows, you may have similar majors and the friendship can be mutually beneficial as you help each other in diff classes. After your first year, you'll start to recognize the same faces. These people are probably in your major, and most likely your graduating class. Befriending the more responsible students among them can be invaluable. I try to make a friend in every class. Even if its not to hang out, i may miss a day and ask them to send a pic of their notes. Most people are more than willing to exchange numbers because it always helps to have a friend to help on coursework.

Join a club. There are tons and tons of different clubs. Ethnic groups (like asian student association). Societies for your major (like society of mechanical engineers). Fraternities. These are literally clubs for people of similar interests/backgrounds to hang out among peers that have similar interests. People go to the events EXPECTING to meet new people. Exchange numbers. Suggest meeting up to hang out. The easiest way to hang out with a girl is to ask if she wants to study. I mean the opportunities are there, you just have to recognize them. 

And finally, if you find certain people are turned off or don't want to hang out, or a girl rejects you, or they don't want to be your friend, Don't sweat it. Seriously, who gives a fuck. There will be 24,999 other students that may be interested. At least 10,000 other girls. Literally. Think about that.  They dont spend their free time thinking about how much they hate you, so don't waste your time worrying about it. Go to class, make friends, hang out, have fun, have sex, take risks. Live, laugh, and love. Then have some more sex.

stance_justification: The writer presents their social practices as definitive rules without acknowledging alternative approaches or uncertainty. They use directive language ('fucking go', 'Be kind to yourself') and present their strategies as universally correct rather than personal preferences that work for them. There's no engagement with potential counterarguments or acknowledgment that different social styles might work for different people.
stance_markers: ["I always follow up", "fucking go and go at the understood time", "Nobody wants to", "The main thing I can recommend", "Be kind to yourself", "be the kind of friend you want to have"]
text:
I always follow up on plans even if I'm not planning on going. Whenever possible I let people have a for-sure answer whether we're doing something at a particular time/day/place. Nobody wants to keep a big question mark on their calendar hoping you make up your mind. If you say you're going, fucking go and go at the understood time.

I don't leave people on read if I have time to respond and I'm in anything above a truly bad headspace. It's about 50-50 on initiating conversations and plans but that wasn't always the case. I spent a lot of time initiating and following through on plans, so people are happy to invite me to parties and plans because I'm actually fun, I actually care, and I actually show up. 

At parties, I have a pretty good sense of who's there and doesn't want to be, who's there to get wasted, and who's looking to have a decent conversation and a lot of fun. I stick around the people who are there to have fun or at least open to it. I try to include everyone as much as possible but I'm not going to pry my way into someone's bubble who doesn't want to join the party. This is doubly true for people who've very clearly decided before arriving that they aren't going to enjoy themselves. 

The main thing I can recommend is practice and persistence until it becomes natural. Be kind to yourself in your choice of friends and be the kind of friend you want to have and model the kind of relationships you want to have.

stance_justification: The writer provides reasoned judgments while acknowledging uncertainty and complexity. They qualify claims with phrases like 'I think' and 'Maybe if you were like 50' showing calibrated confidence. They engage with the reader's perspective substantively, offering multiple concrete suggestions while acknowledging personal limitations ('That's my only preface').
stance_markers: ["I think proves", "Maybe if you were", "That's what's realistic", "You may think", "I don't feel like", "I bet you'll", "In so many ways", "I know for a fact now"]
text:
Hope you don‚Äôt mind but I saw you removed a previous post and just wanted to copy my thoughts over. 

The fact that you‚Äôre reaching out here I think proves you have some spark in you still, which is good to hear. I know deep loneliness. That‚Äôs my only preface. You have to break out of this perspective that you‚Äôre stuck in this situation, that nothing you can do will change it, and that it is anyone‚Äôs responsibility but yours to do so. Even if it feels like a lie. Not to diminish your efforts but you simply have not ‚Äúfailed‚Äù enough in your young life to know for sure you‚Äôve seen all that‚Äôs out there for you and that you should be done. If you did, you‚Äôd have learned more or found a new passion or at least stumbled into a friend group of people that are decent enough to hang around. Maybe if you were like 50 and this was still the case then I‚Äôd have less to say, but even then there‚Äôs always another card to play. That‚Äôs what‚Äôs realistic.

Change up your environment. Do you travel? Can you move to a more exciting town? Get a roommate or two in a nicer place? You may think what‚Äôs the point if you‚Äôre going alone but the fact that you‚Äôre providing an experience to yourself can give you that fullness to life that makes people interested in talking to you. Could you volunteer at an old folks home? Maybe provide that comfort and support to other lonely people. Maybe they‚Äôd have some wisdom of their own. I don‚Äôt feel like looks really matter in terms of meeting people, so do your best to ignore the negative thoughts you have about yourself. It‚Äôs a self fulfilling prophecy that‚Äôs up to you to change.

Social skills are simply a muscle to be trained like anything else. Start small. One trick I learned that I do all the time now is when I‚Äôm at the cashier stand and there‚Äôs that quiet time during the transaction, I ask ‚Äúhow‚Äôs your day going?‚Äù It always gets a nice response. Do that for a month and I bet you‚Äôll feel a little bit stronger with talking to people. Stumble through and treat yourself with grace. Your upbringing has no baring on today, on tomorrow. That‚Äôs on you now. And you can do this. Because we all can do this. You‚Äôre not especially worse than us or especially better than us.

I‚Äôm 35. In so many ways, my 30‚Äôs have been a revelation. I visited another country for the first time when I was 30! Canada, on my own, and it was amazing! Just crossing the border for the first time felt like scratching the crust layer off my life and everything felt fresh and new. I‚Äôve also just in general learned so much about who I am and what I do and do not want in life and a lot of that has been while alone, and living alone. It‚Äôs so tough sometimes, but there‚Äôs just so much out there to discover and I know for a fact now the younger version of me was wrong in thinking there wasn‚Äôt. You can get better at this. You will get better at this. Just keep going.

Also there‚Äôs so much good pizza out there. In Italy they literally put fries on the thing, you have to see it.

text: You are most definitely ‚Äúallowed‚Äù to flirt, but there‚Äôs a difference between flirting and making women uncomfortable by forcing your touch when you‚Äôre hammered. Touching a leg is pretty sexualized. You flirt by chatting with them and spending time with them and reading the room to see if they‚Äôre interested before initiating touch. You clearly have your social boundaries mixed up, and I would focus on figuring that out first. It‚Äôs very likely that because you were drunk you couldn‚Äôt read the room effectively and you were totally being creepy and disregarding it. You are NOT entitled to a woman‚Äôs time, you are not entitled to flirt with a woman, you are not entitled to touch a woman. Saying everyone else is ‚Äúis allowed to flirt but you‚Äù sounds pretty damn entitled and almost as though one of the bigger reasons you‚Äôre valuing the women around you is for sex. Figure out your relationship to entitlement and how you treat women before going to parties and being creepy.

text:
If she always wants to hang out then you need to shut her down fast.

If you're really bad at confrontation, it's up to you to be honest and say that you don't really feel like it (to which she's going to question and you have to answer awkwardly), or lie and say that you got into a new hobby/met other people/you already set up a day with some chick/friends on the internet to play vidya games together/you got work to do.

Just remember that this is basically your chance to get better at confrontation, because this is a much needed life skill. Otherwise people are going to just push you around.

stance_justification: The writer demonstrates evaluativist thinking by weighing different factors and making distinctions between types of opinion changes. They provide reasoning for their judgments (distinguishing genuine learning from people-pleasing) and acknowledge complexity while still offering evaluative guidance about what's 'key.'
stance_markers: ["both ways of being are valid", "maybe you also have to think consciously about", "if you are changing opinions just because you want people to like you... that's different", "That's where you cross the line", "think about *why* you change. I think that's key"]
text:
People are not made of stone or paper and anyone who expects people to stay the same and have the same opinions and ways of being all the time are a little bit unrealistic. We are all multifaceted beings with the capacity to change and learn and focus/hone in on different parts of ourselves at different times. Some people are more "change-y" than others and both ways of being are valid.

You are right in that confidence is key. You can't control what other people think of you and you never will be able to. You need to be able to appreciate you for who you are. For me, I sometimes express an opinion, and then in another conversation I change it. How do I handle this? I just pro-actively own it. "Yeah, you know I used to think x, but now considering different factors I actually think Y is better now". Change is a part of growth and maybe you've met these friends during a time of personal growth for you.

But maybe you also have to think consciously about whether your opinions change because you genuinely are swayed or learn something new... if you are changing opinions just because you want people to like you more or you don't want to rock the boat, that's different. That's where you cross the line into being "fake" (I think the word fake is harsh though) or maybe more a "people pleaser" 

So yeah, think about *why* you change. I think that's key.

text:
Depends on what you define as a 'friend' tbh, i have a handful of really close buddies i regularly hang out with, then acquaintances that ill run into less frequently, usually friends of friends. Then throw in work friends and whatever else.

I feel like introverts are more serious with who they call a friend, where an extrovert would call anyone they talk to on a regular basis a friend.

So in that sense its really whatever you think your content with, Sure i could definitely meet more people and establish new friendships but its mentally exhausting as an introvert. Ill never understand the need to have 100's of friends super extroverted people seem to have.

text:
Questions: would you like to spend time around people  who don't appreciate you as a person? 

Wouldn't you like it better if the people around know and loved the real you?

If you answered NO and YES, then here's what to do: VULNERABILITY!!

now when I say vulnerability,  I don't mean "surrender", there's a difference,  the former is about authenticity while the latter is about loser/weakness...ect

Alright,  it's SOCIAL VULNERABILITY, it means like if you have a silly joke,say it. Don't worry about the outcome.

You got your music playlists,  play them loud,so people can see what kind of music you're into. Don't worry about outcome

The point is, whatever you think is a personal quality that defines you, that you think is important about yourself, SHOW IT TO THE WORLD,whether it's weird or not, cool or not, ...

That's when some people will like/appreciate you for the real you.

text:
Atheist here.

In my opinion it is completely fine to ask people, if they want to pray with you. If someone asked me, I would decline respectfully. I would not feel pressured in any way. I would likely wait for you to have done your prayers before eating, as a basic form of respect for you as a person, not for your faith. I might not share your belief, but I can still respect your decision to follow that belief.

But then again, I'm a strong willed person, that is not afraid to say no, I rarely feel social pressure, even if people are trying to pressure me.

stance_justification: The writer presents their advice as definitive truths without acknowledging uncertainty or alternative perspectives. They make sweeping generalizations ('People don't do this', 'No one cares about fact') and use authoritative language throughout. stance_markers: ["People don't do this", "This is impossible", "It is either...or", "no one cares about fact", "No one does either", "Arrogant means a confident person that I don't like", "you shouldn't bother with them anyway"]
text:
I will give you some of the mentality background, which is arguable more important than how.

>people might try to challenge what I've got to say 

People don't do this. The people who do are assholes who slowly end up with no friends anyway, you shouldn't bother with them anyway.

>arrogant

Arrogant means a confident person that I don't like. You can't get people to like you without other people disliking you. If you are a bit younger, you might still be in the high school mentality of trying to get everyone to like you. This is impossible. It is either some people love you and others hate you, *or*, everyone is indifferent. It is up to you to make the choice.

Now on to the how to tell stories:

Start slow, give context, be hyper descriptive, and hyper specific. Humour is about being agreeable. People will laugh when they can picture what is going on. So when you give enough context and specifics, they will laugh.

>How can I practice this sort of thing? 

Tell the same story to each group you meet.

>Do people who tell good stories think it up on the spot or plan it out? 

Not only do they practise, they have told the same story over 1000 times, editing the details to make it more funny. One of my friends is 70 years old (and very professionally successful). She still tells the stories of her first job which happened over 40 years ago. This means she has been telling them for over 40 years. That's why those stories are so good, she has been telling them since before you were born.

>If you can't properly remember what happened should you try to fill it in? 

Make it up, no one cares about fact. For example, I don't know my friends exact age, or when she exactly got that job, so I just filled in the details, notice how you didn't care. No one does either.

>Also should you only tell stories when they're relevant?

Learn how to segue and you will be fine.

text:
Happy birthday ! 

As for your post, my advice would be to stop trying to do whatever you think might help create a bond with the other person, just because you think that is what you are supposed to do. 

A bond gets created over time. For some people you might be willing to do more. To others less. You can have acquaintances which won‚Äôt be friends. And so on. 

You are young. I remember being that age and my confidence was not very good. You will get there eventually. Just do things for you, go to the bar alone, enjoy your time, and you will get surrounded by people eventually. 

Also, no shame into going to therapy. It helped me tremendously to overcome some issues. 

Cheers!

stance_justification: The writer demonstrates evaluativist reasoning by acknowledging uncertainty ('I know neither you, nor that group'), providing qualified recommendations with reasoning ('if they are literally as bad as what you say and what you've written isn't magnified'), and showing awareness of complexity and nuance. They provide evidence-based suggestions while acknowledging limitations and potential cognitive distortions.
stance_markers: ["I'm not going to tell you whether they are right or wrong", "I know neither you, nor that group", "if they are literally as bad as what you say and what you've written isn't magnified(cognitive distortion)", "there's a chance they will", "I'm tempted to add more, but too much help can interfere with growth", "those shoulds themselves are a problem"]
text:
Every human being intrinsically holds worth.  By virtue of existing. You are literally a massive coincidence just like everyone else here, none of us had to exist, but, we do.   


I'm not going to tell you whether they are right or wrong, or if you're right or wrong, I know neither you, nor that group.   
What I can tell you is - regardless of your faults, you as a lifeform intrinsically hold worth. Don't utilize this as a comeback to them, extolling your virtues and intrinsic worth, if they are literally as bad as what you say and what you've written isn't magnified(cognitive distortion), there's a chance they will find a way to turn that on its head. You don't need that right now. And they have things to fix themselves as well, because - yes, they too hold value.  


If you have the chance, visit a therapist, you need a support system and a therapist can provide at least one crucial pillar. In addition, add more 'positive' things to your life. Practice gratitude, 3 things you are grateful for, day and night, or just day in the beginning.   
The idea isn't to spit rainbow flavored raps, the idea is to build emotional resilience, gratitude helps us to do so, and also simultaneously starts allowing us to recognize and see other opportunities, and can help change our outlook on life. Find the smallest things you can be grateful for, atomic, protons/electrons, I'm not exaggerating here, believe me.   
As long as you think "yeah it IS pretty great that's a thing" then it counts for you, that's it.  
Practice cold showers at least thrice a week or daily if you can. They also aid in emotional resilience. Exercise will help as well, start by just walking/running as those are relatively simple to do without needing the whole trainer/program shebang. Essentially adding more coping methods for your life and environment, and look up classes that can teach you assertiveness in a healthy way.  


I'm tempted to add more, but too much help can interfere with growth and true independence building as well. I know things are hard, I've faced people who 'should' be better, 'should' have been more adult, but those shoulds themselves are a problem, we aren't in that world. But we can become part of the vanguard for it, by learning the things people already in that vanguard have picked up, and bettering ourselves.  


Good efforts. One day at a time. This isn't a movie. It's an ultramarathon.

But after a while, I realized", "And that's ok. Not everyone will be the right fit"]
text:
Hi OP, I wanted to reply because I completely understand where you‚Äôre coming from. Idk how you act in these situations when you hang out with these people, but you seem like you‚Äôre socially aware and not off-putting. Sometimes, it‚Äôs just about finding your people and not necessarily anything you‚Äôre doing wrong. Some people click right away and want to hang out, other times the other party just doesn‚Äôt see it. It may very well be that they do enjoy your company, but not enough for them to go out of their way to initiate. It may hurt in the moment to realize this, but this is a big world and there are people out there that will appreciate you and make time for you. 

Whether you want to continue to initiate hanging out with these people or not is up to you. There‚Äôs no right answer‚Äîif you feel like it makes you happy, keep doing it. If you feel like it‚Äôs a waste of time and that it should be a 2 way street, then it‚Äôs also perfectly fine to stop initiating. 

I‚Äôm currently working a temporary job (1 year contract) that takes a lot of my time. I spend a lot of time with the same people at work, and I‚Äôm in a new place away from family and friends, so like many people I do seek out some kind of community where I am. I had a similar situation‚Äîthere was a coworker I was trying to initiate hanging out with, inviting them to lunch, etc. Usually they were busy, which I understood. But then I knew they would hang out with other coworkers on the side. When I asked one day to hang out and grab lunch, I got a last min text inviting me to join the group. I declined because I had already made plans and it was really last minute. But the invite felt forced. Like hey I‚Äôll send you the address if you want to come. 

There is nothing inherently wrong with what this person did. But after a while, I realized it was just me asking to hang out. Even if we get along at work, she isn‚Äôt that interested in being close friends or taking the initiative. And that‚Äôs ok. Not everyone will be the right fit, but friend groups and situations change. You mentioned being in grad school, which is temporary. I had a similar situation in grad school, also felt that while I seemed to be well liked in a large group setting, no one initiated hanging out with me. I didn‚Äôt fit the culture. But life moves on and you will find your people and people who truly will make time for you.

Something is very wrong with that", "You need to continue to speak your mind", "You should also focus more on your future", "trust me... it will show on the outside because it will be genuine", "people like you deserve better", "you absolutely cannot be nervous, afraid or unsure of yourself", "You have to be ready for whatever", "you will encounter these type of people long after high school is over", "I've got a feeling great things are in store for you"]
text:
Ok that's what I thought initially. Your friends almost sound like they operate on a "gang" dynamic, in that, once someone leaves or is banned from the group they become the enemy or a target for being picked on and bullied... and THIS is not what friends do! Something is very wrong with that, and it also sounds like these individuals could either be any combination of jocks, spoiled-ass rich kids or "Boyz from the Hood." On that note... let me tell you a little story about me.

I know middle school and even high school can be difficult, but I also recall that I had solved these problems by the time I became a senior in high school be carefully picking my friends and associates. My dear young friend let me tell you something... I am Black and I went to an all Black school in Jacksonville, FL many years ago and before they finally integrated the students and teachers. This school had students that came from three different housing projects and a few low-income areas on the westside of town. I had to fight my way through middle school just to keep my damn lunch money and stand up for myself when one of the high school bullies decided to try and punk me. I was that Black kid who just didn't fit it with a lot of kids because I did not care for all the ghetto crap or fighting. I also spoke a little differently in terms of my vernacular which attracted problems at times. LOL I liked a wide variety of music including R&B, soul, pop, rock and contemporary stuff which also translated to a variety of races on behalf of the artists that performed all of this music. I even chose a pop song to sing in my high school play, but I typically sang soul music on the talent shows. I can switch genres back and forth to this very day and think nothing of it. (I think it's very safe to say that most Black people are not into that.) I was an only child from a broken home being raised by a great-grandmother, and I was kind of different in my manner for reasons I was yet to fully understand until I became an adult. As for high school... hell I didn't even TRY to associate with people or groups that acted too "street, violent or ignorant." I just stayed the hell away from them because I knew I didn't really like them. However, I managed to get a little tougher to the point where the vast majority of this bunch would leave me alone as well because they could see it in my face that I didn't want to be bothered. I learned to stand up to them if provoked, and if someone pushed me too far then someone had a real fight on their hands. (People have a way of knowing who to mess with and who not to mess with... believe this.) I met up with a guy in a nightclub (or disco) who attended my high school several years after we'd all graduated. He came out and told me that he used to watch me in school and noticed the way I used to select my friends which really surprised me because he and I were never actual friends, and I didn't really think ANYONE paid attention to the few people I hung with except me! LOL Well he was right because I made it a point to only associate myself with kids who acted and carried themselves like regular well-mannered (or semi-well mannered) kids. They weren't "perfect" people and neither was I, but NONE of them were ignorant, ghetto, delinquent, violent or bullies. I didn't even try to date girls who acted like "hood girls" because I knew they represented one lane and I was driving in another. I found myself attracted to young ladies who ACTED like young ladies (and married one just like that). The bottom line is that I hate and literally despise ghetto mentality and behavior to this very day... and even moreso now because I know myself, and I have accepted who I really am as a person and an individual. If you want to say childhood and school experiences contributed to this strong dislike for ghetto behavior then you would not be wrong. lol 

Now back to you. I told you some of my personal story as a means of telling you that you are going to get a little tougher and "stand up for the person you really are inside." When you make the decision to do this then trust me... it will show on the outside because it will be genuine. You need to continue to speak your mind not only to this group and group leader you've told us about, but with "anyone" because practice is good. You should also "focus more on your future" in terms of your college major and the career you hope to have one day. Immerse yourself in people and activities that "make you smile" and focus more on the people you like instead of those whom you dislike. If you start to do more of these things, you will find that you won't even have TIME to deal with this troublesome group or any other type of nonsense to start with. Maybe it's just time to stop trying to fit-in where you no longer fit-in and move on. Just become too busy.  

I think I understand your feelings, concerns and need to separate yourself on a more gradual basis, and I respect them as well... so go ahead and do it gradually, but you can also do it more quickly if you make some changes in your own life and thinking. Start allowing yourself to experience and enjoy the company of other people whom you might have more in common with in terms of personality, interests understanding of the words "mutual respect." You need to move beyond this group of flakey and shakey individuals with a jerk for a ring leader because there's just something wrong with this group dynamic... and it really doesn't sound right for you because it's not who you are. You just seem to be more down-to-earth, intelligent that calm person who tolerates these people just to have friends, and people like you deserve better. 

Now here is where it gets really serious: If the spirit ever leads you to do so... you should pull the group leader away from the rest of the group or catch him or her alone one day and flat confront them about their behavior. It doesn't have to be angry... just be honest straight-forward, logical, vary rational but above all.. UNAFRAID. You will get better and more interesting results if you do this privately because if you try it in front of the group it could get ugly because you will have put this jerk on the spot and he/she will react in whatever way they deem necessary to hold power. lol If ever you decide to do this, you absolutely cannot be nervous, afraid or unsure of yourself in any way because he or she will sniff it out, sense it and try to pull a power play of some sort. You have to be ready for whatever no matter what and ready to deal with it. If it sounds like I'm saying you might even have to exchange a few punches that's exactly what I'm saying. Whatever you decide to do and however you decide to handle it... you have to stand up for yourself one way or another because you will encounter these type of people long after high school is over. I also want you to talk to your mom and dad or an older brother, sister, cousin or even a grand-parent about everything you've told me and see what they tell you as well. I will stop now, but I want you to have a great rest of your weekend and a good life. I've got a feeling great things are in store for you one day in your life, and everything you are experiencing and feeling now will help make it all come true.

Peace

stance_justification: The writer presents psychological insights with reasoning and causal explanations ('We often divert our thoughts trying to react to the situation than putting an effort to be an active listener when we are less confident'). stance_markers: ["I guess we need to ask ourselves", "usually people speak about themselves", "If we focus on being an active listener we will naturally", "This is just my perspective"]
text:
I guess we need to ask ourselves are we really enthusiastic and interested in what they are saying. Our presence in a conversation revolves around us being comfortable and feel confident with person involved. We often divert our thoughts trying to react to the situation than putting an effort to be an active listener when we are less confident. This works for sometime only and the other person can understand over time that we weren't even listening. 

We should focus on being genuinely interested in listening to others and their problems because usually people speak about themselves more than anything else. If we focus on being an active listener we will naturally be empathetic towards them and don't come across as uncaring. 

And best part is that only when we are genuinely interested in others, they become interested in us.

This is just my perspective and first Reddit comment.

stance_justification: The writer presents their advice as definitive facts rather than suggestions, using directive language like 'Smart doesn't factor in at all' and 'stop acting like there are smart and not smart people.' They provide step-by-step instructions as if there's one correct approach to making friends, without acknowledging that different strategies work for different people or situations.
stance_markers: ["Smart doesn't factor in at all", "stop acting like", "It's ALL just people", "Truly", "But above all", "don't focus on", "Make friends with as many people"]
text:
Smart doesn‚Äôt factor in at all. 
 
Demonstrably smart people are usually focused on a passion - a skill, area of study, hobby, etc. The way you meet them is by becoming a bit more of a joiner - say yes to all invitations, make time for your favorite sport, game, or other pastime. And, as you do this, you will be putting yourself around others who like those same things. And you‚Äôll start noticing the other regulars, and then it‚Äôs up to you to reach out and make a friend. 
 
College is a pretty easy venue. And unlike high school, you don‚Äôt have to make all your friends in the first few weeks - 5 in a month ain‚Äôt bad. But BE a good friend to those five, and let their networks start to filter in - make friends with their friends, hang at the same library/bar/cafe/spot on the lawn as them. Go to their parties. 
 
Of course, the other main way to make friends is through your classes - either you are both forced to take some required lecture and can take turns taking notes or something‚Ä¶ or you‚Äôre in a class you thought you might really like, amongst others who felt the same. Ideally, it IS fun and engaging, but even if it turns out to be a dud, you can commiserate with these classmates. Ask them what they did last weekend. Invite them out to that thing you‚Äôd never go to alone. 
 
But above all, stop acting like there are ‚Äúsmart‚Äù and ‚Äúnot smart‚Äù people. It‚Äôs ALL just people. Truly. They all have anxieties and confidences. Things they suck at. You are not unlike them, ALL of them. 
 
So, don‚Äôt focus on making just one kind of friend. Make friends with as many people in as many majors from as many places as you possibly can!

text:
1) If you have somewhere to go or something to do or want to continue your day, it's no problem to give a "Well I have work to do/ a prior engagement/ I'm heading off/ I gotta bounce/ I gotta get lunch" whatever works for you

2) If neither you or the other party have other priorities there's nothing wrong with just hanging out and allowing a lull in conversation to happen.  You're allowed to just relax, you don't have to be 'on' or talk constantly.  I've spent many hours with my best pals not saying a damn word and not feeling awkward at all.

stance_justification: The writer provides reasoning based on personal experience and general principles ('suicidal thoughts are a clear sign that you are not well'), acknowledges individual differences ('Everyone is different, though'), and shows nuanced thinking by distinguishing between the person and their behavior ('YOU are not toxic. Your behavior may be'). They present their advice as informed judgment rather than absolute truth.
stance_markers: ["What I've learned is", "Everyone is different, though", "For me, I need to be medicated", "YOU are not toxic. Your behavior may be", "It's really hard getting out of a funk like this but it can be done"]
text:
I‚Äôve been there myself. I‚Äôve seen my own behavior in retrospect and cringed, and I‚Äôve also been able to see it happening and been unable to control myself, and the suicidal thoughts would get worse and worse. What I‚Äôve learned is that suicidal thoughts are a clear sign that you are not well. Healthy people don‚Äôt consider suicide. These toxic behaviors are also a symptom of something else going on (depression, anxiety, etc). You are not as bad as you are making yourself think you are. For me, I need to be medicated to feel normal and keep control. Everyone is different, though. You need to get help and get yourself well. And try to curb those intrusive thoughts with positive ones. It‚Äôs really hard getting out of a funk like this but it can be done. 

Also, YOU are not toxic. Your behavior may be, but you are not.

stance_justification: The writer cites research evidence to support their position ('If you read some of the research on practice'), provides concrete examples to illustrate their reasoning (basketball/free throws analogy), and acknowledges the reader's alternative approach has merit ('your style of teaching yourself will definitely help you make more progress') while explaining why their recommended approach is stronger. They present their position as reasoned judgment rather than absolute truth.
stance_markers: ["If you read some of the research on practice", "To be fair, your style of teaching yourself will definitely help", "But working with someone else will help you make a lot more progress", "So it's really up to you", "is it worth making slower progress", "maybe reaching a lower ultimate level"]
text:
If you read some of the research on practice, it's not actually practice that helps you, it's DELIBERATE practice - with purposeful repetition of key skills, and immediate feedback from a skilled coach or other observer. If you got out and play basketball for 100 hours you might get a little better, but you're probably going to plateau pretty soon. But if you throw free throws for 100 hours under the eye of a skilled coach, you will get a lot better at throwing free throws.

Same thing with talking to people. You've been "practicing" doing it, but all of you've been practicing is the same old habits and patterns. If you want new habits, you need to do deliberate practice. 

To be fair, your style of teaching yourself will definitely help you make more progress than just continuing to talk aimlessly. But working with someone else will help you make a lot more progress than doing it by yourself. So it's really up to you - is it worth making slower progress (and maybe reaching a lower ultimate level of skill) so you can say "I did it all by myself?"

stance_justification: The writer acknowledges the complexity of the situation by presenting multiple perspectives ('On the other hand') and weighing different approaches based on their reasoning about power dynamics and social awkwardness. They provide specific reasoning for why direct invitations are problematic (transactional relationship creates pressure) while offering alternative strategies that address these concerns.
stance_markers: ["It's sort of inappropriate", "On the other hand", "That at least would be less awkward because", "if she isn't interested", "Hope that makes sense!"]
text: It's sort of inappropriate due to the transactional nature of your relationship. i.e. If you invite her to something and she turns you down, then she has to worry about losing your business. It's awkward to put someone in that position. On the other hand if you know she has an interest in a particular type of thing (an event?) that you're attending, you could mention that you're going to it. See if she expresses any interest. Another idea would be that you're so pleased with her service you'd like to treat her to (coffee? lunch?) sometime and see if that interests her. That at least would be less awkward because it would be somewhat easier to turn down (too busy...etc.) if she isn't interested, without just flat out turning down an open invitation for no reason. Hope that makes sense!

stance_justification: The writer demonstrates evaluativist thinking by acknowledging complexity ('everyone is different'), providing reasoned justifications for their advice, and weighing multiple considerations (appropriateness, context, individual differences). They show awareness that outcomes are uncertain ('you don't know how that's going to be taken') while still offering evaluated judgments based on reasoning.
stance_markers: ["you don't know how that's going to be taken", "everyone is different", "One woman might love compliments... another woman might find it invasive", "might come across as more neutral", "But say it while you're about to walk away... if you can", "If she's standing across from you... it could be awkward"]
text:
Don't compliment people on their bodies or their looks, in general. It's definitely creepy, especially when directed at women.  But her inviting smile could also be translated to "I really like how friendly you are" or "you seem like a really kind person."

You can comment more easily (less creepy/threatening) on a person's energy (like kind, friendly) or on something they're wearing. But if you have the tendency to come off as creepy maybe test this out with a female friend. Maybe stick to accessories rather than clothing covering their breasts or butt. Not that there's anything wrong with saying "that's a gorgeous dress" but you don't know how that's going to be taken, especially if you're not sure about how your tone of voice and body language come across. Something like "that's a great colour on you" might come across as more neutral. Also remember that everyone is different. One woman might love compliments about her smile or her eyes, another woman might find it invasive. Just be genuine, respectful, and keep it light. Maybe practice on people who are less intimidating at first. Find something you like about everyone you meet (not just the attractive people). Compliment people in passing. That's a lovely coat, great shoes, pretty earrings, love that colour. That's a fun umbrella. I do this with people who are walking in opposite directions on the street sometimes. It will help build your confidence.

You could say something like, "hey, it's your again! Your smile is the best thing about my morning." But say it while you're about to walk away or passing her, if you can. If she's standing across from you and you're behind the desk, it could be awkward for her as she's the one who'll have to walk away. Give her the compliment casually and then walk away. 

Edited to add: also, don't give compliments in order to get something from someone. That's always creepy. If you just want to compliment her because you think she's lovely and she needs to know it, that's great. It's even better because women are used to men complimenting in order to get a phone number or sex. So if you don't have any motives other than to let her know she's awesome, you'll do fine.

stance_justification: The writer presents a structured analysis with clear reasoning (categorizing fan types, explaining regional differences) while acknowledging individual variation and complexity. They use qualified language ('probably should watch,' 'maybe you don't like football because,' 'turns out maybe') and recognize that preferences are legitimate but can be informed through reasoned evaluation rather than treating all sports/preferences as equally valid without analysis.
stance_markers: ["you should probably watch", "maybe you don't like football because it's too long, but maybe you see something in basketball", "turns out, maybe", "not every sport is for everyone and some people like no sports at all. That's okay", "your goal is to try to enjoy it", "develop a genuine interest in whatever you think is interesting"]
text:
Where are you located? Anywhere in the United States, football will be king and baseball is more like a distraction during the summer unless the local team is in the hunt. Basketball, hockey, or even NASCAR is going to be popular depending on region.

There is a lot of talk about fantasy leagues. To me, that is geeking out on sports on a level I'm not interested in.

There are 4 levels of fans. 

First, there are the die-hards. They do nothing but watch ESPN all day. When two die hards start talking to each other at a party their conversation starts to become as socially toxic as two nerds discussing the relative stregnths of Java and Python.

Second there are homers. They grew up watching the sports they watch so they have the rules down. They watch their own city's teams or their particular favorites. They can walk into the last minutes of a game and have a good idea of where the game is at based on the situation.

Third there are pretenders. These are, I got to say, mostly girls, but anyone who is trying to fake interest in sports. They might wear the right jersey on game day, but when it comes down to it, they are chatting with the other pretenders about other topics during the most stressful parts of games. 

Finally there is you. You don't know or don't care about sports.

I can say you should probably watch a few games of whatever sports are popular in your region. You don't necessarily have to watch your local team for this, but you need to watch games cover to cover to understand what you are going to expect. The other suggestion that you play the games on consoles is good too, but as a fan of sports games, even I have my limit with Madden. That game is too hard for its fun payoff. But yeah, NHL 13 is superb. I hear FIFA is great. I can't comment to much on baseball or basketball games.

So, you're watching your game and you're not quite sure what happened. You have internet at your fingertips. Or take a smart bro with you to explain what's going on. 

I can tell you to appreciate football or hockey you're going to need like 20 minutes of coaching throughout the game. To appreciate baseball you're going to need 20 beers. Although baseball is often the cheapest to see live and a trip to the ballpark is a fun summer activity for everyone.

Anyway, not every sport is for everyone and some people like no sports at all. That's okay. But while watching your assignment game, your goal is to *try* to enjoy it. Put whatever preconceived notions you have about that sport or sports in general to the back of your mind. I feel like most people who strongly dislike sports either dislike the wannabe jocks who make them more important than they are or they dislike the fact that the players make so much money playing a game. Put that shit or anything like that to the side.

Turns out, maybe you don't like football because it's too long, but maybe you see something in basketball you never gave yourself a chance to see. Now you have a new hobby. If you live in North Carolina, for instance, you get to pick Duke or UNC or NC State and go out to a sports bar and watch their games.

What I wouldn't do is like learn enough to try to fake your way through a conversation. Develop a genuine interest in whatever you think is interesting.

Sports is a good conversation topic. Like politics, you can argue about strategies and relative merits of teams, but without seriously offending anyone's beliefs. Like the weather, certain games have an impact on the mood of the city you're in and it's better to understand why that is than it is to shake your fist at all of sportsdom. Like fandom, you have an opportunity to have meetups with people who share your interest.

TL;DR. Sports are fun. Try them. Allow yourself to be interested. Don't fake it. Root for the home team. Even if you try sports, and even if you don't care, if you're in a room with fans watching the game, just go ahead and pull for the home team. Don't be that guy  who wants to explain why sports rot your brain at the Super Bowl party.

text:
so having not thought about it before, these are my quick reckons:

- first, the extreme ends of the scale seem fairly clear: if you were already planning to compliment the person on a particular thing then i say go for it, the fact that they beat you to it shouldn't stop you. 
- on the other end of the scale, if you don't like something or you think it's meh then definitely don't give a false compliment, just say thank you and move on. 
- in the middle, one thing I think is basically always ok (as long as you mean it) is to compliment the same thing about them that they're complimenting about you. "I love your handbag"/ "thanks, I love yours too!" is a classic bonding moment.
- where it maybe starts to feel forced is if you seem to be searching for something to compliment, or if the thing you're complimenting is very far from three thing they're complimenting. "i loved what you said in that meeting"/"thanks, I love your handbag!" is gonna feel weird unless it's clearly deeply sincere. 

whether your reddit example falls in the first camp or the last camp for me depends on how strongly you feel about the compliment, if that makes sense?

Just my two cents and best of luck. It's not an easy journey but lighting only has to strike once

**\[This is just my opinion and you might not like it which is fine\]**  
First of all, sorry for the late reply, got bored of reddit just when I started lol. Tbh, if a person cannot respect you for being yourself or following something you believe in which is right and not offending others or hurting others, then you shouldn't be around them. If I was in a situation like this, I would move on first, and you should be proud of being a Buddhist, if that's what you are, then that's what you should be proud of. I won't stop you from pursuing other religions so if you wanna give Christianity a go, well go for it buddy. But don't go around doing this stuff for a girl, do this if you feel like, if you don't, why push yourself for someone who might move on and forget you sooner or later which is a possibility. And nice that you are making progress with her in general, friendships develop through chatting and getting to know each other better and they sometimes turn out to be relationships as well.

text:
To an extent, what you describe is normal - it's what people mean when they say they click better with some people than with others.  There's also the difference between immediate clicking, as happened with the first guy, and connection that builds over time.  It might just take you a bit longer to find that connection with the others.  It doesn't mean anything's wrong with you or with the others.

However, being the only one POC (or the only one of anything, really) does often get in the way of connecting.  Not because of you, because of prejudices or, at best, unconscious assumptions that people hold in their heads.  This is also something that could resolve as they get to know you better, but it's up to you whether you want to invest and potentially waste your precious time on these people, or whether you'd be better off looking elsewhere.

text:
Let me go over what has helped me. I'm going to break it down into two main categories.

Self:

\- Have passions. (Make sure there are  topics you are excited to discuss and share with others. If you do not yet have thigns you enjoy, this takes priority as it is important for your health.)

\- Have ethics. (Make sure you have your own set of morality from which to base your interactions with other people. This is something that I personally value very much but others may not. It is up to you whether or not you wish to disregard this.)

\- Look decent. (This one is a real pain in the ass but extremely important. If you look like shit you will be treated like shit. It shouldn't be so but it is. Pay attention to how you dress, groom, and exercise. If two people are equally amicable, the good lucking one will appear more likable.)

&#x200B;

Others:  


\- Others can be broken down to one major ideal and then several methods to achieve this ideal. Here is the ideal: EVERYONE WANTS TO FEEL VALUED. 

\- So... how do we make others feel valued? There are a lot of ways. Master these to start.  
1. Look people in their eyes. Yes, it matters.  
2. Smile at them. Practice your smile. No , easily seen through BS smile. Learn to believe your own smile.   
3. Talk to them about their interests. There is no way easier way to get others talking then to talk about their interests. This is harder than it seems . Don't just go, "what do you like... oh that's cool." Find their interests and speak in a way which is meant to have them as a mentor and you as a disciple. "Wait, so you are a surfer? Oh, that's amazing I've always wanted to surf! Where do you surf? That's the beach with all the taco places right? Oh my god, I fucking love that place. So you're one of those super fit people I  see surfing all the time while I'm pounding fish tacos, huh?" etc, etc, etc. It takes a LOT of practice to get good at this. You are going to seem very fake initially but once you get good you can talk with anyone.   
4. Compliment them sincerely (flattery doesn't count.) Find something you admire about the person that is neither shallow nor against their values and take earnest notice of it. There is a coffee place in front of my work. Everyone goes there before heading in and one of the girls there has one of the most stunning smiles you will ever see in your life. One day she hands me my coffee and I tell her this. I go, "You know, (name), you honestly have one of the best smiles I have ever seen in my life. Sometimes I think I'm coming here to see it rather than the caffeine. This was true. We text each other now.   


Here is the deal mate. You're young and you have a lot of life to learn. I didn't learn these lessons until my ass had been whopped ten ways to Sunday. I still have a lot to learn. Nobody is ever the perfect statesman and the best are constantly practicing. Abraham Lincoln used to write down his negative thoughts rather than expressing them. Reagan took notes on subjects he didn't understand that he knew his friends cared about. The both of them studied OTHERS andcared about OTHERS. They slowly perfected the art of making those others feel valued. 

EDIT: Whoops submitted early... still typing!

text:
It's a bit childish, so it depends on the person, but I'm a personal fan of the whole sitting-side-by-side-and-he-sways-over-to-bump-my-shoulder move. It's an instant way of telling if I like him back, too, because if I were uncomfortable I'd let out a nervous laugh, but if I liked him back I'd sway back and playfully nudge his shoulder. It's innocuous, it can be played off easily, and it's natural. Most guys I know that have done it do it during a lull in an otherwise good, comfortable conversation.

The other suggestions here are good too, for the most part. Light, quick forearm touching is good. However, I'd personally stay away from the shoulders, waist and back. A hand on my shoulder makes me want to instinctively shrug it off, and a hand on my back or waist feels creepy.

text:
I suffer with this too. 

What has actually helped me a ton is this: 

I realized at some point that people have a list in their head of what is important to them. Like their family, friends, loved ones. Or things that distress them like their self image, health, paying the bills, some drama situation in their life, etc. 

These things are all in our heads and we care about them A LOT. They take up a bunch of space in our heads like hard drives on a computer. Most of us don‚Äôt have the space in our heads to add more things to care about such as how a random person in public looks. They could make *observations* about us and then forget about it 10 seconds later because it doesn‚Äôt matter that much to them. Or they could make legit *judgements* about us, however how much weight they place about that judgement is tiny tiny tiny like 0.1% in their head. The rest of the 99.9% of their head are things they care about in their life, things that are much more important to them. And they‚Äôll probably forget about that judgement 10 seconds later and never give it another thought. They don‚Äôt have room in their head to care that much about a random person they see. 

This has alleviated a lot of stress and anxiety I have being in public when people are looking at me. Sure they might judge sometimes, but they don‚Äôt care about that judgement about me nearly as much as I think it does. Which has been really freeing to me. I‚Äôm not 100% perfect yet, but I‚Äôm significantly a lot better. 

That‚Äôs just me though. Everyone is different of corse. Just thought I‚Äôd share. And remember you‚Äôre not alone!

text:
Don't give up on life. 

I can't reply without ending up writing a poorly-written novel that doesn't really make sense, so that's why I usually don't reply.

All I can say is that by making "making connections" my main focus, I was making everything harder for myself. I saw awkwardness everywhere, I was so sure everyone thought very little of me, every failed attempt was another rock weighing me down. I focussed only on whether things were going well or not during every interaction: this made me overthink my actions and their reactions, keep silence when I should have tried to share/respond more, look awkward because I was trying too hard. 

Most people aren't apt socially to the point where they can completely change the vibe of an interaction. If I make it awkward, negative or cold from the start, it's hard for most people to make the conversation flow, to redirect the conversation away from self-deprecating jokes or make both of us comfortable enough to have an equal exchange. They feel my vibe, but they aren't able to easily change it. So they walk away instead of bringing themselves down. Which I get. Social interactions are stressful enough, I don't want the other person to make it worse. If the conversation really falls flat for you, it most likely does for them too. The difference is how much importance we give the "failed conversation". 

My first real friend, I met when I wasn't even trying. I was waiting for someone else who never showed up and was angry at her for leaving me alone. But I talked to this new person openly, enquired about her, share related experience. I didn't think anything would or even could come out of it, it was just an accident, I wasn't hung up on things going well, so I didn't overthinking. I was myself. Low and behold, we chatted for hours and it only hit me when we stopped. My usual self would have been over-analyzing everything I said and she said to make sure nothing was going wrong, making me less open, more awkward. 

So if I can suggest, don't give up on life. Give up on succeeding to make good connections, but keep trying to connect. Do things you love to do that don't necessarily require other people and, when you get the chance, strike up a conversation with someone. If it doesn't work out, don't focus on that. Forcefully make yourself get back to your activity again and tell yourself you did your best, you can't help what others do, and enjoy the rest of your day. Your plan was to have fun by yourself anyway, so there is no failure. It takes effort, but if you stop yourself whenever you have a negative thoughts about the what ifs and the maybes of an interaction and forcefully replace the thought with something positive (like "I tried, I can't know why the person walked away, so let's move on") before trying to focus on something else, eventually, it'll get easier. 

It did for me. It's still hard, but definitely easier than before. 

So don't make friendship or love the goal behind an interaction. Make striking a conversation the goal. That way, you succeed every time. The friendship is a nice bonus.

Practice helps too. Less social exposure for me means more social anxiety, more trouble with redirecting my thoughts away from overthinking. 

We only control our own actions, not other people's and not the outcomes. So it's up to you whether you start conversation or reach out to people. You can share your expectations as well. That's really all we should focus our energy on. 

We can't control others. We can't know what's going on in their heads and we are all biased in a way that makes our perspective on things (including other people's words) unique. It's basically a luck game. You just gotta click with someone (as in, have similar perspectives on interactions) enough on a certain levwl to build a good relationship. Sadly we can't control that, so we can work on being happy doing what we love, being happy with ourselves and letting people see that, so that we'll eventually be able to meet enough people to get to the right kind of people and once we get there, they get to see our true selves, not the layers and walls of coping mechanisms.

Edit: Typos

We are our own worst critics, and just because you can‚Äôt see something in yourself right now, doesn‚Äôt mean other people won‚Äôt.
