text:
College is a funny time of life for a majority of people. You meet so many new people in a short amount of time and people tend to come and go at the drop of a hat. People in college tend to move around to different circles of friends simply because of the type of lifestyle it is. People flunk or drop out, some graduate, some transfer colleges, some let their social circle get so big that sometimes it's hard to fit everyone in while studying.  

It sounds like you're a nice enough person but ask yourself if people only come to you when they want you to do them a favor or do they hang out with you for the hell of it and you occasionally do them favors? It could be that you need to evaluate who you call a friend because they may be using you. I don't know you and don't know your situation so that's your call to make. 

Lots of people are also fair weathered friends which are some of the worst friends to have. They want to be around you when everything in your life is wonderful but they leave at the first sign of you needing a helping hand. Save yourself the headache and avoid these at all costs.

As you get older and graduate you will find that those 20 or 30 people you thought were really good friends drift away. You will always have the memories and good times but a true, lifelong friend is really hard to come by. Count yourself lucky if you can find 1 or 2 really good friends who stick by you through thick and thin and who keep in contact with you long term.

As the person above stated, joining a club or extra curricular activity is a great way to meet people. Talking to people about homework and other school assignments or having study partners is another good way to meet people. Getting an on campus job or even off campus is another good one as well.  And good luck!!

I wouldn‚Äôt really call myself socially skilled, but I do encounter this problem a lot especially since I like to go to metal concerts.  

Usually I like to approach people with the same fashion sense because I really stick out in a crowd that‚Äôs dressed in all black.  I also like to have a drink in my hand because it gives my hands a place to rest, but that‚Äôs my own personal preference.  I suggest getting to the concert early so you can actually have a conversation without competing with the music.  If you find a person or group that seems pretty chill, but they‚Äôre in a conversation, I would stay close and wait for them to stop talking, and then enter the conversation.  I usually just ask them for their name unless there is something about them that I can comment on, and I quickly follow up with a basic question like ‚Äúwhere are you/you all from?‚Äù or ‚Äúhow did you get into (artist or band)?‚Äù  After that, the rest of the conversation is just up to you. 

I hope this helps.

text:
Hiya! I definitely get where you're coming from - I'm very much the kind of person who wants to fix the problem!! There are two main things I've found that help me empathize and care when people complain to me:

Firstly, I try to think of listening to the complainer as a solution in and of itself-- what I mean by that is, instead of finding an outside solution to the problem, consider that their solution is to find someone they trust and care about to confide in. Your listening and simply being there and acknowledging that it sucks can be a solution right there,  because it reassures your conversation partner in a big way, even if nothing's actually being solved. So that can help in terms of framing it and trying to get away from seeing it as pointless.

In terms of what to do now, then, I find that a combination of active listening (which, okay, 99% of the time active listening is kind of bs but when you're receiving a vent, restating what they're saying both helps you understand where they're coming from and proves you're invested in the conversation), as well as a focus on validating their emotions is important. When people vent, I find, they're rarely looking for solutions-- they just want reassurance that either someone feels the same way they do, or the way they feel is valid/normal. So being like "oh man I totally understand why your boss yelling at you would make you feel terrible" can be super helpful!!

Finally, I think it could be helpful for you to put up boundaries about what you do and don't want to engage in conversation about! If someone seems like they're going to be complaining about a person, you can even say like: "I'm grateful that you trust me enough to vent about this person, but I feel uncomfortable hearing vents about other people. What else can I do to help you feel okay right now?" Or something like that ^.^

It's a process for sure and reframing the discussion can help, but overall it's a journey to work on empathizing and caring when you're on the receiving end of complaints and vents. You got this!!

stance_justification: The writer provides reasoned analysis while acknowledging uncertainty and limitations. They use qualified language ('I think', 'this is only my opinion'), engage with the complexity of the issue by presenting a structured decision framework, and demonstrate metacognitive awareness by sharing their own experience and acknowledging what they don't know ('honestly, I don't know').
stance_markers: ["I think the first thing to do is", "this is only my opinion", "honestly, I don't know", "I don't think I could", "Of course you can", "It's good to be able to", "I really hope you figure things out"]
text:
I think the first thing to do is to decide whether you want to be more extroverted or if you want to stop being jealous of extroverts,  because you can't do both at the same time. You can't appreciate your introversion (thus, stopping to be jealous) if you try to change yourself. 

Being introverted is not a bad thing. Why do you want to become more extroverted if you feel fine spending time alone? If you enjoy your time when you're not with people, then you're not missing out on anything. If you do not want to go to parties, why do you feel like it would be better to go? Being introverted doesn't necessarily mean that your social skills are bad, and you shouldn't force yourself to be what you aren't. Reading your text, I couldn't help but feel that you force yourself to want something you don't want (if that makes sense). You don't want to hang out with people, but if you don't, you feel like a loser. Why? I mean, I know the feeling. I'll never in my life be an extrovert, and I very often feel like my surroundings evaluate my introversion as a bad thing. But it's natural for an extroverted person to think so, because for them, being with people is desirable. Unless they understand that this is not the case for you - that you enjoy your time alone or with a few best friends just as much as they enjoy their party-time - they are going to falsely deduct that you are missing out on something. Don't make the same mistake. There are a lot of people trying to be extroverted, (because in this world, we have to constantly prove and present ourselves), even if they aren't. That can make you very unhappy. In the end, only you know what you enjoy and what you want to do and you shouldn't let yourself be pressured by others. Or more, by their conception of what is good and desirable. 

Still, this is only my opinion, and if you really want to be an extrovert (think about it, do you really want to be an extrovert? Or do you feel like you have to?) , then, honestly, I don't know, I don't think I could change that part of me. Of course you can train interacting with people and you can improve your social skills (which is useful even if you are an introvert, and being introverted doesn't mean that you're not socially competent.). But I don't know if you'll ever enjoy it as much as an extrovert would. It's good to be able to communicate with people and be social and likable when you talk to them, but you don't have to be extroverted in order to do that. 

Sorry for the long answer (I had a rough time, too, coming to terms with my introversion). I really hope you figure things out and I wish you all the best. 

Stay safe!

text:
The thing is that thought can easily be used to claim that facts and feelings are mutually exclusive. That's obviously false. In all reality our feelings should be influenced and even based on some form of factual premise. You can't think critically without those facts. Your interpretation and understanding of that factual premise MUST have feeling and emotion, or you can't think empathically and compassionately. We NEED both, and a healthy balance at that. Fact provides a certain advanced level of functionality if you will while feelings provide a level of comfort. I personally would much prefer both in my life, and in society. Just my two cents

Edit: and yeah... Emotional appeals are just as important as logical appeals in argument. Classic pathos and logos.

You don't. That's the deal with trauma: you're going to have to live with it. Perhaps therapy given by an experienced psychologist might benefit you. There's no one-size-fits-all solution. It's up to you to learn to deal with your experiences one way or another.

You're an adult, so you can make your own decisions regarding partners; however, you're still young enough to fool around and learn from experience. You're in charge of making your own choices and of figuring out what you're good at and what you dream of. Rejection and hardship happen to everyone; avoiding them will only waste opportunities. It's up to you to rebuild your self-esteem and find out what you want in life. There's still plenty of time for all that, though.

text:
first thing first: loss of old self is often a warning sign of depression. time to check in with your doctor or your work's EAP if either of those are options and you haven't tried them already.

second thing second: as far as I can make out, being interest*ing* is generally a combination of a) being interest*ed* in stuff (which gives you material to play on) and b) understanding what parts of the stuff you're interested in will be interesting to other people (which makes the material you're playing on compelling). 

so, what things are you interested in, and how can you engage more with them? thinking about the groups you spend time with, what things are they interested in, and how can you engage more with those things? engagement can be passive (listening to podcasts, browsing subreddits, or whatever) or active (going dancing or kayaking or making music, or whatever).

third thing third: being *fun* is slightly different from being *interesting*. I'm trying to work this out as I type it, so this is a loosely held idea: I think being fun is to do with prioritising enjoyment over safety. it means making jokes without worrying about exactly how they'll land, or proposing activities without worrying about exactly how they'll turn out. I reckon this is partly why depression is such a fun-killer: depression makes you assume everything will turn out badly, so you don't bother to try, if that makes sense?

text:
Random stuff, anything on your mind.

Why carrots are orange, how you saw a perv in the club, about how you forgot to lock your door. What you did today, what you want to do.

Talk to entertain yourself. Picturing it like this helps me alot.

Laughter in my opinion is the best medicine. So aim to make yourself laugh and happy. If your stuff is doing silly dancing, messing about with people and making them uncomfortable then do that.

You'll notice those people who've been friends for years and years they sometimes rarely speak to each other. Just because your best friends dosnt mean you have to talk every second of every day of every week.

You need to find the formula, the balance between talking about yourself and them. Do more stuff, experiment, be silly, because then you'll have funny stories and more opinions about things.

What I'm trying to say is there's no answer, no framework to learn. And if your worrying about what to say to people and what to talk bout then that already tells you enough.. your spending time on thinking about what to say to people when you should be just getting on with your life and making yourself happy.

Everyone is different. For instance another thing I notice works is when I don't focus too much on the conversation. That way if my mind is focused on a task rather than the person I give a natural response saying what I truly want to say instead of filtering and thinking and thinking again and thinking I can't say that because of this or this because of that or this because it's too suggestive of this, etc.

text:
I speak from experience. Last summer, I ran my own franchise that required me to call up previous customers that I had never met before, along with new customers that I had met face to face. Prior to the job, I absolutely DREADED making any phone call, and you can just forget it if you think I'd leave a message. Heavens no. My anxiety wouldn't let me. But after just two months of working, I was a phone calling champ. Nowadays, I won't hesitate to make a phone call. 

My advice to you: I know this might sound counterintuitive, but perhaps you could try telemarketing. I doubt it will be challenging to get a job in telemarketing, as they'll take anyone who has a set of vocal chords. With your anxiety, it obviously will be difficult at first. If you are tenacious about the job, then you will likely overcome your anxiety. Also of note is that you don't know and never will really know the people you are calling. They are of little significance to you and don't matter. They're just another 7 digit number in your call list. No need to be anxious about what they think of you, or messing up (Is this where your anxiety lies?). While you are employed as a telemarketer, you can search for a long term job that caters to your needs. If the job causes you to slowly overcome your anxiety, you'll have a whole new array of jobs that you'd be able to apply to. Everyone has a different definition of what it means to succeed in life. Overcoming ones flaws and becoming a better person is in my personal definition. How about you?

text:
What a delightful read to see the world through an intellectual mindset. I am going to respond to this different than usual as you think differently...which is beautiful. You appear to have a lot of self doubt, I suggest you look into these three areas of changing your mental state; perception, mirroring and anchoring. A person lost 10 lbs, that person is also overweight, both are true statements however it is our perception that makes the difference. I of course do not mean this in a polyannic way, but it is better to see the positives. Mirroring: Find a video of someone you idolize socially, copy their mannerisms, the more the better...you'll begin to see the world through their eyes. Finally anchoring; remember a time when you had social success, imagion how it looked, sounded and felt, when you reach the highest state touch somewhere on your body. Do that several times and you'll find when you do it later you get into the state without thinking about it. 

The reason I chose to respond this way is that I know you'll use your intellect to find out more about these ideas yourself, pm me with any further questions.

text:
First off, find a hobby. Find topics that you are willing to discuss, like a debate-y discussion, because those tend to compel people to reply. I talk about history and current events with people, and usually they move on to different topics. Don't force your opinions on them, take a passive approach to answers: "Yea, I find tiktok kinda dumb tbh, but that's just my opinion. Some people do make genuinely interesting content" instead of "Oh fuck tiktok, that thing's shit and only used by people without brain cells"

Another pointer is to stop talking too much. I have a friend who drones on and on about topics, even when people aren't listening, and people don't really like him for that (they find him too chatty). Most people don't tell him to shut up because they're being polite (I'm one of those who actually tells him to shut it because it interrupts my inner voice). Instead, throw out random opinions every once in a while. Stuff like "Have you noticed that despite being right handed, some people use their left hand for spoons?" or something like that. It gets them to think, breaks the ice, and helps them talk to you easier.

Last but not least, try to find your own identity. People do get girls by trying to be what girls like, but not many people keep them. Find your niche (maybe you're a car junkie, history buff, crazy smart about human behaviour), and naturally you'll find people who are more interesting tan the average narcissistic basic guy/girl. For example, I'm that one guy who carries a camera 24/7, will stand in a field at noon if I find a plane flying, or completely shut everyone up just to hear a nice car/plane drive/fly by. Most of my friends tend to be interested in photography, planes, cars, or more.

Also an addition, I'm 20 and I've not actually had a girlfriend, though a girl was crushing on me a while back.

text:
**Damn, what do you think makes you struggle the most? is it anxiety. Because if it is, I just want to say things that helped me when I felt similar to your situation**

People that are anxious tend to be hyper-critical of themselves and all their mistakes.

### 1.) No need to be perfect

You are allowed, if not encouraged to make mistakes. People (I included) often go over the things they said wrong, etc. However, you can make mistakes socially just as much you can make academically.

Seeing things logically helps. When you get a question wrong on a math test, do you automatically get a 0? Of course not, you can even get a few questions wrong and still get an A. 

Try to think about what you do in a convo overall. If you're being a positive person throughout the conversation, nobody is going to think of the dumb/rude thing you said. Most of the time, you think you said something wrong, but it really wasn't.

I realize that many people assume that if others do not show a positive response to what they say, then they substitute that feeling for disapproval;/hostility. When they might have just been indifferent.

  

**2.) Girls are Usually more Nervous** 

Not trying to come off as sexist, just speaking based off what I hear, see and learned.

When guys are interested in another woman. Most of the time they need to approach to make something happen.

Most of the time it is the women dropping as many ‚Äúhints‚Äù as possible to attract another man.

Women tend to be much more emotionally intelligent and connected then men. That‚Äôs why it may seem that they are so good at keeping there cool but being approached is nerve-racking for them as well.

How would you feel if a beautiful woman started talking to you out of thin air? Most would have trouble keeping their cool

Secondly, you‚Äôre in a frat, people look up to you, not the other way around. You have the ‚Äúsocial validation‚Äù. Many other women probably assume that you‚Äôre just not interested in them and would be flattered you spoke to them.

 Key tip:

* **Catch a glance? Smile at them, if they      smile back, you‚Äôre in the clear**

**If you catch them looking at you twice, go ahead: I** realized that most women tend not to check out anything that walks by like many men do.  

I just published the full article based off your question giving [8 tips about romantic interests and social anxiety.](https://wordpress.com/view/mikemadecontent.com)

I once read that some people( specially if they're bright, like you said he is) appreciate touch, because they feel that it is a way of getting closer to the people they want/appreciate/love. He probably thinks of you as a great friend. 

I've been at his side. I once had a guy friend that I loved like a brother. I wanted to hug him all the time, but never did because he could have seen it as gay or annoying. It was frustrating and a bit sad, but the few times he did hug me, it was heartwarming and felt better than anything.

Also, as a disclaimer, it's my theory: it could depend of what you have seen of him. Maybe he really is gay.

stance_markers: ["I think", "It sounds like", "It also seems like", "correct me if I'm wrong, but I'm getting this vibe", "I think that what's going on here is not necessarily", "it's possible to salvage", "It would be better to talk in person"]
text:
It sounds like you two were closer friends. You counted on him to drive you to a surgical appointment. I think he doesn't care if the other guys make fun of him because they are more like acquaintances, and maybe he only puts up with their bullshit to hang out with you. It also seems like he is more often the butt of the joke, which is mean-spirited, and sometimes, hateful (calling him a homophobic slur.). He might not say it-- because in some Western countries, at least in the U.S., the culture of masculinity dictates that men can only tell their friends they care about each other if everyone is wasted--but he probably considers you a close friend. I think you consider him a close friend, too. I think that's why you feel betrayed (correct me if I'm wrong, but I'm getting this vibe from your post) that he left the party on the night that that girl raped you, because you feel that if your good friend were there, it never would have happened. And you don't consider the other guys (the guys who called your good friend a f**) close friends, because you don't feel as betrayed by them. They didn't intervene, and in hindsight, you didn't expect them to, because they don't look out for you like your good friend does. He has your back, so that's why you asked him to drive you to your surgery. 

I just want to say that I'm really sorry that you had that happen to you. It's not your fault. If you're in the U.S., the National Sexual Assault Hotline is 1-800-656-4673. They also have an online chat at https://hotline.rainn.org/online/terms-of-service.jsp
It might help to talk to someone. I've personally used the chat, and the volunteers were nice. You also don't have to talk to someone if you don't want to either. Whatever you decide is up to you.

I think that what's going on here is not necessarily that your friend is being too sensitive, but that you two have a rift over some hurtful experiences. He might still be upset because you didn't stand up for him when the other guys called him a f**. He might be bringing up stuff from the past because it's still hurtful, and he's expecting an apology, and hoping that by mentioning it, you will pick up on the cues, and apologize. And you're still upset because he wasn't there to take you to your surgery, but also that he wasn't there to watch your back. It's understandable that he would leave when being mocked like that, and it's not his fault that she raped you. It's her fault. There is no way that you or your friend could have foreseen it to prevent it.

I think that your friend cares about you, and it's possible to salvage the friendship, if you guys talk about it. It would be better to talk in person, because it's easy to misconstrue tone in writing. On the phone is the second best form of communication, because you can hear tone, but in-person is best because you can see body language at the same time.

text: OK. ive been getting high 0-7 nights a week to go to sleep for the past 3 years and i have to say, you are very mistaken. This is the problem, people have these misconceptions about weed in particular and they keep throwing around these negatives that aren't true. Withdrawals are the same thing you get from alcohol and caffeine and those two also apply to poor sleep quality. But it is proven through studies and my own experiences that there is very little to no difference in sleep quality stoned vs sober and the only difference is that you can fall asleep much faster with weed. The other thing, SMOKING weed might be worse because you are SMOKING which isn't harmful but it is bad to an extent and might result in some poor sleep. stance_justification: The writer presents their advice as definitive truths using directive language like 'just forget about that perspective' and 'You WANT to piss some people off.' They dismiss alternative viewpoints without engagement and frame their claims as obvious facts rather than reasoned judgments, using certainty markers like 'That's how networking and friendships work' and 'People see someone having fun being themselves and they want to be around that person automatically.'
stance_markers: ["just forget about that perspective", "That's how networking and friendships work", "You WANT to piss some people off", "Don't worry about", "You can meet people at any time", "It doesn't matter if", "People see someone having fun being themselves and they want to be around that person automatically", "It's real simple", "seem obvious"]
text:
Okay, first off, just forget about that perspective that people have "paired up" or are in their own "groups." You can meet people at any time. It doesn't matter if they have friends or not. Chances are the people you do meet will already have friends and if you just meet one person, you can meet their friends through them. That's how networking and friendships work. You meet one person and then you meet another through that person and another and another. And if you get really good at just talking to strangers on the street, you can expand pretty fast (but I think that's way beyond what you're thinking about or wanting at the moment). You already know you can make some people laugh, right? Your current friends already enjoy you, right? Who's to say more people won't also enjoy you? Don't focus on trying to get anything out of anyone. Don't look for validation. Don't look for them to like you. Focus and remember that you are awesome to people that already know you and you can be awesome to people you just met too. Maybe you won't be as funny at first, but that doesn't matter. You'd be in the "getting to know them" phase. And this phase can be an exciting time! You can tell your story, make new jokes, find out about the other person.

Don't worry about pissing people off by saying the wrong thing. You WANT to piss some people off by being yourself. If you weren't being yourself, then when they do find about the real you (and they will), then they wouldn't be your friend anyway. And you don't want to be friends with people that won't be friends with the real you.

If you want a helpful book, read Dale Carnegie's How To Win Friends and Influence People. It's real simple, a lot of the concepts are straight forward and seem obvious. It's just nice that he actually says them and why they're important.

Be yourself, and focus on having fun with it! People see someone having fun being themselves and they want to be around that person automatically.

text: Just my opinion, but I would not expect too much out of your relationship with that person, even in the future. We're not entitled to anyone's friendship or affection and I don't think we should ever really "force" ourselves onto anyone else if we can realize that we're doing that. She's already giving you the amount of attention she's willing to give, no sense in anticipating this to change. I would just think of her as a casual acquaintance that you enjoy and I don't see the problem in checking in with her once in a while (to me, this means once every few months to once a year), just would not want you to expect anything to come out of that. You seem like you're really emotionally invested in this relationship but that you are trying to be less so, and I think that's the right thing to do.

stance_justification: The writer presents their framework about love and relationships as universal truths using definitive language ('That is the true meaning of loving someone,' 'the expectation of love is a love-repellant'). They make prescriptive statements about what the reader 'can' and 'cannot' do without acknowledging these as personal perspectives or providing reasoning for why these principles should be accepted.
stance_markers: ["That is the true meaning of loving someone", "All you can do is", "you cannot expect it and you cannot be disappointed", "the expectation of love is a love-repellant", "You can *still* inspire them", "the way to avoid it is not to be disappointed"]
text:
You had inspired them to go above and beyond their SMO.  Then they want to drop back a bit toward their SMO.  You can *still* inspire them to go above and beyond their SMO!  But you cannot expect it and you cannot be disappointed by not getting it.

All you can do is derive your own happiness from your own efforts to go above and beyond your own SMO to try and promote and enjoy their happiness, because that is what makes you feel happy.  That is the true meaning of loving someone.  

Anything extra, above their SMO in an effort to promote and enjoy your happiness is a gift/bonus to you- their love of your happiness, their happiness in promoting and enjoying your happiness which also makes you feel joyful in seeing their happiness and joy- it becomes a circulation. 

Unrequited love can be painful, but the way to avoid it is not to be disappointed by it!  That's a tough sentence to read because of the negatives, so in other words: "the expectation of love is a love-repellant".  If you still arent feeling loved after some passage of time, it can be some tough feelings to go through but sometimes the timing, or the person, just isn't meant to be.  It's up to you to decide how to apply the principles of positive growth for yourself and others around you in a way that you feel comfortable with.  If you feel the need to leave someday, you'll find your way out one way or another.

stance_markers: ["those are tough", "what is ultimately the right decision", "I try to center myself on the overall truth", "If I play any of the other decisions forward, they're hollow and false", "I stewed for a bit, got my emotions in check, figured out", "It was a decision I knew I had presented kindly, honestly and that I could live with"]
text:
Ah. Those are tough. At the root of each of those, your intent is not to hurt, but to make what is ultimately the right decision. If you can‚Äôt be with your decision wholeheartedly, then you‚Äôre not really giving them what they want either. You‚Äôre only half in. When I‚Äôm faced with situations like those, I try to center myself on the overall truth of the situation and then present it with love and honesty. If I play any of the other decisions forward, they‚Äôre hollow and false and I can‚Äôt commit to them healthily long term, which means that it may look like a good choice to the other person at first, but really isn‚Äôt good for anyone in the long term. I present the truth to them (that I‚Äôm struggling with the response, how I see the other outcome). The boss situation you mentioned:  ‚ÄòI know you had plans for me and I respect and like you so much, this is really tough for me, but I don‚Äôt feel I could truly provide my best for you long term by staying here. I really need to (do other things, make more money...).‚Äô 

RLExample: my husband was out of town, I was absolutely stretched thin with a new child and busy work schedule. My mother in law announced that she‚Äôd be coming to help. To me, that wasn‚Äôt helpful, it was intrusive and pushy and I simply didn‚Äôt have the emotional bandwidth to have a visitor. I stewed for a bit, got my emotions in check, figured out it really was me and this time had to be about me (I didn‚Äôt want to set a precedent of her just showing up, I didn‚Äôt want to blow up at her at some point if she did visit and knew I might have and I really had to honor what I felt was best at that time).  I politely apologized and hoped I hadn‚Äôt mislead her, but I really couldn‚Äôt take her up on her kind offer. It would simply have been too much for me at the time. It was a decision I knew I had presented kindly, honestly and that I could live with regardless of her reaction.

stance_markers: ["I would be absolutely uncomfortable", "This means he is already aware", "What he needs is", "Part of what that means is", "What you're trying to do is", "All that said, I don't think confronting his fears is a terrible idea", "He just needs to", "It sounds like he's doing his best"]
text:
Please do not try and force him into this. I would be absolutely uncomfortable doing improv and I'm not generally a socially awkward person.

You said he is in therapy and getting better. This means he is already aware of the problems and is working on them. What he needs is you to support him. Part of what that means is letting him take small steps to overcoming his fear. What you're trying to do is take someone who's afraid of water and throw them into the deep end of the pool just when they were almost ready to wade in past their knees. 

You want him to know he can trust you, but if he thinks you're going to try and force him into doing something that  terrifies him to the point of tears, he's going to stop opening up to you. 

All that said, I don't think confronting his fears is a terrible idea. He just needs to start way smaller. Encourage him to have small conversations with the cashier at the grocery store, ask him more questions to get him talking more, make "no phone" rules when you hang out with friends or go out, etc. It sounds like he's doing his best so just be patient and kind and he'll continue to improve.

Why would you want to win the approval of people who shit on you? Of people who shit on anyone? 

You can want a fulfilling life. But you cannot expect others to hold your hand. Maybe do something different. Do what works and stick with that. 

Do what is/will be effective in achieving your goals, NOT what you feel/think you should do. Figure it out through trial and error. Clearly you keep doing the same shit over and over and then beat yourself up telling yourself nothing works. 

Life is an act. If people are not naturally attracted to your presence, then it is up to you to figure it out, no one else. If you have to act against your feelings, so that people don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre weird, well then you will never meet people who know the real you. Fuck the people who think you are weird, and embrace the people who think you are interesting. 

Stop thinking people even know why you make them feel the way you do. Because i guarantee you, most can‚Äôt put it into words why, and even if they could it is generally polite to not just lay into someone about how much you cannot stand them. 

This is entirely on you to figure out

stance_justification: The writer presents their communication advice as universal truth ('It's universal') and uses definitive, prescriptive language throughout ('Don't do any of that,' 'you need to realize,' 'That's not how you convince people'). They treat their framework as objectively correct rather than as one perspective among many, showing little acknowledgment that their approach might not work for everyone or every situation.
stance_markers: ["It's universal", "That's not how you convince people", "you need to realize", "Don't do any of that", "No arguing over unwinnable points", "just listen", "There's actually a method you can follow", "It's pretty straight-forward"]
text:
It's universal. Think about it: when someone speaks, what is it they want? They want to know they're being heard. They want to feel like you're listening. They want to feel like you care. They don't necessarily care if you agree or not and they aren't necessarily trying to convince you that they're right. They just want to be taken seriously. They want to feel as if their thoughts, problems, fears, and ideas matter.

This is why counter-arguments and problem solving are usually the wrong approach. Because unless they're looking to debate you, which I highly doubt, they're not trying to convince you of anything. And you need to realize that, even if you're right, you aren't changing their minds this way. That's not how you convince people. That's not to say that your opinions don't matter, or that facts don't matter, or that you shouldn't speak up when you feel strongly about something, but you should recognize that, if this person is important to you, it's *more* important to show that you support them as a person than show you don't support their ideas.

Besides, here's the two possibilities you're dealing with: either they're completely set in their ways or they aren't. If they're set in their ways, what makes you think they'd ever change their minds based on *anything* you could say? Their position is inherently irrational (from your perspective), which means there's no rational way to convince them to change their position. Better to just focus on what you have in common. On the other hand, if they're flexible, then you still need to realize you catch more flies with honey. By letting them voice their wrong (in your opinion) thoughts, asking them non-judgmental questions, and not shooting them down, you're proving that you're flexible, too. You're willing to listen, you're willing to respect their opinion, and guess what? In time, they might soften to your opinion as well.

So just... don't. Don't do any of that. No arguing over unwinnable points. No fixing things unless people genuinely seek your advice--but even then, treat lightly.

In short: just listen. Get good at listening and the rest will come in time. And the funny thing is, people want to talk to listeners, but they also want to hear what they have to say. Watch someone like Charlie Rose and see what a brilliant listener (and questioner) he is. He'll often weigh in with his own take, but he's a brilliant interviewer and his greatest skill is in the questions he asks and the rapport he builds with his interviewee.

There's actually a method you can follow. It's pretty straight-forward:

Ask a genuine question that's fun to answer (people like talking about themselves, their hobbies, and the things they're passionate about) > listen closely, don't interrupt, and try to avoid annoying stuff like finishing their.... sandwiches > when they've answered, respond by repeating back what they've said--not verbatim, but in a way that shows you were listening, and show genuine curiosity and/or enthusiasm for the subject (if this seems fake to you, ask yourself: if you aren't enthusiastic or curious, why are you talking to them in the first place?) > at this point they're either talking to you about a subject you can relate to or something you know nothing about, if you can relate, do so ("yeah, I love old kung fu flicks as well, my favorite is Enter the Dragon..."), if you can't relate, demonstrate your interest by asking more about it ("the closest thing to a real kung fu movie I've ever seen is *Shanghai Knights*, but I'd love to watch some proper ones, I just don't know where to start"). You just repeat this process of ask > listen > relate > ask over and over again. You'd be surprised how quickly people will open up to you, because most people, even the good talkers, aren't very good listeners, and *everyone* likes a good listener. And don't be afraid of showing your ignorance. People love to help other people. They love to initiate new people to the niche stuff they're into. Whether you've seen a bunch of kung fu movies or not, you're essentially making yourself available to hang out with in the future. You're opening the door to future hangouts/dates/parties/whatevers where you'll watch kung fu movies together, either because you love them too or because you're curious and eager to see more.

Anyway, hope that helps.

**TL;DR:** be curious, learn the listening before you learn the talking.

stance_markers: ["Now I don't know you, so I can't tell you", "Makes sense right?", "So here is what I think you should do", "Obviously there is much more to it than that but you have to start somewhere right?", "hopefully some really great long-term friends"]
text:
I am just going to stop you there and not let you put "being a good friend" as something you bring to the table. Being good to not only your friends but other people should be done anyways. If you put too much work into being the best friend possible you might leave yourself out of that. Thats what I did at least. 

Now I don't know you, so I can't tell you what you bring to the table, but I can tell you that you bring things to the table by working on yourself as a person. Makes sense right? The better you are at things, the more you have to bring. 

So here is what I think you should do. Find a hobby you love, something that can be done socially preferably. Now join a group and do it. Get better at it. Invest the time in yourself. Use the people around you to help push yourself further and help them grow as well. 

By doing this you will meet new people, and hopefully some really great long-term friends with similar interests. You will also feel like you have something to offer because you will have a skill that you continue to develop. Obviously there is much more to it than that but you have to start somewhere right?

stance_justification: The writer presents dating advice as definitive facts using certainty language like '100% okay', 'Period', and 'WAY WAY better'. They make broad generalizations about women's behavior ('Girls cheat just as much as guys') as objective truths without qualification. While they acknowledge some variability ('Not all girls', 'hit or miss'), they frame this as tactical considerations within an overall certain framework rather than genuine uncertainty about their claims.
stance_markers: ["100% okay", "Period", "WAY WAY better", "Girls cheat just as much as guys", "That is enough of a sign", "you have to be firm", "Just stay focused"]
text:
1) Yes it's 100% okay to go on multiple dates. Just be clear to the girl you're hanging out with that you don't jump into dating until at least a month or 2 in. Because you got to get to know them. Nothing polygamous about it. 

2) I doubt girls focus on one guy at a time (Not all girls). Girls cheat just as much as guys. And I am sure they have gotten comments from many many men. Wait to see how these girls react to you in the long run that you do what you want, they should want to keep your attention. The app deleting/Talking to no one else is a sign they want you long term (REALLY good sign), but it's UP TO YOU in the end what you want to do. Don't get emotional about your choice or feel bad, especially if you haven't been on a date yet. 

If a girl is talking to you. That is enough of a sign that she's interested in dating you. Even sometimes when she's not talking to you it's a sign she could be interested. Some people like to get testy with you to see how you'll react, but you have to be firm and confident in your action making. (But if a girl tells you to back off. Then BACK OFF. Period.)

As well, Meeting people in real life like bars, clubs, social gatherings can be WAY WAY better if you have a few hours on the weekend and the confidence to talk to a lot of girls. I have actually gotten a couple dates from girls I've met at bus stops (Not straight up "Lets date" but more like "Hi, What are you taking at university?".) Which can be much more rewarding when you meet the right girl. Be open. 

As for online dating, It's hit or miss for me. Some girls will give a lot of feedback, some not as much. Just stay focused, text once in a while, have a good time, try to set up a date when there is availability. Send a girl a joke or a story. If she doesn't reply send her something else in a couple days. And then ask her out within the next 2 days after that. Online dating is a long term game sometimes.

stance_markers: ["I think in general", "There are a few studies that show", "I find that people also tend to", "it's up to you to feel out", "If you think he's misinterpreted", "as appropriate"]
text:
I have that problem a lot, too.  I think in general, a lot of men conflate female interaction with flirtation automatically. There are a few studies that show the more attracted a man is to a woman, the more attractive they PERCIEVE the woman to be to them. Also, I think porn use plays a role (the idea that a lot of women are"available" aka interested). I find that people also tend to make comments and"couple" women and men together when hanging out as friends, so that can be your opportunity to say something. 
I have a lot of guy friends and none of them have any sexual/romantic interest in me, so it's up to you to feel out how this guy is acting and see if it's even an issue that needs to be addressed. If you think he's misinterpreted, you can comment as appropriate.

No need to ask permission from your boyfriend (LOL what a suggestion!), but it's polite to let him know upfront as a clear indication of transparency so he doesn't feel weird hearing about it later

text:
It depends on the person you are going with, having said that, here is some stuff that comes to mind:

**Do**

**1. Smell nice.** 

**2. Listen well.** Learn about her.

**3. Be natural with compliment timing and delivery.** If you don't mean it, don't say it, if you do mean it, say it like you mean it.

**4. Observe.** When you watch people interact with their surroundings, you learn a lot. If she is into dancing, by all means dance, even if you feel silly or embarrassed, don't take it all too seriously and have fun.

**5. Be confident** How? Be yourself. 

**6. Apply the appropriate amount of chivalry.** Some girls love a guy who holds the door, some despise. Gauge this and respond accordingly.

**7. Enjoy her company.**  Have fun. Laugh. Make eye contact. She'll like you liking her.

**8. Take a risk.** Be brave. If you feel scared or nervous, it's an opportunity to overcome it and slay the dragon of intimidation. Do something unique in that you follow your heart, which is sadly a rare occurrence.

**DON'T**

**1. Be gross.** 

**2. Make her feel uncomfortable.** 

**3. Look at other girls.** some guys have a major problem with this. I don't get it.

**4. Worry about what she's thinking.** 

**5. Forget to check your swag.** Guys have to go to the bathroom and check themselves out to make sure they are still looking fresh and clean, too.



**6. Be afraid to touch her.** Starts with a light back hand touch to her shoulder then turns into a small rub of the shoulder. You have to flirt with her and part of that is physical contact, basically. So it starts small and escalates from there. If she isn't receptive or is the type of person who doesn't like to be touched, ease up and just stay friendly.

**7. Leave too late.** Always leave her wanting more. This goes for anything. Time to wrap it up during the falling action, not the denouement.

  
I would also prepare a [mind script](http://colorgenicstest.com/Goldin-Girl-Column/how-using-a-mind-script-will-make-your-life-better.html) for yourself so that you don't give off nervous vibes at certain times.

Good luck, man.
